reviewText: I didn't plan on seeing this film until I bought both Hunger Games steelbooks that came with two free passes. I was not expecting much at all due to the reviews, but I'm happy to report that Divergent is way better than the critics are saying. It's not quite up to The Hunger Games, but it also strays far away from the awful Twilight franchise, which I was initially afraid it would end up being. The story is interesting and the cast is pretty good, especially Shailene Woodley as Jennifer Lawrence lite. I have a feeling the sequels will be even better since this is really just a long, yet engaging setup.

Divergent was a great ride, so fun, very good looking, and it will only get better, trust me im a doctor....no im not, but the story is so very different than Hunger games if you were wondering, i don't want to spoil it for you guys but keep on this series guys!!!

"Divergent" will inevitably be compared by many to that other YA book series, "Hunger Games." And while both books have strong young heroines, the books and movies are actually quite different. See the movie and judge for yourself. I went to see it with my family, but the theater had audiences of all ages - from older 40-50 something couples, to groups of high school-college friends, to middle schoolers with their friends or families. I would recommend this to the same audience that went to see "Hunger Games" - PG-13 and up.

For those not familiar with Veronica Roth's book, "Divergent" is the story of Beatrice (Tris) Prior, a young lady living in futuristic Chicago. Due to post-war effects, their society is divided into 5 factions that represent 5 virtues - Abnegation (selflessness/service to others), Candor (honesty), Dauntless (bravery), Amity (peace) and Erudite (knowledge/learning). Those who do not belong to a faction (basically, ostracized from society) are called "factionless." When they come of age, they attend a ceremony to select the faction they will join for the rest of their lives. Most choose the faction they are born in, while others may "defect." During the pre-ceremony aptitude test, Beatrice is told that her test results were "inconclusive", meaning she doesn't see to belong to a specific group. They call this "Divergent." Their society views "Divergents" as dangerous so Beatrice must keep this secret to protect her life.  When she chooses her faction, she meets her new mentor and trainer Four and the brutal Eric and forms friendships with other new initiates Christina, Will and Al.  The physical and mental training (think "boot camp") is intensive and challenging and Tris needs to find a way to survive. She eventually finds an ally in Four, who isn't quite what he seems.

The movie does a great job introducing the faction-based society to audiences, so you don't need to have read the book to enjoy or understand the plot. Having read the book, I would say I am very satisfied with the casting choices and the outcome of the film. I would consider this a faithful adaptation to the book - some scenes were excised due to time constraints and/or continuity/flow, but this is understandable if you take into account the differences between the book vs. film medium.

In terms of casting, I admit I was skeptical about Shailene Woodley (Tris) at first. Physically, she doesn't quite match up to book Tris (who is supposed to be small and waif-ish). But Shailene has the ability to take on this role of a vulnerable and conflicted young woman at the beginning of the film who grows in strength and confidence as the story goes on.  Some would say that Theo James is much older than his book counterpart, but I can clearly see why he was chosen to play the complex Four. Theo plays Four with quiet strength and charisma - he is an imposing authority figure, but there is some vulnerability a well. He won me over from the first scene and he and Shailene have an undeniable chemistry. Kate Winslet (Jeanine Matthews), Jai Courtney (Eric) and Miles Teller (Peter) are also stand-outs. The remaining main supporting cast are Tony Goldwyn and Ashley Judd (Tris' parents), Ansel Elgort (Caleb - Tris' brother), Ray Stevenson (Marcus Eaton) and Tris' fellow initiates Zoe Kravitz (Christina), Ben Lloyd Hughes (Will) and Christian Madsen (Al).  They capture the essence of their book counterparts very well and, while they are currently relative unknowns, I can see bright futures for the young cast. (And, yes, girls and boys, whether intentional or not, there is a lot of "eye candy" in this movie. I get it. Even Jai Courtney's Eric looks good in a dangerous/tough guy sort of way). Four is my favorite character in the book series and I am pleased to see that Theo James more than lives up to expectations.

The film was shot in Chicago so the filmmakers had to perform some digital magic to make it look and feel like a post-war, dystopian society. Costumes and sets all look spot on. It all works. Director Neil Burger injects pace, energy and a sense of foreboding and danger to the film. As soon as Tris leaves her faction, the action kicks off. There are lots of fight scenes between the initiates and among various characters, and yes, there is violence akin to what you would see in the "Hunger Games" series. There is also a budding romance - and while it is not as heavy a focus as it is in the books, it is equally satisfying.

As a big fan of the first 2 books ("Divergent" and "Insurgent"), I was very satisfied with the outcome. So many books out there get ripped to shreds by the time they make it to film, so I am glad to see that the screenwriters were very diligent in capturing the essence of this dystopian world and the characters that we love so much, and did not feel the need to change the story drastically. The plot follows that of the book and several key scenes are intact (albeit shorter and more compact) - whatever changes are made are relatively minor in comparison. The main characters are there, and there are more minor characters that may have been excised or will make an appearance in the next film. We hope this movie does well enough so that "Insurgent" is made, because that follow-up brings us more dimension to the story and fleshes out the role of these characters. For example, Marcus Eaton, Jeanine Matthews, Caleb, Peter and the Candor, Amity and Erudite factions, and Four's background are expanded more in the second book and new characters will be introduced.

My family and I came out of this film having a few discussions afterwards. Overall the reaction was very positive and we all enjoyed it immensely, so much so that we are all planning to see it again. I would highly recommend this movie not just to the book fans, but those who enjoy futuristic, dystopian films. Young and adult alike in my household enjoyed this film so it works for a broad range of audiences.

I read the Divergent book, and I really enjoyed the movie.  The casting is well done, and the acting is great.  The adaptation is faithful to the book.  My love of the first book made it easy to embrace this movie.

If I were watching the movie with fresh eyes, I think I would probably find the movie a little hokie, maybe even cheesy.  In the midst of the distopian future, there's some real "high school movie" influence.  If you're into it, then you should be able to role with it.  But if your girlfriend dragged you to the movie, it'll probably enduce some heavy eye-rolling.

I just went to see Divergent in theaters and I really would recommend purchasing the dvd. However, I also would recommend to read the books before watching the movie. If you do not have time to read, it would not affect much. Divergent is one of the few  movies that I have gone to see that stay true to the books. The movie is very action packed with a love story. This movie is very unique and I think that many people, young or old can receive a BEAUTIFUL message from it. This movie is very worth the purchase.
I just came back from watching this and loved it. The two leads had great chemistry and played their parts well. I can't wait for this to come out on blu ray

Films based on young adult novels are either a major hit or a complete miss.  Each time one of these adaptations is released, the immediate reaction is to compare it to the successful (monetarily speaking, at least) novel-to-film endeavors, such as The Hunger Games, Twilight, or Harry Potter.  But, with so many sub-par box office returns within the last few years from films like Beautiful Creatures, Vampire Academy, and The Host  - these youthful adventures are starting to earn a bad rap.  Why do some succeed while others miserably fail?  In all honesty, it comes down to the feature films presentation and the plausibility of the story  plus it doesnt hurt to have a recognizable face starring in the film.  And, as all of this pertains to Divergent  it would appear (for the moment) the prospects are bright for the future of this potential franchise.

Based on the novel by Veronica Roth and directed by Neil Burger (Limitless, The Illusionist), Divergent stars Shailene Woodley as Beatrice Prior, the daughter of two prominent members of the Abnegation faction.  In a post-war, desolate world that has been fenced-off from the rest of the world, Beatrice has reached the age where the time has come to take an induced placement exam that is supposed to tell her whether or not she should remain in her current faction or choose one of the other four very different factions  either Amity, Candor, Dauntless or Erudite.

After taking her exam, she is shocked to discover that her test results came back as divergent  a small fraction of the population that think outside the box and are heavily feared, by leaders like Jeanine Matthews (Kate Winslet), due to their ability to ask too many questions and disrupt the system. Keeping the test results to herself, she eventually decides to switch factions  joining the thrill-seeking, fearless Dauntless.  However, new arrivals cant just join the factions  they must prove and earn their place.

Initially, Beatrice (now going by the name Tris) finds it difficult to complete with her fellow new arrivals.  She must learn how to fire weapons, complete in hand-to-hand combat, and avoid finishing in the bottom tier of her class  where she would become an outcast without a faction.  However, Tris forms a bond with one of the Dauntless instructors, called Four (Theo James), who helps keep her motivated and prepared for whatever might come her way.  And, even though it would appear that making Dauntless is her greatest obstacle, she eventually realizes there are far grander issues to consider as the other factions continue to be at odds with one another.

Much like Jennifer Lawrence in The Hunger Games films, Shailene Woodley should be praised and commended for being able to take on such an emotion-filled character and giving her such a dominant onscreen presentation.  Woodley, who is quickly rising through the ranks of young Hollywood actresses, proves that she has the ability to carry  not only a film  but also a franchise.  To call her anything other than exquisite in this role would be a monumental lie and theres little doubt that this film (critical acclaim or not) will propel her character even higher than its current trajectory.

While Woodley is the star of the film and incredibly enjoyable in her role, she is really outshined by the presence of newcomer Theo James.  To many, he will be unrecognizable as his film resume is far from lengthy  but he is currently starring in the CBS drama, Golden Boy.  In any event, James brings a secretive, brooding element to a film that would be completely different with any other actor.  His role, not unlike David Boreanaz from his days of playing Angel, is slightly more powerful than everyone else around him.  As the film progresses, so does his growing (and pleasant) chemistry with Shailene Woodley, and both of these characters find that they have far more in common than you could possibly imagine, at least based on their initial meeting.

The major antagonists of the film include Kate Winslet  whose character is almost a mirror image from the role that Jodie Foster played in the recent dystopian action flick, Elysium.  Still, its nearly impossible to find a role in Winslets career where you can make the case that she performed badly.  No, her character doesnt have a huge role in the film, but her character carries enough weight that it needed a prominent actress like Winslet to sell the part.  And, when Winslet is not around, the film has to rely on another rising Hollywood star to play the aggravating foe  Jai Courtney.  Nearly the exact opposite of James character, Courtney portrays another Dauntless instructor, Eric  who has no problem inflicting his aggression on those that defy him.

The only real major downsides to this film are that it progresses in the same manner as all the other young adult films out.  You have this protagonist that is special  almost like a chosen one type character, who refuses to conform to the rules of society.  The fact that this style of storytelling is far from original hampers it and holds it back from being anything more than your typical popcorn movie.  And, this film does progress at a rather enjoyable pace, it feels like it takes too long to get to the climax, and once you arrive to that moment, the film attempts to do too much too quickly  forcing the film to feel like it has a pacing issue.

Overall, a case can be made for Divergent as being an exciting adventure, but also a case against it as being just another young adult film adaptation with the same old defiant characters and familiar plot progression.  Where you land on that particular side of the fence will likely have to do with whether or not youve read the books and are a fan of those novels.  By no means is Divergent better than The Hunger Games or Harry Potter, but it is eerily similar to Twilight  yet the acting is far superior to Twilight and even as engaging as The Hunger Games.  Since Divergent is only the first film in a set of three popular novels, they likelihood that sequel, Insurgent, gets green-lit for a feature film will hang on the box office success of Divergent.  But, at this state, it would appear the entire trilogy has an excellent chance of telling its full story on the big screen.

GRADE:  C+

Watched this with my 10yo daughter. She enjoyed it.
I'd say it was as though the author saw The Hunger Games, The Matrix, 1984 and a few other cliche sci-fi films (or books) and decided to combine them in to one girl-power story.

It was a pleasant watch but left us both saying "yeah, I'd watch the others at some point."

The acting was decent but a bit of forced edginess peppered every scene.

Set design looked very "studio lot" in a lot of places.

Ultimately it was a basic modern "B" sci-fi movie with a tween girl tilt. Worthwhile if you're in a pinch for something to watch.

This book adaptation of a young adult, dystopian genre is actually really good.  It gets a bad reputation because of its similarities to other books of its kind, but I don't care.  It's perfectly pleasant and easy to follow, albeit the actual plot is a little confusing.  Who doesn't love a story based around a strong, empowered young woman?  I would recommend watching the sequel movie, Insurgent, which is surprisingly better than the book.  But do not go any farther.  The third book and movie, Allegiant, is absolute trash and you're better off just stopping while you're happy.

I enjoy watching this but I am not going to pretend it's an amazing movie. There are a number of differences from the book series, which make the movie seem sillier than it needed to be. For instance, the leadership and conspiracy points which are set up here and then, pardon the pun, divergent to the nth degree in the Insurgent movie, were far better explained in the writing. So many people saw this movie and thought it was nothing more than a Hunger Games ripoff, and it's easy to see why they thought that. The movie fails to set up some of the deeper character nuances and relationships and instead just jumps into a sometimes boring story about a teenage girl getting to be completely awesome just because she's "pretty" and likes a man who likes her back and gives her support. It's still entertaining to me but it's definitely not of high caliber.

First of all, I love this book and the entire series. Go read it if you have not. Like seriously. Right now.

Now for the Q&A session about the movie.

Question 1. Does this book follow the plot of the book?
Answer: Great question. I hate it when movies do not follow the book. *cough* Scorch Trials. But the movies was decent, the first one was great, and loved the books. Anyways. This movie does follow the book very well, and basically everything is included and fits what happens in the book.

Q2. Is the acting good?
A2. Yes, Shailene Woodley, Theo James, and more do an excellent job in portraying their characters actions, emotions, etc. I also liked how the characters sort of looked like how I pictured them in my head for the most part and that they looked basically how they were described for the most part.

Q3. What ages should see this movie?
A3. Concepts might be hard to understand for younger audiences, might be some language but I do not remember there being any, see one character's back when he shows his tattoos but there is nothing that would prevent anyone from seeing it besides intense scenes and hard to understand content/violence (like the serums, mind control stuff, the factions, the fighting, etc) So PG-13 is a good rating for it, but it's not on the higher end of that scale.

Price: Amazing price. I got this for $4. I do not know how long that price is staying but I am glad I saw this item when I did. SO obviously a great price.

I also found the main character very easy to relate to because she is always trying to improve herself. I probably rank this in my top five favorite movies of all time, along with Fight Club, The Matrix, Home Alone, and Crank.

I'm according the movie four stars because it's pretty inarguably moderately entertaining, and because Shallene Woodley is both talented and perfectly cast as Tris.  That said, I feel about Dauntless the way I did about Slytherin in the Potter novels.  Why have a House (or a faction) reserved to the savage, deranged and those most frequently possessed of psychopathically sadistic proclivities?  From *whom* are they supposed to be protecting the citizens?  The most riotously violent people to be found in the population are mostly the members of Dauntless (which is *such* a good quality, because the urge to take insane, violent, suicidal risks and to treat each other homicidally is obviously what you want in members of your law enforcement faction. NOT.) -- so apparently Dauntless exists just to protect society from Dauntless. So the movie's well-acted, the plot's interestingly convoluted, and the presence of a protagonist driven to jump off rooves and glory in rambunctious, simian behavior makes me wholly unable to sympathize.  If she had defected to *any* other faction, I could well have understood, but Dauntless? My immediate reaction was, "she's deranged and I don't want anything further to do with the character."

Enjoying this particular movie depends on how much the viewer has in common with either of the two main characters- the more, the better (age, gender, body type, etc...). This production is built specifically for teenagers, and I say that as a fan of the Hunger Games. Here's the difference: the plot in The Hunger Games centers on correcting injustice far and succeeding in the face of loss and change. This movie, however, is more about about finding a place to fit in, how parents just don't understand, and how the young people are the only ones who really "get it." The teens (and maybe twenty-somethings) should love this movie, but beyond them, there's a bit of a disconnect. Sadly, this production got boring along the way, and I hope the next installments are better.

All in all this is definitely a movie to see.

I can't say how disappointed I am in this movie.  I always make a point of reading the books first and I'm glad I did with this because the movie has none of the fierceness, strength, danger, raw emotion, adventure, and complexity that the book did.  As an adult, I loved the book.  It had strong female characters, a complex plot, and some of the characters were even frightening in the book.  The movie is just the opposite and seems silly and unreal.  Although the basic premise, a society divided by factions and Divergent being one that can't be controlled and the names of the characters/factions are the same, the similarities end there.  So much was changed that the story isn't even the same and what replaces it is a weaker, disjointed tale with little substance to keep the viewer interested and entertained.  Key characteristics of characters were even changed.  I would still highly recommend reading the book but skip this movie altogether.  It will frustrate you to no end.  They ruined what could have been a really awesome movie.  I suppose it's because they wanted to keep that PG-13 rating for teenagers but honestly, there were creative ways around that.  This was a failure in all aspects.  I expect if I hadn't read the books first, this movie would have put me off to it.  Even the main character was made to seem much weaker overall than she does in the book.  One of the worst book adaptations I've seen.

Four INTRODUCTORY Stars. "Divergent", based on the novel by Veronica Roth, is a post-apocalyptic movie along the lines of "Hunger Games" but very confined in location, themes, and conflict. After a terrible world war, only some in the world survived. Hundreds of years later, survivors are living and thriving inside Chicago, surrounded by a wall, and split into 5 functional, allegedly harmonious factions, except for the factionless. But there is an internal power struggle and there are secret 'divergents' who don't fit any faction and could be a threat. Beatrice "Tris" Prior emerges as a focal point and leader. Early on, it seems more time than necessary is spent on "Dauntless" and their rituals and less on other factions, but it helps the overall conspiracy and storyline since we are following Tris' development. Directed by Neil Burger. Starring Shailene Woodley, Theo James, Ashley Judd, Jai Courtney, Ray Stevenson, Zo Kravitz, Miles Teller, Tony Goldwyn, Ansel Elgort, Maggie Q, Mekhi Phifer, and Kate Winslet.  Well acted, well plotted in a unique universe and Very Definitely Recommended. Four DAUNTLESS stars (Summit Entertainment and Red Wagon Entertainment. PG-13. HD Color. CC. X-Ray. 2:19:40. Note: This movie ends on a minor cliff-hanger leading to the next installment, "Insurgent", which I was intrigued enough to buy. Two more movies are planned after that.)

Divergent is a dystopian science fiction that finds itself suffering from the stereotype Hollywood has created for recent book adaptations. It is a very formulaic and predictable storyline that is immersed in an intricately-built world. However the acting is insanely good, particularly Shailene Woodley, who makes everything feel much more real. The only issue was the repetitive theme of 'Chosen One' fights against oppressive government force. In the end Divergent is a watchable film if you enjoy dystopian science fiction.

This movie, although fairly enjoyable, was only a pretty good adaptation from the book, and for those who have not read the book, this film may be confusing. If you have read the book, I would give this movie four stars, and if you have not, then I would give it three, or maybe even two. These two alternate reviews are as follows.

If you have read the book:
In this case, I would give this movie a four star review. I would give it five, if it were not for the facts that the adaptation from the book to the film, and even though the  book did give the main story, it was still slightly confusing, even after reading the book. That being said, this was a pretty good movie, and it was entertaining to me. I thought that most of the people were cast pretty darn well, except for Tris, who should have been cast much different. I also thought that it was interesting how Tris and the person who played Caleb both co-starred in The Fault in our Stars. Just thought that it was a strange coincidence. Overall, I thought that if you have read the book, this is a good movie, and you will enjoy it. But it is a whole different story if you have not read it.

If you have not read the book:
If you have not read the book on which this movie was based, I recommend that you do not watch it. It may be entertaining just because it is movie, something to look at, but it will be confusing, you won't know any of the backstory and who anybody is, and what is going on will seem strange and will not make sense to you. I guess that I am not saying do not watch this movie,  I am just saying that it will be confusing and you may not be able to follow it very well.

Sweet but confused little teenage amish alien female accidentally buys herself a lifetime career in the military, even though she really just wanted to be cool and jump on and off of moving trains. She gets a tattoo, and the hots for some guy named Four. She then plays paintball, before going zip-lining. She drops some form of futuristic injectable LSD, and has a bad trip involving Crows. Later she begins to realize that she has superpowers. She grows a pair and marches into the nerd school to visit her jerk brother. Some big bully tries to throw her off a cliff, but her boyfriend sweeps in and saves the day. The insecure bully who tries to kill her decides to commit suicide. Her schoolmates all turn into zombie-millitary-pawns, and she chimes in on the party and murders one of her friends. Her mother comes running up wearing a burlap sack and carrying a gun, and they enjoy some quality mother/daughter time shooting her classmates. After her mother gets shot and killed, she has an epic crying tantrum before picking weapons off the dead and running away. Then she preaches to her friends that the best course of action to stop the war, is to shoot as many people as they can. She and her boyfriend decide have a major fist-fight with a few WWF moves, to express how much they care about each other. The movie ends the same way it opened, with her narrating about her fascination with jumping off of trains.

People are put into categories based off their predisposition for violence, intelligence, compassion, etc. There are those people who don't exactly fit into this model and instead are able to display all of the traits. These people are called divergent because they don't fit the societies model.

Overall, the movie was okay. The acting was a "eh" for me, but the story was intriguing. There were a lot of unanswered questions (I guess the book covered it better) about why they were living like this and WHO was outside of the walls, but outside of that, not a bad way to spend an afternoon.

The movie arrived quickly, wrapped with adequate stuffing as to not break the case, and unopened. The movie itself it awesome - some parts are different from the book, but overall the adaptation was pretty great. I'm a fan!

I did not hate it- I loved it- I give these negative reviews to get readers- a great story and love the (fairly oft trotted out idea that we must march to our own drummer)- problem is- what is that drummer? That's where the writers of these tales fall short- they have no solutions. It's easy to portray the rise of fascism- Hunger Games does it also- but, from my point of view as a leftist Christian- these stories end up praising weaponry (like bows and arrows) and praising the military faction- Dauntless. Even Trtiss mother was originally in Dauntless. Dauntless seems like a bunch of subhuman world federation wrestlers. Navy Seals or ISIL.
We fought for, and continue to, the ideals of non violence in the 60's- do these authors never go beyond the agenda of- two lovers, humanity, caring, love for humanity? They never get specific, so fritter away what could be great stories or movies- create same old cliches.

This isn't a bad movie, though the influence of 'The Hunger Games' is very obvious. The action is good, the acting is acceptable and although it is set in the future it isn't overwhelmed with computer graphics. The main drawback I found with it (apart from being half an hour too long) is that nothing much is done with the central idea of the heroine being divergent. It doesn't stop her from joining a faction, it doesn't appear to help her with her chosen career and although there are dire warnings throughout the film that she must not tell anyone there is no plotline dealing with her disclosure or unmasking. In fact, the only reason for calling it 'Divergent' at all seems to be a single line near the end of the movie.

In watching it I was reminded of the late great sci-fi writer Isaac Asimov, who wrote a story back in 1957 called 'Profession'. In that story, the failure of the system to assign the hero to a suitable profession is made the centerpiece of the plot, with a twist which seems obvious once it is revealed, but is hard to anticipate and leaves your mind buzzing. This movie needed a writer with Asimov's capacity for lateral thinking.

This is a good, not great, teen action movie, but you won't find yourself intrigued by the possibilities it raises.

Divergent is a movie about a futuristic rundown Chicago where everyone's divided into five factions based on their virtues.  Shailene Woodley stars in this movie, and it would seem she's an outcast and doesn't belong to any faction but has tremendous skills and knows how to defend herself, which places her in a top category of elite fighters.  The idea is that you must eventually commit to one of the five virtues, and those five virtues are the following- Candor (honesty), Abnegation (selflessness), Dauntless (the bravery), Amity (peacefulness) and Erudite (intelligence).  The movie does a pretty good job bringing out each one in Shailene.

This movie clearly takes several notes from the Matrix based on the special effects, which is sort of an aggravating approach in my book because the film often settles for an exaggerated storyline and appearance which often interferes with the plot.  Anyway Shailene isn't travelling on this dangerous adventure alone- she brings along Theo James (who of course cares deeply about Shailene- what else is new), the guy who doesn't contribute much (Ansel Elgort) and the tattle tail rat (Miles Teller).  I personally wouldn't save Miles at all because he's the one responsible for forcing Shailene and others on the run from the gunmen early on, which basically starts all the chaos.  Later on when the group is stuck in a tricky situation and Miles is forced to join up with them... nah sorry- no forgiveness on my end!  I'd have shot the guy the moment I was free.

Also Kate Winslet is in charge of organizing the faction by placing people through intense tests to see how they handle it, and later makes Shailene face five tests.  Each one is basically a test to see how powerful and courageous Shailene is.  The Matrix comparisons are REALLY strong here but admittedly makes for enjoyable storytelling (especially watching Shailene swing from ropes around buildings being lifted off the ground and watching the ground crumble below- heh, I couldn't help but notice flying over such a rundown miserable looking city was the only way to make it look pretty!

The movie has a way of being most entertaining in the beginning when Shailene and company hang around villages out in the country, and it picks up the pace even more when gunmen storm into the place and look for Shailene prompting her and her friends to run away and board a train (with MORE troubles!)  This, along with the way Shailene goes through with thodse dangerous tests near the end, are the two high points of the movie.  Unfortunately Divergent tends to drag on occasion.  After the train ride the pace slows down drastically and forces some confusing storytelling into our brains.  However I think Hunger Games fans would enjoy this movie.  Also Maggie Q plays a part, but isn't shown enough to make an impact.  Her importance wasn't clear to me.

I don't know, Divergent has its moments, but the storyline often ventures down confusing paths (hey what else is new when it comes to science fiction, the most confusing genre of movies there is!) and lacks a consistently high-octane pace and prefers settling into slow-moving grooves from time to time as a means to further the progression of the characters, but this isn't exactly executed with ease or excitement.  You have excitement for a little while, then you have slow parts that require close attention on the viewers part to grasp it all.  Back and forth between the two the whole time.  Actually Kate Winslet is probably the best character in the movie based on how determined she is to squeeze out the best in Shailene, and how she's willing to kill without any care in order to go through with it.  Still, decent enough for science fiction lovers I suppose.

Divergent Movie
By: Alaina Arens

So today I am here writing to you about the movie Divergent, but first I wanted to ask you what your favorite type of movie genre is. If you said dystopia, you're in luck because Divergent would be exactly what you're looking for!

Divergent is a movie about a town and people who are put into what are called factions and are labeled by what their strengths are and what defines them, the 5 factions are: abnegation, erudite, dauntless, amity, and candor. The main character, Tris is one of the Divergent people and there is only one person who can be fully divergent and Tris is 100% divergent.

Tris has a brother a mom and a dad and also a boyfriend later in time, named Four he is also one of the main characters in the movie. Both Tris parents get killed by abnegation people because they were trying to find Tris because shes the Divergent person and she was hiding so her parents basically had to risk her life for her.

Getting to the point though, there is a lady who controls everyone and everything and she is the one still looking for Tris and Four because Four is also half Divergent. So Tris and Four have to go through a lot of things and risk their lives almost to find the lady to wants Tris, they end up finding her but the rest is a mystery! Youll have to see for yourself.

In conclusion, I highly recommend this movie if you absolutely love dystopia movies because I know I do! This movie plays out like a lot of movies in its category. The lead character in a different world from our own is forced to make decisions about her future at a young age and finds that her choices lead her to unexpected truths about the world. Add in the love interest, the friends, the tension and the strong plot and it is a great product. I absolutely fell in love with the book and enjoyed the movie as well. The acting is great and I just love the premise of being forced to choose a trait that I am supposed to belong in. After watching the movie, my friends and I had long conversations about what factions we would belong in and found that each of us seemed to find a fit with our personality traits. It is an amazing movie that is totally worth watching.

Originally saw this movie on opening night in the theaters, and haven't watched it since, until now. I still love it so much. Often it is criticized for being "too much like The Hunger Games," but that's just not true. Although they both involve a dystopian plot, that does not make them the same. Differences include: basic plot, factions (based on a person's "inner self" and beliefs) vs districts (based on a person's birth and job), the overall objective of the main characters, etc.

It appeals to exactly the audience the studio had hoped. That would be young people and their youthful parents. It is an action film based in possible reality if only our lives were governed by a different set of leadership values. In this instance, young people have to test to learn which walk of life they have to pursue when they come of age. This story is basically about what happens when you are not a fit for anything. It does have thrills and action for the guys, but is a little too long and full of dialogue for me. As a movie fan, I learned that a lengthy movie can cause the audience to lose attention and this is exactly what happened to me as I watched the movie in theaters. To the producer's credit, all book-to-film movies are long and winded and most people will take a compelling story with well directed scenes over length any day. I was tossing back and forth from 4 star to 5 on this one, but after watching it on Amazon versus seeing it in theaters, I quickly brought it to the 5th star. As many others have said, if you've seen the Hunger Games or any other YA dystopia sci-fi made in the last decade, this will be basically more of the same.
The story was presented too simply, with the only questions it leaves being due to its inability to properly set up its world, but acts like there's something deeper. The characters are hardly fleshed out, being sort of generic character types for most of the movie, until the screenwriters realized there needed to be character development and suddenly thrust tons of development into one or two scenes. The character relationships are not believable or even attempted to be. They're just suddenly in love one scene. The story attempts plot twists, but for anyone paying attention to any movie in the past decade will be able to figure all of it out before the movie wants you to. The villain comes out of nowhere, given two short scenes before she becomes the big bad, and has no development to lead to a believable villain. The final confrontation with the villain comes out of nowhere, suddenly the love interest tells main character of this thing happening, then they're all being mind controlled by a macguffin that comes out of nowhere, then they have to get guns and save the day.
There was nothing great in the movie, nothing wholly original or fantastic. There's one scene where Shailene Woodley acts, after seeing someone she cares about die. It was the one scene in the movie that anyone felt like they were acting, but she was really good in it, and made me realize that she is actually an actress and not just a cute young face. The fact that Loscil had some music in the movie was pretty great, too, since that dude is great and needs to be represented more.
There was also nothing offensive in the movie. Nothing in it was so bad I felt insulted, or so bad that I felt the story was trying to rip off better YA stories.
I wouldn't recommend it, but I wouldn't tell people to avoid it. If I had paid any money for this (got it free with the Amazon Thanksgiving thing) I might care a bit more, but for now, Divergent is just kind of... there.

Veronica Roth's modern-day classic comes to life on the big screen as this rich and full two-and-a-half-hour epic starring Shailene Woodley and Theo James unfolds. I loved Woodley's portrayal as Beatrice "Tris" Prior and James' portrayal as her love interest, "Four." For reasons that become clear later in the film, "Four," is a just a nickname, but for Tris, it becomes something that saves her very life at a crucial point later on in the film. For those who have read the books, this film is a very faithful adaptation that you will be happy with. For those who haven't, watching the film will make you want to read the book even more!

Even if I were a kid, I think I probably would have thought this movie was a joke. As an adult, it's downright awful. I tried watching it on the recommendation of a friend who thought I'd love it because I enjoy films that depict post-apocalyptic scenarios. I really wish I would have read through some of the critical reviews before taking her recommendation at face value! For starters, the whole faction thing is completely unrealistic to the point that it can't be taken seriously. The cheese factor and immature emotional overtones are out of control. I stopped watching after what's-her-face chose to join the Dauntless faction and they all bust out of the Choosing Ceremony jumping and smiling and running down the street like a scene straight out of West Side Story. If you're not a pre-pubescent girl, you might ought to think twice about wasting $6 and 2 hours on this.

It's worth noting that I thought The Hunger Games was quite good even though it was written for a younger audience, so I'm not judging on that basis alone.

Wonderfully exciting, thrilling ride to the very end!  The casting is spot on - the story is almost identical to the book;  I can't imagine anyone who read the book being disappointed with this movie.  I've watched it several times and it's just as stimulating as the first time!
If anything, I think the movie tweaked some scenes, brace yourself, for the better *gasp* *ohmahgawdnoshediint*

For example, the breathtaking zip line scene and the scene where Christina gets punished.

The casting was great, the movie was spectacular. All in all, I was more than pleased and would recommend this movie to anyone who read the book or anyone who didn't read the books but wants an action packed, thrilling movie with a little bit of romance thrown into the mix!

** To see my FULL review visit:  http://kayreadsblog.wordpress.com  **
I like it and it is exactly what I ordered. As expected. Nothing extraordinary, nothing more, nothing less.

It's not really a good movie and it's not anywhere near the book.  It's just sort of meh.
They decided to "save" some time and assume that everyone who was even considering to watch this had already read the book, gotten Veronica Roth mania and right away bought the dvd for the movie.  I feel like without reading the book first anyone who tries to watch this movie will be completely lost as far as figuring out what's going on.  Therefore this movie fails to tell a story anywhere near the quality of the book.  Or any story at all.  The book has a very grounded feel to it, and that is thanks to it being told from Tris's pov.  It relies on that point of view so much, that without knowing Tris's thoughts about everything and how she sees things, it just falls apart.  And all of the important plot points that help to shape Tris's journey, are turned into a handful of random unimportant events that contribute nothing to the story.  Tris's friends aren't really all that important either, Tris needed her friends to help her get through becoming Dauntless, but here she feels like she's already become brave and she's already who she needs to be.  She doesn't need anyone else.  The zip lining scene is still awesome!!!  It's by far the best part of the movie.  Tris and Four's relationship doesn't have any character to it, everything that made it happen was removed, here they don't seem to have any chemistry, much less be able to fall in love.  And the worst thing of all, my favorite part of the book, the scene where in the dorm Edward gets stabbed in the eye, is not in the movie.  I was disappointed about that.  It's very jumbled and not very coherent.  This story does not translate well to film.

This is a trilogy by Veronica Roth. It is not in the same vein as the Hunger Games trilogy but remains quite close. It is a science fiction film that is set in a futuristic community after wars have destroyed most of the world population. In this film, societies are divided into five separate factions, representing different virtues. At 18, children have to decide their particular faction based on a test that highlights their inclinations and they have to choose a faction for the remainder of their lives. The protagonist, Beatrice (Tris) Prior has to make a her choice that surprises everyone. This is a good thriller, not as good as Hunger Games,set in a place where people have to pick factions before blood.  Tris is warned that she is a divergent, meaning that she does not fit into any slot. Along with Four, a character from the Dauntless faction, she has to unearth a conspiracy by Jeanine (Kate Winslet) to eliminate all divergents. Tris has to understand what makes divergents so dangerous. The character development has been handled well by Director Neil Burger. Good performances by Shailene Woodley as Tris and Kate Winslet.

I enjoyed this movie. It had an interesting premise and the acting was good in the film. We all know that people have different personalities and the logic to sort people out into groups after a catastrophic war shows what extremes society may consider to prevent another war. I wondered where the group of people prone to violence and total disrespect of any control were. The divergents were part of that personality but they still exhibited humanity in their personalities.

Ultimately the plot exposed that like most governmental controlled concepts it really is manipulated to have some group have all of the power. Greed and control always are part of the human mentality of some people.

I liked the premise and the action. I didn't go for five stars for two reasons, one plot driven and one probably petty.
One: the movie seemed to take a long time building up to the action. It was clearly going to be a series because so much time was spent on how society was set up and how the characters ended up in the guilds they did. There were moments when I was sitting forward in the seat urging the characters to get busy and do something.
Two: come on; it's an action movie. How many girls in life-and-death struggles can run a hand through their hair and have it fall into perfection? And keep flipping that hair into perfection? She has functional hair until the hero shows up and then all of a sudden it's flowing and every hair in place. And I guess the makeup must be hardcore waterproof because it seems like most girls would be either a) smart enough not to wear makeup to a battle or b) sweating it off in rivulets while they jump from trains and climb tall buildings.
But if you're not petty like me, or can look past petty, the movie was fun to watch. Not sure I'd watch it a second time, but it wasn't a waste of time.

While browsing movies on Amazon, I found this four-star rated sci-fi film and dove in.  While the premise was nothing original - people being assigned to a certain class (or faction) based on their naturally-occurring characteristics and talents - the movie kept my attention for the first 20-minutes or so.  However, as characters failed to develop, different factions demonstrated over-the-top stereotypical behavior, and young love blossomed, I started to think to myself, "Is this a teen movie?"  After the conclusion of the film I googled "Divergent" and learned that, sure enough, it is.

I can't fault the film for being oriented towards teens.  However, when compared to the other recent big Sci-Fi teen film - The Hunger Games - Divergent doesn't compare.  Hunger Games takes the concept of pre-determined destiny in an original direction with the Districts, while Divergent seems like something out of an old Twilight Zone.  As an adult, the originality of the The Hunger Games, the uniqueness of the universe, and the quality of the acting has intrigued me enough to return to the movies several times; once is enough for Divergent.

Though I have never watched any of the Twilight films, I suspect that Divergent is closer to these than The Hunger Games.  In summary, I imagine the movie appeals to many teens, but if you are an adult looking for something to keep your attention for 2 hours, you'll want to look elsewhere.

I myself, haven't read the book and see that some say it's true to the story, some say not, for me, it's
quite simply an enjoyable, and am looking forward to - 'Insurgent'
Some time in the future many years after war had destroyed much of mankind, in the city once known as
'Chicago' now 'Dystopia' society are divided into five factions, which is determined by an aptitude test.
Tris Prior' disappoints her parents when after the test she chooses to join the 'Dauntless' a group sworn
to help and protect the factions living within the fencing that surrounds the city.
Tris' must complete a series of gruelling and intense tests and trials to be accepted within the order, failure
is not an option, being in the bottom four in their section will see failures no longer able to return home, left
with no hope no home and no real place in society.
After a series of tests 'Tris' remains in the bottom four in her group and on the verge of being dropped from
the program.
One of the key members of the 'Dauntless' 'Four' befriends 'Tris' breaking ranks to help and encourage her
make it through the final trials.
Though she does face one more trial, she has to face her fears.
'Jeanine' a faction leader appears to be a friend when asking for 'Tris's' support, it becomes apparent during
their conversation 'Jeanine's' intention is to rid the city of 'Divergents'
'Tris' has never told anyone the outcome of her earlier aptitude test when she'd been told that she was a
'Divergent' which actually makes her an enemy of the faction leader - the Divergents are different and seen
as dangerous.
What control has Jeanine over the army of 'Dauntless' are there enemies within the faction.
'Tris' and 'Four' will have to unite to survive however they cannot do it alone, a price will be have to be paid
during the battle.
Tris played by - Shailene Woodley. Four played by Theo James. Jeanine played by Kate Winslet
This is an action-packed adventure that'll hold your attention leaving you wanting more.

We love movies in my household, especially Sci-fi. We have been waiting for Divergent to come out so we could watch it.  I can say, that it doesn't let you down.  It is a combination of action and sci-fi rolled in one.  It has a very creative story line on a socialist society and shows how there will always be a group that will not conform, can not conform and will not conform.  Shows how we all must choose our own path, but we are responsible for these choices. I liked how it showed that based on these choices you left your previous life behind, no belongings, and no contact with anyone from you past. Many of us sometimes wish this could happen in our own lives.  If you love scifi and a great original story try this one. Can't wait for the sequel!

I like the idea of this story and the theme in general - it's very trendy for a reason. The plucky young girl/boy in a dystopian future finding an unconventional way to break the mold and save the community from the "big bad" while discovering adventure and true love along the way. However, Divergent the movie just didn't live up to other offerings in the genre. It was very colorless in both literal color and dialogue. Some of the acting was stiff even from the experienced supporting cast. The pacing was unnecessarily slow and drawn out - the entire movie was about 45 minutes too long. Watching at home on streaming we made a snack and let the dogs in & out without pausing the movie and were able to step back in without missing a single key plot element. Hunger Games and others are lively, action filled, and colorful with excellent acting throughout - Divergent just doesn't live up to the standard.

I had to wait so long to see this movie but I finally saw it. I watched this a few weeks after I finished the first book which I thought was awesome. I thought this movie, for the most part, was an excellent adaption of the book and the movie itself I thought was very good. The acting was good to great and I especially liked Woodley's performance as Tris and Winslet's performance as Jeanine Matthews. My only complaints are that they didn't include the scene where Peter stabs Edward in the eye which was in the book and that Al's character didn't get as much attention. In the book there was much more focus on Al's character and the build-up to his suicide which they did include in the movie. And Jeanine getting attacked and knocked out by Tris didn't happen at all in the book and that's what happened near the end of the movie. I know it seems like I'm criticizing it a lot but those are really just minor complaints. Other than that I thought the movie was great and I totally do not agree with all the Critics' review on this. Yes Divergent has a few similarities but they are really two completely different stories and personally I think I enjoyed divergent more than Hunger Games. 5 stars.

Divergent is a somber, slow-paced post-apocalyptic teen adventure with an absolutely ridiculous premise.  In this world, all people are divided into five "factions" based on specific personality traits:  Abnegation (for the selfless), Candor (for the truthful), Amity (for the compassionate), Dauntless (for the brave), and Erudite (for the intelligent).  The suggestion is that by dividing its populace into these five separate groups, and by drilling into them the mantra "Faction Over Blood," the government can control everyone.  Anyone who can't cut it in their chosen faction is tossed out into the street to live as "factionless," basically meaning homeless vagabonds who huddle around burning barrels in dirty clothes.  And those rare individuals who fit into more than one of the five factions (imagine that, someone who might actually be intelligent, brave, and compassionate all at the same time!) is labeled "Divergent," and becomes an enemy of the state, since they can't be controlled.  Ha!

The story is told from the perspective of sixteen-year-old Tris, who was born into Abnegation and now must choose whether to stay with her parents' faction or choose one of the others.  Psychological tests are administered to the teens before the "Choosing Ceremony" to help them make a wise choice, but Tris's tests are inconclusive - she's Divergent, a label she's advised to keep secret lest she be targeted for extermination.  So she wavers between following her parents' lead (and spending her life selflessly helping others and never looking in the mirror), or joining the Dauntless faction (where she can jump out of speeding trains, climb to the top of humongous scaffolds, and practice hand-to-hand combat in the Pit).  It's no big surprise which one Tris chooses.

But why is she given a choice at all?  If this society is so set on keeping its citizens locked up in separate factions, surely the tests would reveal which faction is right for each person.  Why give them a choice?  Because just about any sixteen-year-old kid is going to choose something fun (like Dauntless) rather than something rooted in self-denial (i.e. Abnegation)!  It makes no sense.  In The Giver (which also divides its people into groups - but groups based on aptitude), there is no choice.  In Brave New World (which also has five factions, although they aren't called that), the people are genetically bred to fit into designated castes.  In the case of Divergent, the groups seem random and purposeless, especially since the kids can pick whichever one they want regardless of the results of their psychological tests.  And what ultimately happens reveals how random and purposeless it all is.

Since all of the leaders of this society come from the Abnegation faction (since they are supposedly selfless, and thus won't ever be greedy or power-hungry), it's not surprising that the other factions might start questioning whether this is quite fair.  And it's also no surprise that it's Erudite that challenges things first - after all, they're the intelligent ones, right?  They'd be the first to wonder why a bunch of selfless sheep are running things when there are smart people out there who can do it better.  And they can do it better with an army of brave Dauntless behind them, an army they've figured out how to control (since the Erudite are the only ones in this society with any brains!).

Which leaves Tris in a sticky situation.  She's a member of Dauntless, but she's really Divergent.  That means she can't be controlled in the same way the rest of the Dauntless are.  And it also means she can see what's coming, because she's got a little bit of Erudite in her.  And she feels bad for her parents (because she's got a little bit of Amity, too).  And she wants to help people (she was born in Abnegation, after all!).  It's just lucky she's not a full-fledged Candor, or she'd be blabbing all of this to everyone she sees!

Ultimately, the movie is about Tris's efforts to make it in Dauntless (think Ender's Game), her discovery of an insidious plot that needs to be resisted (think Hunger Games), and her growing love for eighteen-year-old Four, another secret Divergent who's hiding out in Dauntless (think any teen romance between star-crossed lovers).  Had the premise made any kind of sense, this might have been a watchable, if somewhat slow, science fiction adventure.  But it doesn't.  It's impossible to be any one of the five factions in this film without also possessing elements of the other four - that's just what being human means.  Some of us are more intelligent than others, braver than others, or more compassionate and selfless - but what good is a selfless leader without the ability to reason?  And what good is a brave soldier without compassion, intelligence, and a willingness to help others?  You can't "protect and serve" if you couldn't care less about those you're protecting and serving!  No, the premise is flawed.  And what remains is a rather tame YA sci-fi story that never quite rises to the level of a really good film.

Hello, I'm the Ranting Usher.  Let me talk you to your seat.
  In this sci-fi action film that is the first installment in a series based on the novel by Veronica Roth, society is divided into five factions which it's citizens must choose to conform to.
  The main character, Tris Pryor, carries a deep secret that, if exposed, could get her killed.  The more she struggles to keep her secret, the more she is physically and emotionally challenged within her chosen faction.  What I like most about Divergent is that, despite borrowing tropes from other classics, it delivers a riveting tale of survival.  It maintains themes of self-actualization and control while creating engaging character development, and builds tension and suspense that will keep you watching from beginning to end.  It's hard to take your eyes off this film.
  For more about Divergent, Google the Ranting Usher.

I was asked to review "Divergent" and watched it half-heartedly, having been told it "is a lame ripoff of 'Hunger Games'."  I learned a valuable lesson - make up your own mind - because "Divergent" won me over in the first ten minutes.  I can't wait to read the novel!

"Divergent" may have been targeted to the Young Adult genre, but ANYONE of ANY age, can appreciate its messages of morality, dangers of pigeon-holing of personalities, appreciating those who are different, the pain of moral choices, and its rich fantasy world in futuristic Chicago.  It's a fabulous coming-of-age story, as Tris learns who she is, develops her moral code and makes often painful moral choices.  There are SO many levels to this movie!  Any sci-fi, fantasy, and post-apocalyptic story fan can appreciate "Divergent."

Shailene Woodley is a fabulous actress who gives depth to her young character.  Her romance with darkly-handsome and mysterious Four is believable and I can't wait to see both characters continue to develop. It's wonderful to see a movie give an age-accurate portrayal of teens and teen romance; so many screenwriters (who are of course adults) make kids act either too old or too young for their actual depicted ages.  Zoe Kravitz proves herself as talented as her famous rockstar dad, and I look forward to seeing more work from Jai Courtney and Miles Teller, too.

The special effects are awesome. I've never been a fan of CG effects, which make many movies look more like a cartoon or an XBox game than a live-action movie.  "Divergent" takes state of the art to its fullest, and futuristic Chicago looks real and gritty.

I thoroughly enjoyed "Divergent" and can't say enough good things about its actors, storyline and technical achievement.  I will be purchasing and reading the novels, and eagerly await the next installment in this trilogy.

If you like the Hunger Games, Maze Runner or Harry Potter, you'll like Divergent. For me and my wife it's just OK but for our 20 year old daughter it was great.

Divergent, based on a trilogy of books by Veronica Roth and follows an all too familiar tween movie formula ... young, innocent, compassionate, female teen who doesn't quite fit into society's and is faced with an event (in Divergent's case "The Test") after which the teen must quickly grow up, discover themselves and their special skills, lose their innocence and ultimately become a strong willed heroine who saves the day.

Of course along the way our heroine is tormented by others around her for being weak as she constantly struggles with herself to do the right thing. Then there's the inevitable romance which starts out with uncertainty, then transitions into awkwardness (does he like me?) and eventually turns into a mutual attraction between a sexy girl and hunky guy ... who knew that would happen?

Yes Divergent is a formula movie ... the story is old and the plot is predictable but that doesn't make it bad.

Divergent probably won't win any Oscars, but the story is entertaining and the acting and cinematography are good.

Overall Divergent is worth watching, I'm just not sure it's worth buying. I'd recommend renting this one.

Divergent (2014) is a thrilling, dystopian, action movie based on a book of the same title by author Veronica Roth. The book series is simply called Divergent as well, and consists of three main books, Divergent, Insurgent, and Allegiant; plus an additional few short stories.

  So, in the movie Divergent (2014), we meet Beatrice Prior (Shailene Woodley), a teenage girl who lives amidst a precarious faction system within the walls of a great city safely cut off from the ruins of what once was America. The factions are Erudite, the knowledgeable ones; Amity, the peaceful crop-tenders; Candor, the honest; Dauntless, the brave protectors; and Abnegation, the selfless. Beatrice's parents are part of Abnegation, which makes Beatrice, and her brother Caleb, part of it too. Until they get the test and choose a faction at the choosing ceremony. The test tells teens what they're most like (it helps them choose right at the choosing ceremony). ...But to some, like Beatrice, it tells something entirely different. Some dangerous. A condition punishable by death.

  This film brings us along with Beatrice as she struggles to cope with being divergent, and live in spite of it. After joining a new faction, she begins to realize that some things are very wrong with the way her city is living, and she has to decide whether to stay undercover, or take a stand.

  First off, I found Divergent (2014) to be thoroughly entertaining; interesting and captivating. The whole dystopian thing has really captured my attention of late, and that element of this movie doesn't disappoint.
  We have the strange faction system. Crumbling, abandoned ships and skyscrapers. Fascinating concoctions that stimulate the part in a person's brain that processes fear... when is injected into a person, along with little things that allow your fearful hallucinations to be seen on a computer screen. Yeah, crazy technology or something. :P But it's very interesting to think of.

  There's a strong family theme. It's easy to see that Beatrice and her brother and parents love each other. In some cases, this love is shown as certain ones put their life on the line for others. There's hugs exchanged, I love yous spoken, and sacrifices made.

  No spiritual element to speak of since Divergent (2014) isn't a Christian movie (or book). I read somewhere that Veronica Roth is a Christian, so... I don't know. *Shrugs* Some good values are still captured in this film though, such as standing up for the innocent even when it'll hurt (even kill) you, and putting friends and family above yourself as well. There's lots of shooting and deaths, especially in the latter part of the movie, but I didn't feel those parts were too glorified; and there were several scenes of characters grieving over someone's death. It's seems evident that Tris (Beatrice) is shocked, horrified, regretful over all the deaths, and the fighting she herself has to do. You can see it in her eyes and a scene where she says she's not sure she knows who she is anymore.

  That all being said, I will still note that some of the violence creeped me out. There were smaller things, such as the fighting rounds during Dauntless training, that didn't creep me out, but it wasn't too fun to watch, I'll admit. There were at least four intense fighting scenes, (girl on girl and boy on girl) in which one of the pair gets beat up pretty bad. There's punching in the face and stomach, some shoving and kicking and whatnot. The part that creeped me out really though, was when the fighting with guns/fighting against the government started in earnest... armed men are chasing a teenage girl, and loved ones start to die. I got over it after awhile, but it definitely made me stop and go, wait, this isn't a pg, fluffy romance or anything. So yeah, stop and realize this is pg-13 for intense violence before letting any younger children watch it. I would say viewers should be at least 13, preferably older (16 or so and up). If not because of the violence, then because there's definitely some mature themes that younger children and maybe even some teens can't really grasp.

  Such as intense competition between the Dauntless, which results in a suicide. And some of the stuff the Dauntless leadership try to teach their trainees, like obeying even when you don't agree with what's being done, or are even horrified at what's being done.

  Divergent (2014) was really interesting that way. It made me think of how some leaders/rulers really try to manipulate their people, as the society/dauntless leadership were trying to do in this film. "Human nature is the enemy," says one of the leaders, Jeanine Matthews... (which is true in a sense because it IS human nature to sin, to be selfish, to protect yourself even when it hurts others, to seek pleasure at any cost, and so on.) But the society's solution to human nature being the enemy, was to wipe out free will, wipe out thinking independently, wipe out emotions, wipe out the tie between family members. Faction before blood! is their quote. So yeah, its an interesting, thought-provoking theme overall.

  The romance of Divergent (2014) was touching and heartfelt at points. A little too much at other points. There's an extended kissing scene as well as a few other little moments that perhaps didn't need to be added. Also, there's a brief hallucination of a girl getting attacked. Some immodest dress and inappropriate comments also are downs of this movie.

  And there's some swearing. Some misuse of God's name. Perhaps four or five of each throughout the film.

  In conclusion, I'm not really sure what to think of Divergent (2014) yet. Like I said, it entertained me. The dystopian world fascinated me. For the most part, Tris had a sweet romance. There were no really twisted ideals being promoted that I can see as of now. But there were still teens pummeling each other, and lots of shooting. The end of Divergent (2014) leaves me really wanting to watch Insurgent (2015)...but, we'll see.

  For the most part, the dystopian world, the action, the crazy stunts, the intriguing story of Divergent (2014) really pulled me in. It's a thrilling watch in that aspect! :)

*For more information about the pros and cons of the movie Divergent, I would suggest visiting http://www.pluggedin.com/videos/2014/q3/divergent.aspx*

I am not a fan of the YA genre in general. But I decided to give this a try since I found the Hunger Games: Catching Fire surprisingly intelligent and well-done. Unfortunately, this film was disappointing. More so because the premise and the acting was good. But the screenplay and directing ruined it. There was no exploration of why Tris chose to leave Abnegation or how she felt about leaving her family forever. Did she just want to be with the "cool" kids? Who knows. In fact, Tris' motivation throughout the movie was ambiguous if non-existent. The film never gained a consistent tone. When the Dauntless crew began whooping and leaping through the streets I swear all I could think of was West Side Story. I expected song and dance at any moment. Then they turn into bullies and psychopaths, more stupid than brave. And after 100 years, you think they would repair some buildings. Seems like they needed a construction faction. The romance part was also too predictable and lacked the subtlety found in the Hunger Games. It should be a backstory, not THE story. The sheer oppression of being told exactly who or what you were going to be should have been the tone of the whole movie, yet it never even gets explored. A perfect example of how a poor screenplay and directing can ruin a film even if the premise is there and the acting is decent.

Goodness, this movie is dumb. Five factions - Amity, Dauntless, Candor, Abnegation, and Erudite (three nouns, two adjectives), and you had BETTER fit neatly into one of these. For starters, who does fit neatly into just one of these? Almost nobody, that's who - there would be boatloads of "divergents."  And what about the shopkeepers, lunch counter workers, taxi drivers - is there a group for them, or are grocery stores and such just a thing of the past? And how many of these stories about unexceptional teenage girls saving the world do we have to stomach before this brand of entertainment plays out? And just as a matter of curiosity, what possible purpose can a faction of people with "candor" serve, especially since the smart folk have a faction all their own? So, I wasn't smart enough or selfless enough for Erudite or Abnegation, but I'm honest. This is just plain goofy and not even half-way imagined.

I would like to begin my review of this book with an analogy. (Mild spoilers)

You meet this girl that you are immediately attracted to. Like instant love, movie sort of stuff. You ask her out and amazingly enough she agrees. You really want to impress her, so you get reservations at one of the finest restaurants in town. You go all out (i.e. get a tux, rent a limo, etc.). You pick her up. The date goes great. You think she may be the one, and she seems really into you. Finally, at the end of the night you walk her to her door to kiss her goodnight, at which point she pushes you away and says "I had a lot of fun, but I just want to be friends."

This movie left me as unfulfilled as this scenario. I've never read the books, but I went into the movie with a certain level of excitement. I mean the hype for it was insane. But the movie itself was just...empty. Admittedly I found the whole premise of the story absurd, but that's really the least of my issues. All of the plot elements had either already been done before (Harry Potter's hat choosing ceremony anyone?), were poorly explained (so the security force that's supposed to protect everyone acts like a bunch of monkeys?), or just made no sense at all (so he's not affected at one point, but then he's suddenly affected when the plot demands it?). The only good parts were the pseudo-Matrix scenes, and they really didn't fit with the story at all. Perhaps the story would have made more sense if I'd read the books. Maybe some things would be explained better, but I doubt it. As it stands, I have zero desire to see the next one.

On the plus side, my 15 year old daughter loved it (LOOOOOOOVED IT!!!1!!1). I guess that explains the high ratings.

I enjoyed this movie. It had an interesting premise and the acting was good in the film. We all know that people have different personalities and the logic to sort people out into groups after a catastrophic war shows what extremes society may consider to prevent another war. I wondered where the group of people prone to violence and total disrespect of any control were. The divergents were part of that personality but they still exhibited humanity in their personalities.

Ultimately the plot exposed that like most governmental controlled concepts it really is manipulated to have some group have all of the power. Greed and control always are part of the human mentality of some people.

While I liked the movie I wondered why no one left the confines of the city. What was the world like outside of the wall. It was a good story but the holes in the story bugged me. The film was obviously set up for sequels so perhaps some of the questions will be answered in the future. I obviously have not read the book and now that my interest has been peaked I will have to get it to read.

Let me start off by saying that in my experience, it is very difficult for me to like a movie based on a book that I've already read.  I have too many expectations of what the movie should be.  (Anyone remember Eragon?  Super horrible!)

The movie felt rushed and I feel it may have been difficult to understand exactly what was going on if I hadn't read the book.  But that's normal for book adaptations.

That being said, it was still a decent movie.  It is exciting seeing a book come to life, even if I don't agree with everything they did.  There was some cool scenes and I thought the acting was good.  I'd like to give it 3.5 stars.

I'd just like to comment on one specific aspect of the movie that I remember.  (It was a couple months ago that I watched it)

SPOILER ALERT:

I thought that the two scenes in which Tris' parents die were poorly done.  In both cases the book makes it clear that they died to save Tris.  If memory serves, the mother holds some guys off from Tris and is overwhelmed; and the father draws the guards away in the other direction making it safer for Tris.  Both of which create a bitter-sweet moment that added to the book.  The movie didn't convey that, at least not very well.

Maybe a small detail but I just wanted to comment on it.

This movie is very exciting!  To me it has to do with courage and bravery.  There are very good stars in the movie like Shailene Woodley, Ashley Judd, Ansel Egort, and Kate Winslet.  Tris's (Shailene Woodley) good friend Four (Theo James) is very good in it as well, and good - looking!  Overall, great movie that's definitely worth owning!  I'd recommend it, especially if you like exciting movies!

I have never read the Divergent YA novel.  I had no preconceived notions of how a character should act or look.  So everything on the screen was completely new and I did not mentally go over the plot differences from the novel.  I must state I loved this movie.

The premise is that after an apocalyptic type of war, people are grouped into five different factions.  These factions all have differing functions and personalities and once people choose a faction, there's no changing.  It's how people are categorized for life.  To be factionless, is the worst fate imaginable, you are without a home, uncared for and unwanted. Young adults choose their faction based on an aptitude test which happens through a mental dream like state.  Heroine Tris discovers she has abilities and talents in several factions making her different and Divergent.  She chooses the faction Dauntless which acts as the police/military for the city.

Dauntless is a brave group of warriors and Tris has her work cut our for her.  The training is difficult and intense.  One of her training instructors, a man named Four, becomes both mentor and love interest.  Tris is smart and curious and when she discovers that her parent's  faction is at risk (they do not belong to Dauntless), she takes great risks to save her old faction.

This whole totalitarian theme with a bit of romance and fast paced action was supremely entertaining.  The leads had fantastic chemistry but also vulnerability.  Shailene Woodley hits the right note in just about every scene.  She is spunky and brave but also there is a quiet control to her actions too. She is believable in all her emotions from feeling insecure about her ability to survive Dauntless training to her growing romantic feelings for her instructor.  Theo James who plays Four is also good. He represents both strength and fairness.  He is the perfect man for a woman who has those same traits.

This movie is the beginning of a trilogy and I look forward to the next installment.

I loved this movie.  It was way better than the book...although to be fair, I read the book after watching the movie...perhaps that made a difference.  I liked how the characters were portrayed better in the movie than in the book.  There were times in the book where I didn't understand Four's character or even like him (he really did seem a bit sadistic at times in the book).  The same could be said for Christina and Will.  I also think the script writers take on the simulations made more sense than the author's.  The movie did a great job of taking what was great about the book and making it even better.  I can't say that about many movie adaptations of books, but this was superbly done.

*Possible Spoiler Alert*
The only thing I liked about the book better was the explanation of her bird tattoo (one bird for each of the family members she left behind) and the glimpse into her mother's background (her mom was originally dauntless, but was also divergent.  She was saved because her mom...grandmother of Tris...was a dauntless leader and told her to choose a different faction for her safety.  She chose abnegation).  There were a couple of conversations/meetings that happened between Tris and Four in the book that weren't included in the movie that I did like (For example, he was the one who told her about the hamburger and to put Ketchup on it and there were a few more kisses between the two in the book), but they weren't really important to the plot and it made sense the script writers wouldn't include them.

This is an interesting story, with a good (although simple) plot, as well as good screenplay, direction, cinematography, effects, and acting.  The premise of the story is interesting:  that people choose to belong to one of five social factions; and if you don't fit into a faction, you're considered an outcast - and possibly a rebel, so to speak.  This is not far off of our present culture, where most people conform (even promote) the status quo, where most people are followers (and even seek leadership from others), and where most humans do not know who they are and cannot think for themselves.

In this story there's an interesting character, Beatrice (or Trice) who is a non-conformist.  I enjoyed her character arc, beginning as an uncertain girl, not knowing where she belonged, and ending the film as someone who because . . .  well, you decide.

This is a simple plot with few interesting nuances.  It is somewhat predictable - although I nonetheless enjoyed the unfolding of the story.  This film also took me out of my comfort zone, because I found myself uncomfortable with the pervasive 'zombie-type' behavior of the culture.

It is nonetheless an enjoyable story, and I recommend it primarily to the younger generation.
