The movie has a fascinating premise, makes the aspect of human nature a central theme to what people will be doing in the future.  It's an exciting movie with some good science fiction illustrations of computer and mind control drugs to wonder about.  I have to object to movies however that show a man fighting with a woman as if it is a fair fight.  This movie has a scene where the main female character - a slender woman, goes up against a man in a boxing ring style fist fight.  Are we really supposed to believe she had a chance?  Who wants to see that?  In the sports world of competitive boxing no one would even want to see a man her size go up against another man so much bigger!  Of course she apparently recovers from her beating in no time at all and the man who did it apparently feels no shame for engaging in such brutality.  This scene went beyond science fiction and injected a huge dose of dramatic farce.

Finally dawned on me how bad it was when a parent died and I didn't feel a thing. That is when I tapped the eject button. Unfortunately, 80% of the movie was over by then. I'm glad to see more homely girls getting a shot at carrying a movie, but even that Hunger Games chick could not have saved this. Weak, implausible story, with character development virtually non-existent. It embarrasses me to admit that I sat there watching for as long as I did. I mean, I was trying as hard as possible to like this dang movie, because I did thoroughly enjoy the first 2 Hunger Games and this one had so many similar elements that I thought, perhaps, it might at least turn into Hunger Games Lite. Alas, it wasn't even ultra-lite. I shed tears when the little girl in HG died. I had nothing but apathy for any of these characters. My only tears came from the realization that I had been suckered into watching this by the sheer numbers of 5-Star Amazon reviews. It's mind blowing. COME ON, PEOPLE!!! You canNOT sit there and tell me this movie was as good as it gets. That IS what 5 stars means, ya know? Yeah, buddy. This one here ranks right up there with the greatest films ever!!! Under no circumstances should this thing get more than 3 stars.

And, no, I did not read the book. Didn't know there was one, for that matter. I do get weary hearing from reviewers who say the movie was terrible compared to the book. Good night, if you read the book first, do NOT go to the movie, because 98% of the time, you WILL be disappointed.

I read the first book of this series and liked it alright so I thought I'd watch the movie.  I did not particularly care for it.  To begin with, Shailene Woodly, who I've liked okay in other films didn't work for me as Tris.  She seemed far too delicate to portray a person capable of being a fierce warrior, nor did her character seem to be particularly intelligent.  She was actually rather bland which is not good since she was the main character.  I don't blame her.  I assume she was following what the director told her to do. There seemed to be more concern with keeping Woodley's hair looking fabulous than giving her a realistic warrior persona.  There was virtually no development of the relationship between Tris and Four.  He went from being abrupt to favoring her in the blink of an eye for very little reason.

Secondly, the script was terrible.  The dialogue was stilted and the story jerked and skipped along in a less than coherent fashion. Had I not read the book, I am not certain I would have known what was going on.  There are some good people in the cast, they just didn't seem to have much to work with when it came to the script.  There was far too much time spent dwelling on less important parts of the story only to suddenly jump to major conflicts with little or no explanation as to why they were happening, just POOF!  Now we're fighting mean people.

I know sequels are being made.  I just hope they do a better job than was done with the first installment. This adaptation deserved better.

One of my favorite fantasy movies of late.  Strong Christian symbolism--poses strong questions about what makes a moral decision and how to balance differences in society. Speaking as a former psych therapist.. and avid Sci Fi fan/critic.. I find Divergent worthy of high regard. Many critics tore it apart, but I often view most critics as wild wolves roaming the alleyways of entertainment. The story is a good watch for adults and young people alike.. though if you are someone who does not want your child seeing violence of any kind.. please keep that in mind. Theme of the Movie... without any spoilers.... In the real world we often want to protect our kids from adult themes as long as possible. But is that possible today? And is it wise, considering how we are devolving as a species this Millennium? The positive messages of this movie outweigh ANY negatives. The message is simple - that it's good to be different and it is good to appreciate our differences.. that there are always bad people who will try to rob us of our gifts and punish us for our differences. It is okay to lead 'the good fight' and it also okay to just follow.

When I first heard about Divergent, I though the first Hunger Games rip off was upon us, and besides that the whole story seemed somewhat confusing. It is Science Fiction and Directed by Neil Berger, the mind behind Limitless, so I decided to give it a shot, and it was the best idea I had in a long time.
In a post war America, the city of Chicago is fenced off from the rest of the world, and has split into five factions of people. At the age of 18, all citizens must take an aptitude test, to determine where they belong. Beatrice (Shailene Woodley) is one of the girls taking the test as the movie starts, and her results show that she has an aptitude for all five factions, making her Divergent. Divergent's are highly intelligent, rebellious, and seen as a threat to the Government, so she hides her results and joins Dauntless, the equivalent of the National Guard in Chicago. During her rough training, the now renamed Trice, meets up with Four (Theo James) who she has an instant connection to, but who is also a threat to her secret identity. One thing that was never explained is why these people have to take the aptitude test, if they are allowed to join whichever faction they choose. It's a major plot hole and the only reason this film didn't receive 5 stars, as I really hate plot holes. Shailene Woodley stars as Trice, making the jump from TV to film, and she has done it with a bang. In much the same way Jennifer Lawrence was the perfect choice to play Katniss, Woodley was perfect for the role of Trice, and brought so much more to the film than I ever thought she would. Theo James is also terrific as Four, the mysterious trainer and love interest of Trice, and together the team is the perfect pair. Divergent is highly original, really well written, and introduced Hollywood to a whole slew of new stars, not to mention it's Director, Neil Burger, is on one hell of a successful run of films. Divergent has everything I look for in a film and in my favorite genre, and for that it is now one of our must see movies!

I did find a few times the movie strayed away from the book, but both were worth my time.

As a standalone movie, it's a good one, hence the three stars. As an adaptation of the book it fails and I'll tell you why.

First and most important annoyance: In the book, Tris is a very strong female character. Personally, I think this series gets that right better than any other YA series out there right now. Especially when you read the stories from Four's point of view you realize that he is consistently amazed at how smart and strong she is. That's lost from the movie where it comes off as him helping her all the time. My favorite scene from the book is when they go through Four's fear landscape because it shows that - Tris helps him through each step and when the landscape ends he is looking at her with awe and admiration. In the movie, it's all about him helping her prepare for her final test. He doesn't seem the least bit scared when it starts with them on the windy beam when fear of heights is one of his greatest fears.

Second annoyance: In the book, the romance is so tentative and slow. There are many small moments where he just touches her back as they're walking or they carefully move closer to each other just to see what it would be like. In the movie there are only a couple moments like that and then BOOM they're making out on his balcony. Four is just as inexperienced as she is with the other sex but the only time we see that is a flash when she touches the tattoos on his back (which, if you hadn't read the book you wouldn't even realize that's why he startled). The scene in his fear landscape for confinement in the book is so much better than in the movie both for her lack of taking the lead with helping him through it (instead of him telling her how in the movie) and the awkwardness of being so close to each other for the first time.

I'll leave the age difference out of it because Shailene Woodley and Theo James have such great chemistry.

I still look forward to the next movies where I hope they can make up for making her seem weak in this one but the romance part is already ruined for me.

So here we have yet another movie that has an evil person or group who is trying to take over the world, or whatever is left of it, and the only ones who can stop them are a couple of super attractive teenagers with impeccable hair and make up.  And yes if you are thinking that this is basically the plot of the Hunger Games with a few changes made, then you are absolutely right.

It's also like a lot of other teen movies in the fashion that this incredibly powerful evil person can only be stopped by a couple of teenagers.  Also there is their version of the "Reaping," from the Hunger Games and the "Sorting Hat" ceremony from Harry Potter.  Also just like in those other movies, being sorted or reaped doesn't matter because you can just ask to be put in a faction.  Just like Harry asked to be put into Griffindor and Katniss volunteered to be tribute for the games.

And speaking of these 5 factions, what teenager in their right mind would choose any faction other than Dauntless?  I mean if any teenager had the choice between the 5 of these groups they would see these guys and think they are the coolest thing ever and instantly want to join.  I mean seriously, what teenager in their right mind would want to be a farmer?  Or live a life of what is basically suffering to help others?  The others are what I can only describe as brainiacs and paper-pushers.

Not to mention that during this ceremony, they are only using one knife to cut the hand of every teenager there.  One kid with any kind of disease like Hepatitis, and they are all screwed!

The story itself is kinda interesting and it does keep you watching, but it does have it's flaws.  For example, every five minutes someone is talking about, their rankings and how their rankings will effect them or how if they don't get good rankings, they will be cut out of Dauntless.  I will admit that Beatrice is a much more interesting main character than Katniss ever was and she does actually have some good motivations.

If you have time to kill and can find a copy of this, it's worth watching.

There is not a doubt this movie was meant for the youngsters but that didn't make it only for them.  For those who watched and enjoyed The Hunger Games, Divergent will certainly appeal to them as well.  Conversely, if you did NOT like The Hunger Games, you might find yourself drawn to Divergent.

Many years from now when mankind has yet screwed itself up again through wars and ignorance, society suggests divests itself into five recognized factions and the factionless.  Different factions control different functions.  For instance, the Erudite are the thinkers and Dauntless are the protectors.  Those outside the norm who embrace two or more qualities are known as Divergents.  Being a Divergent is not a good thing.

This is the story of Tris, name shortened by herself from Beatice, upon choosing her faction, Dauntless, and the trials and tribulations she faces during her training and initiate period.  To say much more would be to spoil the plot.

The book was amazing. What made it so was the depth of characters that was based largely off of descriptions of their body language and demeanor and being inside Tris' head from her perspective. It was a richly written and well thought out society that doesn't pull punches. It can be brutal and unapologetically somber. It plays with ideas of human nature and corruption as part of the human condition. It is beautiful. The movie was none of the above. They took too much creative license to alter the book. The casting was flat to say the least. There was no sense of what Abnegation was truly or any other faction for that matter. It broke good writing 101 and told the viewer everything instead of showing and revealing. Tris' parents were completely off as were her friends and foes. Four in the story was full of depth but Theo James fell short of this role. It was a tired and pointless plot where they tried to do too much with too little and left out the true meaning. It was plain awful. Skip this drizzle and read the book instead. Please don't judge the book based on this film. It is truly an insulting rendition.

First sign you are watching a movie geared toward 21 and under is the conspicuous absence of violence along with the heroine going up against men bigger than her yet somehow suffering MINIMUM brutality. I can't even start on the mellowness of Theo James. Only proves in my book Milla Jovovich, Angelina Jolie and Scarlett Johansson are the few women in Hollywood who can sell violence. Second sign of this movie that it is geared toward a younger crowd is a quiet revolution following a quiet hostile takeover. When was the last time you saw that? The premise doesn't break new ground if you've seen the likes of Equilibrium, The Matrix or Elysium. Familiar tale, familiar theme and a weak 'romance' don't really flesh out the rest. My kingdom for a movie for young adults that doesn't coddle.

Is it even possible in this day and age to make a dystopic science fiction film without it feeling somehow derivative of so many earlier, better works? I tend to doubt it.

Take "Divergent," a futuristic tale based on the book by Veronica Roth, itself just the first in a series of  novels aimed primarily at young adults. Right off the bat, one can see that "Divergent" owes a great deal to Aldous Huxley's "Brave New World," both being set in a society built on a strict caste system, where every member of the community is assigned a social level and a specialized task from which there is basically no escape. The difference is that, in Huxley's world, one is engineered from "conception" to be a member of a certain caste, while, in Roth`s, individuals are, theoretically at least, free to choose, at one crucial point in their adolescence, the group to which they will forever belong.

In "Divergent," there are five categories or "factions," as they`re called here, only two of which have any real significance in the film: Abnegation, whose principal function is selfless service to the community, and Dauntless, which serves, essentially, as the police force in this walled-off, post-apocalyptic version of old Chicago. Caught in the middle is a young woman named Beatrice (Shailene Woodley), who, while raised in Abnegation, finds that she may actually be what is called a "Divergent," a rare individual who fits comfortably into more than one category, making her an existential threat to the stability of this homogeneous society, where everyone knows his or her place and role. Beatrice opts to join Dauntless, a decision which leads to innumerable training sequences that seem to drag on for a minor eternity.

Par for the course for the dystopic genre, our divergent heroine soon finds herself on the run from diabolical government forces (led by Kate Winslet) bent on destroying her lest she throw a monkey wrench into their "peaceful," "well-oiled," "harmonious" society.

And that's pretty much all the movie is about. Throw in some dreamscape elements straight out of "Total Recall" and "Inception" - both much better films, by the way -  and soon we find ourselves heading down the rabbit-hole into incoherence and confusion from which it becomes virtually impossible to extricate ourselves.

Even decent - if pretty much standard, at this point - production values can't rescue a generally drab film.

Divergent(released Mar/14)stars,among others, Shailene Woodley,Theo James, Ashley Judd,Jai Courtney,Ray Stevenson,Zo Kravitz and Kate Winslet. This is a film I found to be totally UN-engaging and without any sense of excitement whatsoever.
The story finds us in a dystopian future Chicago. A good portion of the city is in ruins and it is surrounded by a wall. The citizens are divided into five different factions. When the children come of age they must select which group they will join."Faction before blood" is the motto.
Woodley is the lead character and when her time arrives she chooses the "Dauntless"faction;an ersatz police department which resembles a group of parkours than anything else. She has been tested beforehand and it was found that she was the film title"divergent".That is,she fit in to no particular faction. She was told to keep her mouth shut and tell no one. She enters the Dauntless group and she is put through three separate tests, along with all the other initiates. Tests can involve anything from plain fighting and  shooting skills to psychological testing. In fact psychotropic drugs are used in a variety of ways to either test or control. The latter is what eventually brews as Woodley is completing her training into the "Dauntless".It seems the leader of another faction led by Winslet is preparing to take over the city. To do that they have injected each "Dauntless"member with a drug with which they can be controlled.
Winslet and company direct them to go to an area of the city in which Woodley's parents live. There they are forced to start eliminating the population there. Woodley and other different faction members who have rebelled, join her and storm the facility where Winslet is. After a struggle they overpower them and Woodley injects Winslet with the same drug the latter used on the "Dauntless".After a quick wiping of the computer program, the slaughter of the innocents comes to a halt. Woodley boards an El which she and her friends ride to the end of the line;to the wall. They are now factionless, but have each other.
At no time in the film could I get up enough empathy to care about anything I was watching .It was like being injected with the same psychotropic drug used on the screen. I felt like I was sleep walking. Woodley has about as much charisma as a tree. It was like watching an even more sober Katness Averdeen(Hunger Games).Unfortunately the tone/dynamic/vibe we get with her character bleeds into everyone and everything else and it is.........borrrring.
Technically speaking the film is in its original w/s a/r of 2:35:1 and is clear and crisp. Extras include trailers,commentary and deleted scenes.
All in all an approximately 140 minute yawnfest of monumental proportions. I think they were going for a similar Hunger Games type lead character, but Woodley does not have the acting chops to get there. That coupled with the somnambulistic plot,and we have a film that will engender not one feeling of....anything,one way or another. Forget engagement or excitement of any kind. In fact,forget it altogether.
Unexpectedly good, moved along nicely and was true to the book... wish it have been about 15-20 minutes longer, they seemed to push the end of the movie. All-in-all a good movie.

Many reviewers have compared this movie to Hunger Games.  I can see the resemblance a bit--young people working for a society that pigeonholes them into specific groups.  There is also the strong feminine hero in this story.  However, this is where the similarities end, except for the fact, that she will--most likely--bring the government down.  The movie did foreshadow this.  Divergent is a dystopian societal story that seems to be a combination of many classics from the past.

The characters are believable and the story intriguing.  After watching once, I couldn't wait to see it again.  Moreover, I can't wait for the second in the film series.

After seeing the movie preview, I decided to see the movie in the theater.  I really enjoyed it.  Shortly after, I had to know what was going to happen next so I bought the books. Of course, you will always have the people who will compare the book and the movie.  I am both an avid reader and a movie lover.  It is unusual for me to see a movie without reading the book first (this is one of the few exceptions). I think readers need to accept that no movie is ever going to be 100% like the book - you need to be able to keep them separate to fully appreciate both.  I think this is one that is worth watching.

The 'what if's are in place for a good SciFi.  In this future world there are five classes of people (factions).  Each of the five is dedicated to a different subset of human virtues.  Whole persons would be rare in such a world, and that might be interesting to look into here.  Instead we have the heart rending family trauma as both children freely choose leave their parents' faction.  They will live totally different lives, cut off from everyone and everything they ever knew.  There's no turning back.  These choices are 'forever'.  Really heavy stuff here. Boy chooses, oh, nevermind.  Girl chooses warrior!  We got brutal training in kevlar leotard armor, cold and cruel to conceal forbidden love.  Not enough action for a guy movie.  Not enough love for a chick movie.  Not enough ideas for SciFi.  The story is different, but there's not enough of the story in the movie to make it anything more than a tired clone of Hunger Games.

So this is a formula film, not an art film or overtly sophisticated, but I loved it.  It is well acted and directed, engaging, and layered with meaning.  What more do you want for entertainment?  The film reflects many aspects of today's societies worldwide and is extremely plausible.  Strong rulers take power and control the masses through all methods of manipulation, and we, the people support them in doing so through our laziness or ignorance.  But the real power lies within the people and the hands of those people who take the responsibility to act.  Within the humanrace, it is the 'divergents' who are the free thinkers, recognize that there is no set reality other than what we create ("it is not real").  They are the ones who break out of or away from the status quo in an attempt to awaken the masses to understand that with a bit of awareness and willingness, we can live healthier, more compassionate, responsible and peaceful lives. We can be free.  It's a great film.

I liken it to a coming of age movie... teenage girl wants to find herself and go her own way, goes on a dangerous adventure, falls in love, saves the world and comes to realize mom and dad weren't so bad after all.

A common complaint of mine with a lot of these sci-fi futuristic movies... if the civilization can create sophisticated machines and devices that can see into and control the human mind or travel at the speed of light why don't they also improve or at least show an evolved kind of living condition... just seems like they scrimp on the set to save costs but to me it just screams lack of commitment to a quality movie.  I want a believable fantasy... I'm trying to escape and the visual is as important as the script, the filming and the acting.

If it's not clear, this movie is terrible.  Hunger Games was watchable, this movie is a poorly devised knock-off with almost zero redeemable qualities.  To guarantee to ruin the experience of this movie, I suggest you notice how often the "cool" faction hoots, hollers, and otherwise "woos" and "whoots" when performing only mildly interesting activities, e.g. running, walking quickly, running up and down stairs, and high fiving.  You will immediately hate all of them and go back to watching something far more valuable, like the puppy channel.
Tried to be futuristic but ended up being completely senseless and boring

First off I am going to start with, I did not read the books.  I am only going by what I saw in the movie.  So I can only assume I am missing a few things.  Maybe if I read the books I would care a little more about what is going on.  Maybe the story wouldnt be so bleh.  Maybe you couldn't poke holes in everything, or the plot wasn't so in your face easy to figure out.  This made it difficult for me.  I didn't care about the characters, I didn't care about the danger they were in, and I didn't really care about the love story either.  That being said, I didn't totally hate it.  The movie just felt like it was going through the motions.
To give you a little bit of what I am talking about, my wife and I like to talk about the movie after it is done to see how we both thought of it.  We both came to the same conclusion, and just didn't understand why a society would willfully create a utopian like society by creating factions which segregate people into 5 faction (6 really, but I will get to that later).  They are:
1. Abnegation (Selfless) Always help those in need
2. Erudite (Intelligent) The engineers
3. Dauntless (Brave) The military or teenagers getting to do what they want
4. Amity (Peaceful) The Buddhists
5. Candor (Honest).  They just never lie  whooped dee-doo
The movie made it seem like these factions couldn't intermingle or dont.  Im not sure which.
You are born into one of these factions.  However if you do not like the faction you are in, you could choose to leave and join another faction once you reach a certain age.  Before you do so, you go through a "test."  This test is to determine what faction you would be good in before you choose.  A fail safe to not choose poorly.  Once you choose, there is no turning back.  Choosing the faction you were born into would be easiest as you already know what is required of you, choosing a new faction becomes difficult and requires you to go through the trials.  If you fail these trials you become factionless (6th faction).  A dystopian group of homeless faction rejects, the janitors, bus drivers, servants. Now comes the divergent part.  Detergents could be good at all factions and is seen as a threat to the way of their societys norm.  Or as the movie calls it, someone who doesn't think like everyone else.  (Woooo special)  So back to this factionless 6th faction.  Wouldn't this factionless be classified as a faction then?  This faction does not seem to have rules and guidelines like very one else does, a faction with all factions intermingling together to strive (though in poverty).  A faction full of people not thinking like the segregated factioned utopian society.  What this movie seems to call divergent?  (I don't see a huge plot point coming in the following movies, nope not at all)
Now I won't ruin the whole movie by explaining other examples as I am really starting to ramble but this movie is meant to be watched with your brain off.  A movie for teenagers, as this faction that the main character, Beatrice (later to be just known as Tris) chooses, does not have adults.  I think I saw 1, maybe 2 once she chose to join Dauntless.  The movies "Military" force.  A faction of teenage heart throbs having to live co-ed, jumping, laughing, and running around all parkour like everywhere they go.  ((((*** This section contains some spoilers - With a captain that of course hates the lead character, and a co-captain that loves her who is also a hidden Divergent (if you didn't see it coming a mile away then please start using Lumosity.  You brain could really use some exercise)))
I think I will stop now.  If you want to watch this movie, watch it without expectations.  Watch it with your brain off.  Watch it if you are a parent and your teenage daughter wants to watch it with you, or if you yourself are a teenage daughter.  Otherwise you will be a bit disappointed.

This coming of age sci fi will appeal most to young adults, especially girls, but it is entertaining to all.  It is about a society divided into 5 factions.  If you don't fit in any you become a street person.  The world has been destroyed and a wall is built around Chicago and this new society lives within.  At certain age all young adults are committed to choosing which faction they wish to join and once they have made a choice they are stuck in it for the rest of their lives.  The film follows a young girl who is a divergent, her thinking isn't bound by any group and free thinking is outlawed, as she leaves her family faction for another more adventurous one.  Interesting film for all ages.

I gave it as much of a chance as I could stomach (about 25 minutes).  It's definitely a movie aimed at girls who are not yet old enough to drive and who lack a fair amount of sophistication.  The imagined society of the future seemed like the product of a 15 year old's imagination, and some of the concepts were downright nonsensical to the point of being absurd.  (I had to laugh every time the "Dauntless" faction was featured; they're an over the top bunch of buffoons who always seem to think everything is "super rad, man" and who take all sorts of unnecessary risks for no apparent reason other than to ...well, I don't know; there really is no reason for most of what they do.)

Too much of a thinly disguised attempt at social commentary on coming of age and trying to chose one's place in society.  A theme that I just cannot identify with anymore, and even when I could, this movie was just too dumb to have had much appeal for me.

Skip it and wait until it's free and you are literally dying of boredom.  Or, if you're a 13 year old girl, beg your parents to let you watch it; it's about your speed.

Maybe it's an age group thing. Maybe it's a gender thing. My 16-year-old daughter didn't want to see this until she'd read the novel, so I (male, 54) watched it by myself. I can't believe I sat through the entire film, waiting for something new and fresh to appear, or even something re-done, but re-done well. Ah, well...

If you're familiar with Brave New World, Where Late the Sweet Birds Sang, or even Aeon Flux or Gattica, save your money; you've seen this before - better.

I won't delve into the story beyond the above. Perhaps the novel is different; I don't know (and likely won't read it). Suffice it to say that I was unimpressed with the explanation of how Society reached the point where this film started, whether (spoiler alert) Chicago was just isolated or the last urban area left (almost) standing, and why the City was sort of half modern metropolis and half post-apocalyptic ruin. <sigh>

As for the film on its own merits, other than the heroine, all of the other characters - to a person - fell completely flat for me. Even her compatriot seems more than a little two-dimensional. Ashley Judd can - and does - act better than she did in this film, though the script surely didn't help (I think she might have done better had she had more to deliver beyond a dozen lines).

I'm glad that I opted for SD on Amazon instead of HD on FiOS for this, saving a couple $$ in the process.

This is another instalment of the latest teen fad in literature of a post war world where everyone had been divided up (for our own good) into culture groups, in this case they are based on personality lines.  The storyline is granted predictable, but is quite action packed and holds your interest.  Shailene Woodley does a great job in the lead role, and it doesn't hurt that she's quite attractive.

Divergent's set up is when teens reach a certain age they get to choose which cultural group they will become a part of.  The catch is that they can never change their mind.  Obviously the beginning of a series of movies this one mainly tackles the main character Tris' experience in her chosen group, where everything isn't as exciting as it seemed it would be, and to her horror, she is not automatically part of the society, she in fact has to compete to be worthy of staying, which amongst other tasks includes violent fights with other teens (although being a teen aimed movie, no one ever bleeds or breaks bones etc as would be the case in real life).  If she doesn't qualify in the top part of her intake, she will be kicked out and forbidden from joining any other social group, forced to live amongst a group which is pretty much the same as being homeless in our world, where of course safety and food are scarce.  Tris is of course (as is usually the case with this genre) different, she questions things, doesn't blindly want to follow orders, and can see the bigger picture of the evil of her fellow human, that is growing around her in relation to the wider world.  This is of course a pretty dangerous way of being.

I enjoyed Divergent a lot more than similar genre recent movies based on teen books such as Ender's Game and the Hunger Games.  There is obviously a lot more story to be told in this movie's world, I just hope the sequels can live up to this one (how boring was the second Hunger games film!).

Divergent was a film that was something else.  Based in a world which is divided by factions based on your way of thinking, Tris learns that she doesn't fit into any of them and that she is actually Divergent which means she won't fit into their way of thinking.  With the help of fellow Dauntless Four, the two of them discover a plot to destroy Divergents.  The two of them must stop this plot before its too late and they are all destroyed.  This film is based on the novel written by Veronica Roth and the screenplay for it was written by Evan Daugherty and Vanessa Taylor.  Neil Burger was in charge of directing this film and prior to this he was known for films such as The Illusionist and Limitless. This film is based in the future in Chicago where the society has divided into 5 factions because they believe that is the order which is the best way to survive.  Those factions are Abnegation the selfless, Dauntless the brave, Erudite the intelligent, Candor the honest, and Amity the peaceful.  There is also one group that roams the streets because they do not belong to any of the groups and they are Factionless.  When the teenagers come of age which is 16, they must chose if they want to stay with their birth faction or move to another faction.  If they chose to move though they are not allowed to go back and the rule is Faction before blood so you are forced to forget about your family if you leave them behind.  After watching her brother Caleb (Ansel Elgort) chose to leave his faction, Beatrice Prior (Shailene Woodley) must make the decision to stay where she knows she doesnt belong or transfer and leave her family behind.  She chose to go to Dauntless and leave her parents Natalie (Ashley Judd) and Andrew (Tony Goldwyn) behind.  She is not a full fledge Dauntless yet because there is a highly competitive initiation that she must pass to stay a Dauntless or get kicked out and become Factionless.  When Beatrice became Dauntless she chose to change her name as well and she is now known as Tris and she must make some tough decisions, but being a Divergent means that she has to keep a secret that could mean death.  All of these struggles are minor considering the struggles that her mentor, Four (Theo James) seems to be hiding. Four and her grow to love each other which helps when things get worse which they do, because there is something bigger that nobody seems to know about that threatens to tear the city apart.

The film was very enjoying to watch and I loved the scene above.  Everyone that changed factions is told that the only way into the city is to jump off the building.  Its awesome because you are forced to take a leap of faith or leave the faction immediately and Beatrice is the first person with courage enough to step up and do it.  After she does it of course she is safe because there was nothing to harm her at the bottom because there was something to break their fall.  There are so many scenes that are extremely thrilling in this film that if you are not a Dauntless at heart this may not be the film for you.

 Overall I give this movie an A.  This is one of the best films based off of a book that I have seen since Jurassic Park.  I really had a connection with the characters and believed it because the chemistry was there with the whole cast!  When they were sad you really wanted to shed a tear, if they were mad you got mad with them.  I wanted to jump in and help which is what I want from a film.  I want it to bring me into the environment and this one did.  If you haven't seen this one yet I definitely suggest that you go and check this one out!!

In the future, when you turn 18, Hillary Clinton will put you in one of 5 categories, the jocks get to bully people, the nerds read books in big glassy buildings, the stoners get to farm the land (and we all know what they are growing) and two types of political casts, one for the liberal arts majors and one for the preppies, but don't worry they are all very attractive people and while society went to pieces over some unexplained cataclysm this has seemingly emboldened people to take better care of themselves...

Anyway, the preppies, lets just call them 'Conservatives' about had it with how shoddy the arts majors, or 'Democrats' have run the place and they decide to do something about it by using the Jocks for a coup, preventing this entails lots of tiresome and predictable running around and shooting at things.

Like all movie this one, just as Hunger Games will in retrospect reflect a time in which people were obsessed with looks and appearances and a growing unease with the establishment without the ability to impact true change, because just like in real life while a crisis was narrowly averted, no real change came, the caste system is still in effect with our main protagonists having simply left a system that doesn't work for them.

The special effects were good.  I wish they had spent more time explaining the significance of the simulations, and less time with filler.  The teacher / student relationship is a bit more exaggerated in the movie, more inappropriate than in the books, she looks like a child, he looks like an adult ten or more years older.  That said, this might not be ok for less mature kids to watch.  Anyways, as an adult I had fun with the movie and the books, enjoy.

I have very mixed opinions about this story. The tense atmosphere amongst the divided factions works well, but the romance is incredibly predictable and unnecessary.

Woodley strongly asserts herself as Tris, someone who defies conformity and is shown to be very brave in harsh times, but I felt that the (budding) connection between herself and 'Four' (Theo James) was forced and only there for the contrivity of having the two lead characters get together. He makes sense as her brooding mentor, but I question if anyone would have been so interested in Tris and Four getting together had Mr James not been British or so attractive. Don't get me wrong, he's fine as the generic action lead male, and I can see why he was chosen (despite being much older than the actual book character) but his swift change to being her love interest did not work for me.

The other problem with DIVERGENT is that it doesn't bring anything new to the table in this era of Young Adult adaptations, it merely depicts those same cliched ideas already covered in a vast majority of movies and television shows. A basic summary: the lead female character longs to break free from a world she does not relate to and be with her brooding boyfriend who is burdened by daddy issues. Nevertheless, it's that same storyline that seems to draw in big box office numbers, so somehow, the younger generation's enthusiasm to see the same storyline over and over again amongst different movie franchises keeps these YA series popular in the media.

Some pros of the movie: the energetic score, which elevates the pace and emotion of the film; Tris' inventive ways of escaping the hallucinations; and the down-to-earth dynamic of the Prior family - although even this was marginally ruined by how the parents' journeys reach their conclusion. The underground feel of the Dauntless faction also works well, as does the superior styled setting of Erudite.

Reportedly, ALLEGIANT will be divided into two movies, and this only adds to the repetitive structure of YA adaptations as I have mentioned. I will probably watch INSURGENT, if only out of curiosity as to where the train takes the surviving characters.

I am currently reading the third book in the Divergent trilogy. I read Divergent itself a few months ago, so there were things in this movie that I had forgotten about. Overall, I think the film was very well done. I really enjoyed it.
****** spoiler below:

 I wish they hadn't changed Tris' fear of being intimate with Four to him trying to overpower her or even rape her; that was totally unnecessary. I can kind of see why they did it because since she didn't narrate except at the beginning and the end, it'd be hard to explain all her feelings of not wanting to become intimate with him.

**** end spoiler.

It's really crazy how even a longer-than-average running time movie like this can still feel like  a skeleton of the book itself. But I think they did a very good job with those 2 hours and 20 minutes. No huge things were changed, no enormous plot points were left out, nothing stupid was added. I thought the casting was terrific. Shailene Woodley did a fantastic job, and is a great actress.

Teen age years are definitely the most difficult. Problems of self-identification and uncertainties of the future cloud your mind. And, how much worse it would be if you lived in a society of contending factions where the possibility of growth and development in an extended family was a question mark rather than a certainty. Set this problem in a post-apocalyptic context and you have "Divergent." I enjoyed this movie more than I did "The Hunger Games" because it was grittier and less beholden to high tech special effects. Shailene Woodley does a bang-up job as a vulnerable but determined teen who adapts and grows in a setting of violence and adventure.

divergent was delightful. i liked that it was so different from the book. it felt like the book was written for pre-teens and as an adult i enjoyed the complexity of the movie. my only regret in the change from book to movie was we didn't get to meet any of the dauntless born in the movie they are really important in the second and thrid books so are they just going to pop out of the wood work? i understand that a movie can only be so long but i wish we could have been introduced to at least one.

Good, but seems a bit close to Hunger Games. You will wonder where Donald Sutherland went. The genre (young folks fighting an evil government) is being reborn from the 60's and 70's pollution pics (Soylent Green, Silent Running, Them) where non conformers save the world. Only these few farsighted folks understand how to save the planet.

This is strictly an entertainment vehicle. There is not much thinking required. I have not read the trilogy, so I may be a bit hard on the first installment. Maybe it will develop in a sequel. And maybe that is why I had a problem with it. I have never enjoyed movies that had intentionally ambiguous endings. Either have the story stand on its own and make us want to see the next one because it is so good, rather than making us go see the next one because you want to find out what happened in the last one. Having a movie so there can be a sequel is unfair to movie goers and the industry as a whole.

While the acting was good, I think the main characters lacked depth. The development of the characters was fast and then very slow. You can probably guess where things are going (just the title should give you a clue).

The special effects are very good and integrate well in the story. I think teenagers today will identify with the leads, but overall, it seemed formula but I am happy we are finally getting strong female leads instead of the boy saving the world...

Set in a future, dystopian Chicago where society has been divided into five factions depending on virtues, young Beatrice Prior (Shailene Woodley) - when tested - learns she is Divergent, a mix of more than two or more factions, really fitting into no one group.  Problem is, for some reason the governing society is threatened by and seeking to capture and destroy all who are Divergent, so after joining the wild Dauntless faction that holds guard over the city, she changes her name to Tris and tries to navigate her training into her new life, all the while trying to hide who she really is while avoiding the unwanted scrutiny of the hardened, mysterious Four (Theo James).  This movie seems like one people either really love or really hate, and if so I'd lean toward the former; shutting off my brain, I just enjoyed the ride, finding it much more entertaining and involving than, say, the oft-compared The Hunger Games, particularly with Woodley in the lead.  I guess one good sign I liked it: I bought the book almost immediately after watching the film

The story is similar to the book. Society is divided into 5 categories and human nature with the need to control power produces a megalomaniac taking advantage of the security faction to overthrow the government faction with the typical heroine and hero take down the bad guy. The acting is decent with the characters well portrayed. Four was solid throughout. Tris did better with action and excitement and was not completely believable in the sad emotive scenes such as her mother's death. The film is very action oriented.

I rate very few movies this high, but this one definitely makes the grade.
One of the requirements is that I could probably watch it tomorrow and still enjoy it, and again within six months.  I have no doubt that's the case with "Divergent". I watched it alone, but probably would have enjoyed it even more with family.
Other movies that fit this category were some that have already been mentioned, "The Hobbit", "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy, both "The Hunger Games", both recent "Star Wars", and a very few others.
Those giving ratings of three stars or less must just not like this genre, or are just too critical.
It may have had a similar story line as "The Hunger Games" and some other movies, yet it was vastly different, definitely enough to hold it's own.
Similarities are the young heroine and factions/castes.  However, the caste system is far different than what is seen in the "The Hunger Games".  And almost everyone is satisfied with the faction they're with.
I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoyed the "The Hunger Games".

The movie depends on your demographic. If you are under 25, you'll likely thoroughly enjoy the this post-apocalyptic fantasy world that features characters you can cheer for and perhaps relate to. If you are over that age, you may still find the whole movie charmingly naive escapism...or not....The person who wrote it, is undoubtedly in the age range of the movie characters, so I don't want to chastise the movie TOO bad. Some of the hilariously goofy movie premises I though were 'awesome' and 'kick-ass' when I was in my early 20's, I look back at and laugh at their sheer sillininess of today. Fun escapism, as long as you don't hold the movie up to the scrutiny of anything to the 'would this really happen' magnifying glass of plausibility (for which the premise and 95% of the movie is so ridiculous you would need to shut off that part of your brain to enjoy it).

Divergent
 The Twilight films and then the Hunger Games series has set off a run of adventure films with teen age girls as the protagonist.  The producers are hoping for an out of the park hit with a new billion dollar franchise.  Along the way to the bank they sometimes make something that people want to see, to trade their hard earned cash of a couple of hours of solid entertainment.  Divergent fits the bill on all marks.  It has a story we can follow and a cast of young actors that we can enjoy watching.
 In the future, 100 years after the war is as close as a date that we have, the city of Chicago evolves into an isolated island of sanity and civilization.  We don't know what goes on outside of the city, but there is a gigantic wall to keep whatever it is out and the people in.
 The society within the enclave of order and peace involves elements of great virtue.  Five casts dominate the social order, each with a particular function and personality.  The Dauntless clan protects the society from internal disorder and from nameless outside enemies.  Peace loving Amity sings and grows vegetables.  Erudite thinks about things and figures out the solutions to societys problems.  Candor runs the courts with hard edged truth telling.  Abnegation, the selfless do-gooders, is deemed moral enough to form the government and administration.  There are outcasts, homeless, hopeless bums who live precariously beyond the boundaries of the five groups.
 At 16 youngsters choose a clan, a choice that is irreversible and lifelong.  Naturally, this cannot bring anything but squashed dreams and rigid government enforced conformity.  The goal of this set up is order rather than the expansion and exultation of the human spirit.
  Divergent puts the action in some distant future so criticisms of historical accuracy do not appertain.  What quibbles we have with the fantasy/reality tension disappear in the fast passed narrative and the charm of the characters, particularly Tris, the young girl at the center of things.
 16 year old Tris is played by 23 year old Sharlene Woodley.  Viewers will remember her from many TV roles and especially in her portrayal of the younger daughter in Descendents, the recent saga of the Hawaiian dynasty staring George Clooney.  Even at 23 she can stand close

ups with no apparent make up.  She is believable as a fresh faced 16 years old.  She will continue her role as Tris in the next two episodes which are already in various stages of production.
 He co-star in Englishman Theo James as an older fellow named Four.  I saw him in a small but perfectly executed role in Downton Abbey, the immensely popular TV show.  The handsome 30 year old once said I know I often get a job because of how I look.  I hope that I keep the job because of how I act.  He can act, as he proved in Downton Abbery.  He is not asked to do so in Divergent which is a shameful waste of talent.  He is tasked with looking good (or yummy in the lexicon of the teen age girls that form the core demographic for the audience) and frowning to indicate various degrees of concern.
 Ashley Judd plays Tris mom.  The best acting nod goes to Kate Wisnlet in her role as the evil leader of the Erudite faction.  Also watch for Zoe Kravitz as one of Tris gal pals.  Kravitz is the offspring of singer Lenny Kravitz and actress Lisa Bonet.  Her beautiful parents blessed her with wonderful features.
 Novelist Veronica Roth is only 26 years old.  The three books in the Divergent series have sold in excess of five million copies to date.  Her target for the young adult novels is the demographic that begins at age 12 and continues through high school.  She knows what her audience wants and just how to give it to them.  The translation to the silver screen succeeds in spades.
 There is a deft undertone in the work about Teen Alienation that the movie brushes over lightly but definitely.  The five groups might easily be compared to the High School clans of Jocks, Hippies, Brainiaks and so on.  In one scene, a chemical induced nightmare, young Tris is shown separated from the other kids by an actual glass barrier, a symbol of the eternal yearning of young people to belong and fit in and the panic inducing sense of being outside the herd.  I thought is a nice metaphor, done quickly and without fanfare.
 Evan Daugherty and Vanessa Taylor adapted Veronica Roths novel to the big screen.  Daugherty is best known for his script for Snow White and the Huntsman.  That film attained a spectacular success and his negotiating skill garnered Daugherty a stunning $3.2 million writing fee.  Taylor penned the touching and also successful look at middle age marriage Hope Springs.
 Director Neil Burger exercises himself in Divergent and makes a craftwork film with interesting shots and techniques.  He leaves out any movie magic moments that might interfere

with the story.  Sometimes a director cannot help himself and allows the direction to become the focus of the film.  Not here, Burger keeps the audience fixed on the story, not fancy director stuff.  He also directed Limitless and The Illusionist.  Both of his best known films received good marks artistically.  Both gathered the monetary devotion of satisfied watchers.
 Divergent is on the road to a smashing box office success with a strong opening weekend domestic gate of $56 million on a budget of $85 million.  The strong three saw blade film is properly rated PG-13 for some violence.  The actors utter no bad words and while the youngsters smooch, they manage to stop there.  You get your moneys worth time wise with this two hour and 23 minute movie.  Most people will enjoy this film, especially the young teens but parents and grandparents will also like it.
 Fun Fact-Kate Wisnlet filmed her scenes while she was five months into her pregnancy.  Director Burger used his subtle director tricks to hide the bump.

While it's not a "bad" movie, it is realistically just another "oh look how cool my computer effects guys are" movie.  The story concept is interesting, and had a lot of potential; however, the actual story treatment in this movie left a lot of holes and implausibility.  My wife and I paused several times to say "huh?  Didn't they say something else before?" or "now in a society like this how would what they just did even be possible?"  I mean not at the end, but all through the movie, it contradicts itself and really is incoherent... and leaves you with a lot of unanswered questions.  That said, it is a visually stunning movie.  Though probably 98% of the sets and background in this film are obviously computer generated, which although sad is the lazy movie maker norm in this time, it is very well done.  It looks nice, there isn't pixelated poorly rendered distant background, the lighting an shadows are kept consistent with one another and the environment is imaginative and realistic at the same time.  The acting is pretty good as a whole, they cast all the parts very well (though Ashley Judd is a serious disappointment) and no one seemed to be phoning it in for once.

In the grand scheme of things I'd say this:  Did I enjoy it?  Yes.  For what it is, it was entertaining.  Would I watch it again?  NO.  It was sloppily written, and no matter how pretty it is to watch, how 'cool' the effects seem to be, the story sucks and I won't subject myself to that again.

I hope the book is better than the movie. The movie does not sufficiently establish the reasons for the existence of the factions system. It is presented pretty much as a given - sort of the way that the paper money system is blindly accepted by most people in the world. The reason for the existence of a "factionless" group is not established at all. It merely seems an arbitrary cruelty. The villains in the movie are cardboard comic-book cutouts. They are presented as evil psychotics lacking in any real motivation for their actions other than the typical lust for power over others. I suspect the book goes into much greater depth. I hope so.

All that said, it was obvious to me that certain factions represented political groupings or groupings of people in the U.S. The abnegates are obviously the social idealists, which in the United States means liberals. Other countries which have an actual left would include social democrats and socialists. The erudites gave me the impression of being libertarians who want to hack the state down to a tiny size so as to give unfettered freedom to business owners. The factionless obviously represent the homeless. I'm quite sure that the book is a political allegory. The movie, however, is so shallow that the allegory is just barely visible.

All things considered, Divergent (the movie) makes "The Hunger Games" (movies) look downright deep and intellectual. I wish I had bought the book instead of the movie.

One thing is certain when it comes to movies being made in Hollywood. If it's at all possible any movie made will come down to marketability and the chance to spin it off into a series if at all possible. Now when someone can find a series of books to turn into movies it just makes that so much better for them. Does it mean movie goers will get something special? Well, some times yes and some times no. The first two major franchises in the teen/action genre, TWILIGHT and HUNGER GAMES, have both been pretty good. But what about DIVERGENT?

After the great wars things changed and people were segregated into five factions, groups that all contribute to the greater good of the whole by performing tasks set for each faction. Abnegation believes in public service for the greater good and taking care of others. Erudite are the intelligent group built upon knowledge. Amity is the peaceful group that takes care of food. Candor handles legal matters and deals with total honesty. Lastly is Dauntless, the warriors and protectors of the whole. There is actually a sixth group, Factionless, composed of people who fit into no group.

Shailene Woodley stars as Tris, a teenager in the future living in this world, what is left of Chicago. Her family is part of the Abnegation faction but she dreams of being in Dauntless. As teens reach a certain age they are tested to see what faction they naturally belong in. The woman giving Tris her tests is stunned at the results and tells her to let no one know what they were. Tris is divergent, meaning she possesses skills in all five groups and is considered dangerous to society.

When the chance to choose arises, Tris picks Dauntless and begins life as a trainee in the group. The challenges they go through are incredibly physical and demanding but she carries on. She catches the attention of two very different leaders: Four (Theo James) who attempts to help in her training and Eric (Jai Courtney), the main leader of the band who tries to find ways to eliminate her when she displays leadership skills that might one day rival his own.

The storyline here runs down two paths, the first being the training of Tris and her trying to hide what her true nature is. To show she has too much aptitude would be to reveal herself but if she doesn't make the cut when the final test comes about, she could be eliminated altogether and sent out into the Factionless group. The second story line runs alongside this one with the Erudite planning something big that is revealed near the last 45 minutes of the film. I won't spoil it by letting you know what that is. How Tris handles both paths as they converge into one makes for much of the drama here. How she handles Four and falls for him inserts the romance that these teen franchises crave.

So does it hold up in the long run? I would say yes it does. The movie offers and entertaining action film in a world of the future. Like both TWILIGHT and HUNGER GAMES it features young people in roles once populated by middle aged males. Instead the action becomes theirs as do the romances between characters. With teens making up the major portion of the movie going audience this should make it a guarantee to fill seats. But don't let that prevent older movie lovers from enjoying this film as well. It delivers the goods from start to finish and you'll find yourself cheering for Tris before the end of the movie.

While I sometimes think the whole concept of franchise films has potential the fear that Hollywood will exclude anything else remains. Thankfully the star of this film, Woodley, has been given several great roles in the past few years including starring in THE FAULR OF OUR STARS and THE DESCENDANTS. It shows that there is some faith in her ability to not only star in a series but in independent storylines as well. As long as that continues I'm all for the franchises to carry on. With three more movies already in the works for this series I'm sure we'll be able to see what happens down the road.

I think you can tell how good this was by the speed with which it went to Netflix, Amazon, video, etc.. I know I wish I had the two hours of my life back that I wasted watching this video. Like David Letterman used to say, "People Are Hungry For Entertainment," and they must be. Poor character development, acting talent that was nonexistent, and a story? who knows. I think the writers were trying to develop something of a  Hunger Games theme, but they appear to have missed the mark badly. And, there wasn't anyone with the strength of a Jennifer Lawrence to carry this story.

Obviously, this movie must have appealed to someone, maybe the Young Adult market. However, I think that what this story lacks is the breadth of appeal that the Hunger Games had, it drew you in. This was too focused on the YA market, it lacked convincing execution and did not have the complexity to draw in a more mature audience. Of course this is why I recognize it as a "copy of", an "imitation of", a "knock-off of". I know I won't be viewing part II, that is if there is a part II, but I'm pretty sure there will be.

Another psy-op against the caste system and how you cannot "qualify" people so that they may be put into a caste/class. A good reminder for our current times, since we've learned nothing from Hitler, Stalin, Mao, Pol Pot and their eugenecist mentors.

Far more boring than the trailers would have you believe, this film/storyline is just another weak attempt to break into the wildly popular and lucrative young adult market. The main character is essentially a two dimensional caricature of other popular teenage heroines, and every plot point is painfully predictable. The soundtrack is a laughable trainwreck with poorly chosen songs so terribly synced to the story that it really pulls attention from the rest of the film. I haven't seen much of the lead actress (Shailene Woodley) in her other roles, but her performance in Divergent was surface level and boring though in all fairness, her character "Tris" doesn't give her much to work with. Of course, the real problem lies in the completely idiocy of the underlying premise of this world. The social structure of the world is ludicrous at best and so unbelievable that I find it hard to see how there could possibly be more than one book/movie set in it. I'm guessing this trilogy was a big hit with Twilight fans, but everyone else, save your money for something with at least a bit more substance...or at least something more entertaining.

This movie is too slow in its build up which robs the audience of the suspenseful ending.  Aside from the lack of suspense, there plot holes a truck could drive through.
The plot is basic at best. I spent the movie trying to guess what would happen and when. I could guess what would happen before it happened.  I suppose if you have not seen dozens of movies like this one you would be entertained.  I however found the movie boring.  The only thing I am happy about is that I did not find myself divergent of money by watching this a a theater.

This movie described a highly structured, communistic world of a future dystopia.  I think the movie is directed mainly toward a young audience, but it also has some points of interest to contemplate for people who are older than teenagers, or outside the 20 - 30 age bracket.  Neuroscience in this future is extraordinarily advanced, and is used to place young people in the available groupings, the "factions" (which are not ranked hierarchically), that make up this society.  Despite the knowledge of the particular "breed" of person, and such extraordinary ability to select for a young person's life, after testing, the young adult is still permitted to select for his or her group, which is usually the group defined by the test.  The test also identifies, to some extent, what are called the "divergent".  The "divergent", the people who can adapt and survive, and receive the benefits of a culture's resources in bringing them to adulthood, but who do not fit, are a serious threat in this structured, closed world.  Why?  It is a question that I believe applies not only to this fantasy world, but to the broader world of reality.  What makes the "different", the "individual", a threat for the group hives we humans create?  In this movie, part of the answer is pretty obvious, but partly it leaves us with something to ponder.  I read some of the serious criticisms of this movie, and they seem to miss the point a bit, although some criticisms have merit.  The movie is a bit too flawed to warrant five stars.

I liked it.  I was not particularly happy with how much was eliminated in the translation from book to screen, but that's kind of always the case when you've read a book first.  It's inevitably a disappointment.  All in all though, it was an entertaining movie and my husband who hadn't read the book enjoyed it.

Apparently, teen novel adaptations are all the rage right now.  This year alone we have the first part of the conclusion to the Hunger Games trilogy (or is it a quadruplet or some other made up word like that?) as well as films like The Giver and The Maze Runner and earlier this year everyone went crazy (or at least a bunch of teenage girls did) when Jennifer Lawrence 2.0 (a.k.a. Shailene Woodley) starred in the big screen adaptation of Divergent.  I initially had no desire to see this, considering that I kind of loathe Woodley as an actress, but I used to hate Jennifer Lawrence too, and The Hunger Games was partly to blame for my shift in opinion of her.

Beside, this also stars Kate Winslet, and Ive been in love with her since forever so Ill stoop to watching just about anything in order to see her school everyone around her.

Its a shame that Divergent is a ridiculous, lazy, halfhearted, underdeveloped and over stylized absolute mess of a film, because it had the makings of something that could have been halfway decent and yet, well, this was outright awful.

I have so many issues with this film that Im not even sure where I should begin.  I felt almost ashamed to be hating every second of this film, because I was in a room with my best friend and his wife and my wife and his brother and his brothers wife and they were all kind of glued to the screen and loving this movie and I was hiding in the corner of the couch Tweeting about how awful this movie was.  I mean, I had this awkward smile on my face the entire film because I couldn't for the life of me understand how anyone could find this remotely entertaining in a serious fashion.

It was comical in its depiction of teen life and almost reminded me of a modern-day set Nicholas Sparks adaptation (because he just CANNOT write for modern culture).  It all feels so put on and overtly obvious.  The depiction of the Dauntless felt so early 90s, but not in a good way.  Think Hook and then laugh because they are serious with this mess.  I also couldn't really care much for the films description of futuristic life and those factions mostly because it felt so Hunger Games lite.  Like, weve seen all of this before done much better, and while I cant say that The Hunger Games is a relatively smart piece of literature (because, well, come on), the film (and the novel, to a degree) understands the absurdity and uses it as an advantage, dissecting it in order to present a near satire at current pop culture.  Divergent is almost too serious minded to be taken seriously as much of anything, and it is so stale in its presentation, thanks to an absolutely lifeless performance by Woodley.

I wanted to shoot myself about three minutes in while Woodley was talking at me, explaining what her world was like.

I don't care.

Shut up.

Please turn this off.

The production values aren't any better, really.  I mean, so much of this was so obviously shot against a green screen that it becomes awkward to watch (that train jumping scene, both of them, were just preposterous and ugly to watch).  No one is remotely interesting, and the pointless backstory created feels wasted on this film.  I understand that this is the beginning of yet another trilogy, but at least give us something to care about here.  Instead, we have visions of beatings that aren't explored and a family that feels divided almost immediately, for no reason presented at all.  It doesnt help that the only performance here with any real life is Miles Teller, who has a thankless bully role and is pretty much abandoned halfway through only to get a small shot at more screen time in the end.

Winslet does fine here, truly, but her villain couldn't be more bland.

I guess that is the bottom-line here; this movie (story, book, whatever) is so incredibly bland.  There isn't anything interesting at play here.  The story feels borrowed, heavily.  The ideas feel marginally developed, with no real spice or detail.  The characters are one note and disengaged.  The performances are a bore, the music is so horribly overplayed and overbearing (like, SHUT THAT MUSIC OFF, PLEASE!) and the finale is so swift it feels horribly lazy and almost rushed.

Another real issue I have here is the amount of time it takes to get to the point.  This is probably the films largest downfall, because by the time we actually get to the actual Divergent issue, weve already checked out.  Who cares?  Whos still paying attention?  I wasnt, or at least I wish I wasnt.  I mean, I understand that this is building a foundation for more films to come, but taking over an hour to get to the meat of the story was wasted celluloid and created content that felt like filler, and if your film is filled with 50% filler then you have a real problem.

Theres no way to avoid a comparison to Hunger Games, so here it is: I consider the "Divergent Trilogy" to be a strong runner-up to the "Hunger Games Trilogy" -- they have many similarities and both envision a dystopic, distant-future United States with highly factionalized populations.  The Hunger Games movies are extremely well done with phenomenal young and adult actors.  Similarly, the Divergent film has been casted and produced very well, however the story is just not quite as strong as the Hunger Games (in my opinion).  Thus, like the books, Divergent was a strong 2nd place to the original Hunger Games movie.  Even still, it was very good and I really, really enjoyed it!  Definitely recommended for fans of the dystopian/sci-fi genre and/or fans of the books

In a world where you must live among those that are divided into groups that are chosen by you only to find out that you are not like the others.  The added pressure of pleasing your family about the choice you made to join a select group only to find out the group that your family chose for themselves may be in danger.  Interesting story of dividing and manipulating select groups of people until you run into someone that will not conform.

This is a movie for ALL (not necessarily kids).  You can watch this movie and just enjoy the story of the maturation of a young woman from a position of submission to a position of power (along with a little love story), or you can catch a much deeper satirical message if you pay attention. Monstrously incomplete and totally boring 3/4 of the way through. I literally didn't finish watching it. How does a society divided up into values keep the peace when it so obviously would end up in conflict? Why did the main character pick the warrior caste (the movie makes it appear to be pure caprice...which I doubt). Would anybody seriously believe that a caste based on goodness and simple values is orchestrating large-scale theft of resources successfully? And how do you pick the bad guy these days? They either have a heavy accent, or they are affluent and attractive. Good guys wear jeans, skimpy tops, and have tattoos.

No, I didn't read the book, and I get that many of these questions may have been less annoying if I had. But I don't think that's acceptable as a reason; I know a lot of people that never read The Lord of the Rings and loved all three movies. I didn't read the Hunger Games and thought the movie was decent, in fact I watched it twice.

The beginning is the most interesting, but like many of the now-day "ADHD" type movies it begins good and starts to move too fast and leaves the viewer to put the pieces together in your own mind. "ADHD" type movies = any and all movies that just jump through the motions and force the viewer to rely on previously produced films and / or your own imagination to put the sequences together. Like the mind of someone who's hyperactive - they seem to think that you are connected with their thoughts with some magical mind link and you just naturally know what's happening without actually seeing and experiencing the actions and sequences in the movie. It's like the producers are saying to themselves "Cut ! We've all seen this in 100 other movies, the audience will figure it out... let's just shoot the next scene."
I'm noticing a lot of films coming out now that seem to be this way and I'm tired of it.

Better book adaptation than most.  No blatantly poor acting.  Smarter than the targeted audience expects.  The music is entertaining without being harsh or dull, particularly during the end credits.  Also appealing is the lack of gratuitous cursing, nakedness and sex which the vocal sci-fi crowd demands of every production.  Every once in a while a sci-fi film comes out which attempts to tell a story with characterization rather than effects, and this is one of them.  This is often because the budget could not afford it, but in this case, it's because the characters and story are strong enough without the lavish effects.  While the story concepts are admittedly well worn in this genre, the book author's slant using a multi-caste social system with strongly divided lines allows a little wiggle room to explore two castes which are forced out to live in scorn or distrust; the "factionless" and the "divergents."  School age viewers will identify with the clique parallels.  Most will identify with the risks associated with departing from social expectations.
-Pv-

I think my first mistake was reading the books and then watching the movie. The movie was bad. Just... bad. There were scenes left out, scenes put in that weren't supposed to be there that messed up the story line. Not enough blood. Not enough pain. I think the best scene was when Ashley Judd's character died - she did it well. (I teared up) Shailene Woodley's character was spot on in that scene as well. (I could actually feel her pain) Other than that, the feeling wasn't there. It reminded me a lot of Twilight. That is SO not how Divergent is. I wanted to like it, I really did. I watched it 3 times to see if I would change my mind. It didn't. I doubt I'll see any of the sequels. I'll just reread the books. It's always better in my head anyway. So if anyone wants my copy, I'm selling it...

This was a good movie.  It was somewhat predictable.  I enjoyed the futuristic, yet simplistic settings.  I want to live outside the wall, though.  If I was them, that is where I'd go.  I guess they will have to make a sequel and take us outside the wall.  Anyway, I'm divergent for sure as I totally relate and do not conform.  I enjoyed this movie. It was a little bit of a call for us to wake up a little to what too much government can do to a society... especially a corrupt one.  Where power is desired, there is nothing the evil in a human won't do.  I can see America becoming like this if the people don't take it back and remind our government in America that they work for us.  Good reminders.  Good running theme.  A lot to think about and to discuss.  It is one that will have you thinking for a few days after watching it.  I hope you enjoy it too.  I would have given it 5 stars, but I did not like the ending.

They did a good job on this movie.  It followed the book well, cut back on the teen angst, and the main characters have some chemistry.  This is young adult fiction about a dystopian future, so don't expect sophisticated drama.  On the other hand, it had pretty good character development and dialog.  The story is well adapted from the book -- mostly what is left out isn't missed. (I do wonder if someone who did not read the book would "get it" quite the same way we did, since we knew the backstory.)  The plot is solid and the story has very few gimmicks or loose ends.  It is an entertaining escape from reality, and it left me thinking that I would be back for the sequel.

Maybe it was because the movie followed what I remembered of the book well enough that I just wasn't surprised by anything, or maybe it was too slow.  Or both.  I do remember the book feeling very exciting, and the movie somehow doesn't bring that across.

Unfortunately it tries to liven things up by mimicking Twilight's style of adding pop music to scenes that really don't need it (e.g., eating in the cafeteria). It was distracting to such a point that I'd turn to my husband and ask if one of the characters had turned on a radio and I missed it.  And Tris just doesn't come across as the strong person the book portrays her as.

Seeing the movie did make the book's story seem more juvenile to me too and reaffirmed the fact that I don't care to read the rest of the series: She's special; she can't be put in a category like these other dopes! Dauntless is crazy-- they get tattoos and zipline! etc.

I can't say the acting was terrible (not great, but not terrible), and there was nothing about it that was egregious, so I give it a 2.75. I can't quite bring myself to give it a full 3.

This is the first of the "Divergent" trilogy books.  150 years in the future people are segregated into different factions.  They undergo testing to determine which faction they are best suited for but may choose the one they want.  Some people don't fit in and are "divergent".  Divergents can't be controlled by the powers that be so they are eliminated, thus requiring them to hide the fact.  Book one of the trilogy follows a young female divergent.  Present day Chicago fills in for a seedy, rundown future city.  The movie is about 2 hours long with a 45 minute "The making of" following.
