Set in a post apocalyptic Chicago, protected by a giant fence made of TV antennas and bleachers, this young starlet finds out that she is "divergent". Divergent, as far as I can tell, means that you like older men with tattoos who are subject to mind control from Kate Winslet (Titanic Chick). If you are in the mood for a couple hours of mindless child-coming -of-age in a FM antenna filled Chicago hell hole then this is your flick. I, on the other hand, would prefer that you instead dedicate those 2 hours to developing a mind erase devise, which I can then use to "divert" this movie from my memory banks. All this is just to say...heed the title DIVERT, avoid, change direction, evade, elude...do anything but watch this movie.

Hunger Games inspired, glossy-magazine-model-cast, modern-contemporary-furnished apocalyptic future not far from now.
Good fun, albeit a bit too "perfect" in some ways. For example all the factions had tailored designer clothing, a dystopian future beset with G-Star clad "Dauntless" in matching outfits, including the Derelicte inspired factionless. I wish that there were more people with scars; a bit more "gruff" and "real". It's reminiscent of the latest Star Trek movie series in its overly-polished squeaky-clean appearance. In fact, it should just be called Detergent since there is not one iota of dirt on any clothing other than the stage-dirty Derelicte factionless. The only thing that diverged was my interest and the movie at various intervals.

The story line is fairly similar to the Hunger Games female lead's journey to self-discovery and resistance to the system which holds society in a dystopian, fascist lock-down. It's an easy-on-the-eyes watch which is enjoyable as long as you don't expect any intellectual prodding from its plot.

I am a fan of science fiction and some fantasy so it is not too surprising that I was intrigued by this movie. I had first rented the movie and then watched it three times during the rental period; I have now ordered the Blu-ray and the entire series of books including "Four" so this will suggest my level of enthusiasm for the story. I am also a fan of "The Hunger Games" series and have read those books many times.

As I watched the movie for the second and third times I began to see some interesting parallels between the story and the situation in the United States today; I wonder if the similarities are intentional or coincidental; it is something to ponder.

The general outline of the story is a post-apocalyptic society located in what had been Chicago and has become an isolated community divided into five factions. "Factions over blood" has become the standard to which all should adhere. The heroine of the story is a young girl, Tris, played by Shailene Woodley, who encounters a dangerous problem with which she is compelled to deal.

The movie is well paced and never failed to hold my interest as Tris meets the challenges that are thrown at her. The characters are sympathetic and the viewer can develop a concern for their well being as the story progresses.

There are four novels about the "Divergent" world and chronologically this is the second in the series. Based on the success of this first movie it is likely others will follow.
Parts of it are aimed for the adolescent audience, but it was a great escape movie.

I hated the Twilight series because Belle was one of the most useless and annoying heroine I've seen in awhile. I'm indifferent to the Hunger Games- didn't like the first movie and didn't care enough about the plight of the people to see the sequel. And I tried watching the other YA adaptations in between but it all sucked as well. I'm probably not their demo anyways at the ripe old age of 30ish!!  Lol! Anywho, I enjoyed it much more than I expected ( lowered expectation usually yields above average rating!) Tris started out a little meek but through out the movie she became a stronger person - both physically and emotionally. I like movies with character arcs that show growth, so it was nice to see that in this movie. Also, Four was a strong counterpart to Tris - he was intelligent, strong, and capable as well. It's always good to the see both male and female leads be equals. The story was fast paced but interesting, although not really new ides but it still felt fresh.  The only issue I really had was the abrupt ending - but I supposed that is the pitfall of trilogies.
Good actors. Too many holes in the story. But an ok movie.

Tris in the book was strong and opinionated to a fault. She talked to much,  was proud and stubborn. The Tris in the movie makes me want to cry. She was weak. She had no fire, no substance, no depth, she was just weak(didnt I just say that). I didn't feel this was until I read the book.  I blame the director, this was poor directing at its best.  Shailene's acting in the movie had no variation- maybe there is a technical term for that, I don't know, but this is the directors fault.  I loved the actor who played Will, he was funny. The actress who played Christina did good, as well as the guy who played Eric. Theo James did good as well. I just thought the director failed to capture the essence of the book.

I also blame myself. I watched the movie-absolutely loved it. Purchased the movie. Then I messed up. I read the book. The book was wonderful in every way, but it made me change how I felt about the movie. The relationship between Tris and Four was so wonderfully intense. The movie failed to show just how much they were endeared to each other. Movies are not like books I get it, but the director missed the mark on this one. It wasn't that he did not put in certain scenes, understandable, but he failed to show the depth of their relationship and feelings for each other-just in this book. Maybe the second director will do better

It's ok...that's about it. The male lead (Four) is fun to look at, the female (Tris) is so-so. The best way to sum up this movie is The Hunger Games meets Twilight. I wish I would have waited until it came out on cable instead of paying to watch it.

A good movie, can't wait to see what happens in the sequel (don't want to read the books). The acting is good for most characters, yes some are a bit off, but they are the exception and not the rule. There are some story line gaps, but if you can let them go, you will enjoy this dystopic  film.

You could tell it was a low budget film. Wait it had a higher budget than the first Hunger Games (Sad). In comparison to the other large book franchise such as LoTR and Harry Potter, its is about on the same level of Hunger Games and had over 12 million more to spend. Witch makes it even more irritating because it was not any better, I hate comparing the Hunger Games to Divergent because they are not all all similar, its not a group of teenagers killing each other (nice roll models there) its groups of people that are "segregated" into 5 groups and the 6th group are the Faction'less. And then there are those

SPOILER: STOP READING. That are Divergent, witch in the English language dictionary means: tending to be different or develop in different directions. So in this story some people 'don't fit in" with just one Faction. SPOILER OVER.

You don't understand the depth of emotions Tris is feeling in relation to the events because you don't realize how important certain characters are to her.

Overall, I actually enjoyed the movie just as much, if not more than the book because the pacing was better.

If you have not read the book, but enjoy dystopian storylines, you must see this movie at least once!

A definite movie to own or at least rent and then you will want to own it.
Awesome movie

The movie was ok but I'm glad I rented it and didn't buy it. It was slow and took  way to long to get to any action or the main purpose of the plot. The way society was portrayed didn't seem viable; what purpose did having 20% of the population be "candor"? Speaking the truth doesn't seem like an occupation, they didn't seem to have any connection with the government. Who manned the stores, picked up the trash, who were the doctors? Being ex military the training seemed very wasteful in that 20% of all recruits had to fail and be thrown out in the waste pile on non factions? What society can afford to waste so many young adults? Too much of the movie was spent on brutal training that didn't add anything to team work and seemed destined to kill some of the recruits. There was no explanation about why the Mom changed factions, why the brother selected a different faction, the movie didn't make any sense.

I never read the books so I really didn't know what to expect of the movie. I usually don't like compare them anyway, as you can never make a movie from a book and be, "verbatim." The acting overall was good, not excellent, but good. The 'adults' -if you will- roles did seem to be a bit hesitant and shallow. It's hard to explain - I just didn't see a lot of depth of character in the parental-type figures.

As far as the ebb and flow of the film, there seemed to be more ambling than any kind of real momentum. It wasn't just the absence of true 'action' scenes like you'd think there would be, but just a lack of real momentum in the story. I was never really sure what kept the storyline moving forward. Without discussing in detail each scene or character, I'll just say there was a whole lot of answered 'whys" to character actions, societal and cultural portrayals, and, for me, a huge 'why' about the reasons for one faction to suddenly become so militant and 'evil.' I know the movie gave reasons, they just didn't make sense and certainly didn't have enough back-story to explain the explanation.

In conclusion, I was glad I only rented the movie. I realized this when I clicked on the movie to see how much was left to watch and despaired that I still had over an hour to go before it ended.  Here's to hoping any sequel has more movement and reasoning to it.

What a great role model Shailene is...she is pretty, but not perfect...how refreshing to see a non plastic person (young or old) on screen. The casting of this movie is flawless...well except for Mekhi Phifer...nonessential role that did not call for a well known actor. Eric is a scary dude without having to try...he's one cold character!  The soundtrack is glorious!

First of all this isn't really a true sci-fi film, the script builds a world but fails to explore any of it save a narrow storyline which is basically a hyped after-school special type of story. You know the kind where there's the HS girl who doesn't belong but works hard to prove herself, add obstacle for instant heroine and then finish by pairing her with the hard-to-get cute guy, love & integrity win the day yada yada yada. The story is very predictable which is strange since the theme is "divergence". If your an adult but are interested in these kinds of stories you're better off investing in the 'Hunger Games' series where the world they build is more complete, nuanced and layered.

This movie was your typical recycle of the past few years worth of teen movies.  It was very predictable, it tries to force a love story that it doesn't need, female heroine that is special from everyone else, separated from parents and must grow up quick.  These movies are metaphors for going to college.  The film was still watchable, i finished the 3 hours but halfway through i felt dissapointed with the direction the plot was going.  The worst thing about this movie is that its 3 hours long but doesnt have anything realistic about it to get you into it.  Example would be everyone lives in a grungy bunker with no showers but everyone has perfect hair, notably the girl, seriously you will notice how good her hair looks to the point its distracting.  A sci-fi or action movie should be over the top unbelievable and hour n a half long or believable at 2+ hours.  I can go on and on about what ruined this film for me but overall i think most people will find it okay but not worth renting, and a few loving it that can relate with the main character and havn't watched all the other ones.

Read the book before I watched the movie. It was one of those books where the end was so convoluted and rushed that it not only felt like an after thought but made me wonder if the same author even wrote the ending. I kept thinking that the book had the potential to be so much more if only the author had taken a few more months in revision. I wondered if perhaps the movie would have picked up where the author failed and in some ways they improved the inconsistencies in the plot but they left out the violence and rage and danger that the initiates faced in training which is the most compelling part of the story. I kept asking myself if this was about the ratings. Did they need it to be G rated to bring in more viewers? Totally flabbergasted by both the book and the movie. Both left me feeling like they had the opportunity to be significant but failed.

I truly wanted to like this movie. I wanted to enjoy it as much as I enjoyed the book. Alas, I could not. Maybe it's because I am nitpicky, maybe it's because I am a super book nerd, or maybe it's because this movie was just terrible. This movie was just not likable. I completely understand that almost 99% of the time, there is no comparing the movie to the book, the book is always better (except One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, I hated that book with a passion, but that movie is a classic!! go ahead, judge me)! There were just too many differences, too many things left out, and too many changes. The ending, that's all that really needs to be said, it was awful! I hated that simple things were left out or changed completely in the movie. Yes those things were simple and minor, but they were also important to the plot of the book. If you have not read the book and are not a huge fan of the series, you can probably enjoy the movie. If you enjoyed the book and the rest of series, watch the movie with an extremely open mind to change and differences, otherwise you will hate it as much as I did!

In the future if I want early online access to a movie I will preorder it in the store or through VUDU.

This movie delivers a powerful message about being an individual and not conforming to a category defined by society. It is not a new theme, some other reviewers have suggested The Hunger Games movies as being similar, however, I disagree and feel they deliver a different message, a "hate the rich" or "the rich are evil" theme, which Divergent stays clear away from. Initially this movie reminded me of Anthem by Any Rand (if you like this movie you'll love Anthem, you can read it in a few hours and it too brilliantly portrays the message of being yourself in society). I very much enjoyed this movie, especially the celebration of individuality. If you are the kind of person that prefers hiding in groups or hates people that stand out as exceptional, don't waste your money on this movie because it will make you angry; be guided accordingly.

Though I never read the book it is based on...I have seen Hunger Games with Jennifer Lawrence and Shailene Woodley (lead actress) is no Jennifer Lawrence.  She looks similar, but the raw talent is just not there to make her believable in this movie.  There are scenes that are great, but then the director says "cut" and he goes and chases after another subplot...leaving the concept of the moment loss.  What you end up watching is a "hodge-podge" of the Matrix, Hunger Games and a little bit of every futuristic science fiction movie ever made.  To top off all of that there is another one of those "pre-sequel endings which tells us to get ready for Divergent number two.
I thought this futuristic movie was very well done.  I would recommend this movie.

Not nearly as good a transition from book to screen as the Hunger Games series so far.  Major rewrites of the story in places.  Starts off pretty good but not as well matched at the end.  The lead actress is better than I expected at playing Tris, but we are also dealing with studio the clearly wanted this to be her "Jennifer Lawrence" moment so they keep her too clean and her hair to well groomed.  Same problem with NBCs Revolution.. its a bad genre I call  "Salon Punk", post apocalyptic but with perfect hair... you may not be aware of the cameras in every scene , but you are aware of the hair stylist off camera.
With all the rewrites at the end of the movie, they still left it just a bit unfulfilling.  If you like the books, I think you will still enjoy the movie, Kate Winslet nails Jeanine Matthews, in general the casting is really good.  I liked the first 2 books, 3# is slow slog to get through.. but I was still was entertained by this movie and will rent it next year when it hits Amazon or Red box.  If you like the movie at all, the books are better fire up the Kindle and read them.

Although I have watched hundreds of films through Amazon's service, for various reasons I almost never write a review.

I felt compelled to write one here because I believe that for those, such as myself ,who have not read the book (LOL I had never even heard of it), the trailer does not do this film justice.

Merely from viewing the trailer I got the impression that it was your typical, hokey, run-of-the mill, simplistic, not credible dystopian flick.

Contrary to my expectations I found the film to excellently and beautifully paint a realistic post-apocalyptic world requiring little,if any, suspension of disbelief.

The outstanding acting, plot, script, character development, and visuals had me totally gripped every minute along the way.

I'm positive that the book had to be better. Acting was good but the plot lends itself to the readers imagination. This movie could have been one of those "After school Specials" from back in the 70's.

This review is about the DVD quality not the movie. I put the dvd in to play it and it hung up on the coming features section playing over and over again the same movie promo. I had to force it forward by selecting the menu and then telling it to play movie. Also, at scene 8 it hung up on that scene playing it over and over again without moving forward. I again had to go to the menu and force it into the next scene by selecting the scene after where it hung up thus missing a bit of the movie. It was purchased brand new from Amazon and I have contacted Amazon about replacing it. Hopefully I will have not issues they are usually good about this kind of thing.  Do not know if there is a problem with a block of the copies shipped but wanted to alert people to the issue I had. My rating is due to the problem with the DVD. The movie itself is good but not great. Was not the same as the book in fact an important scene from the book was omitted from the movie which I think helped portray the characters psyches very well and explained things better by utilizing that scene the movie omitted. Also Caleb  did not go to his parents side during the rising of the faction Erudite via control of the Dauntless as they showed in the movie. In the book Caleb was a sniveling self centered superior acting jackass and in the movie they portrayed him as more sympathetic and caring which he was not throughout the book or the subsequent 2 books. (Spoiler alert for those who have not read the books- read at your own risk) In fact I never understood why Tris sacrificied herself for her brother at he end of the third book. Which I thought was the worst ending ever and I think I am supported in this belief by many who read the series. It was a horrible ending no matter how you sliced it and much was left unsaid and unexplained as to he issues for the encampment in the enclosure in Chicago were divulged. I know why they set up the encampments but why they continued  after what was happening on the outside or why the outsiders (not the controllers of the camps but the embattled civilians themselves) did not rebel and crush these ridiculous camps I do not understand. I liked the first two books ok but did not like the third one. It seemed a waste of a powerful and influential character to kill of Tris and the return of the people to Chicago after what they found outside seemed cowardly and a waste of what they knew and what they could do to effect possible futures.  JMHO

Divergent is in fact divergent. It has elements of stories that may remind you of some other movies like The Hunger Games. That said it is unique and engaging, and still keeps the action fan in us happy. If you enjoy Science Fiction movies that are philosophical about a utopian society you will probably be pleased. I found it exciting, emotional, and intelligent. It isn't easy to combine those into a theme that doesn't seem either over the top ridiculous or mushy. It is successful in making us see a society of people divided into five factions. Although it seems perfect, inevitably someone gets the idea they are better for ruling the rest. In this case the supposed intelligent lawmakers. Was this a jab at lawyers? The peaceful agrarians that have been the decision makers are now in danger of being overthrown by the treacherous cold and calculating leader of the lawmakers. These lawmakers shouldn't be capable of such treachery and yet the leader somehow has convinced others like the leader of the law keepers it is for the greater good. Now to add a twist there are those in the society that could fit in anywhere they want because they have the makings of all, but this divergence is considered a threat and so they are ostracized and are killed or forced to flee the protection of the city. Perhaps a jab at our worldwide societies having difficulty finding rulers that have intelligence, compassion, and strength of character to stand up for everyone. I had heard mixed things about the movie, but I'm glad I decided to rent it. Although I thoroughly enjoyed and purchased both Hunger Games, I found this more thought provoking and I plan to add it to my library too. It seemed to me they left Divergent open for the possibility of a sequel, at least I hope so. CA Luster

A lot of folks compare Divergent to Hunger games, and they're right! I saw this at the theater on opening week and wanted to go back, but never made it. So I've been waiting anxiously for it to come out on DVD. In the interim I began to wonder if I was going to enjoy it as much on the small screen. I've gotta say, I love it at least as much now as I did then, if not more. The characters are solid creations, the writing is fabulous, and even the sets are easily believable. You can look at this future Chicago and say "yeah, I could believe that's how things could look in 100 years. Shailene Woodley is fabulous as Tris. You can believe that this young woman is just that good, and has the strength and courage to face the things she does. And Tris' relationship with Four is genuine and strong, without it taking over the plot. Not to mention that Theo James, as Four, is a handsome young man! They learn that they can trust one another early on and that trust deepens throughout the movie. It's very nice to have a relationship that just grows, without the soap opera angst that you so often see in this type of movie.  Kate Winslet, as Jeanine is a very low key, driven villain, quietly frightening as she creates her own version of hell on earth. One actress/role that I fell in love with instantly, was Ashley Judd, as Tris' mother, Natalie. She was very much the earth mother type, but shows her fangs and claws when things got rough. I just wish she had a bigger role in the movie! Finally, as this is the first role I've seen her in, I have got to say that Lenny Kravitz and Lisa Bonet created quite a lovely, talented child in Zoe Kravitz ;) Finally, Jai Courtney, as Eric, is the embodiment of cold, heartless evil!

I could go on and on, but I'll simply finish by saying, see this movie!

now that ed wilson's dubious sociobiology has been invented, and direct genetic measurements (and manipulations; do you really believe they will be confined to vegetables?), the association of human behaviors and quialities (intellect, altruism, aggression, love, obedience, independence, creativity, patience, certainty...) are going to be linked to genes and gene sets, and the ensuing assignment of identity and. social status is becoming a possibility, however tenuous it remains.  behavioral stereotyping, conditioning, and rigid assignments to class are nothing new.  divergent explores a dytopic system that rejects human nature itself as a dysfunctional invention (which, in terms of survival, it certainly seems to be) that can only be constrained by the segregation of the species into a few mutually compatible castes, overseen by a distinterested governing faction (the very opposite of jefferson's vision of a heterogeneous one; tj distrusted any factions, including religions and political parties as inimical to a stable, democratic, and balanced government.  in point of fact, both he and franklin were confirmed atheists).  according to the story, most individuals manage to conform to one of five divisions, to which they are either assigned, or select on a probationary status, risking exclusion from all.  the divergents are innately incompatible with any, being far too multiple in their qualities, and impossible to subjugate.  makes for a modestly engaging scifi (however, suggest the much better '97 version, gattaca, in which all choice is elliminated, or equilibrium, as alternatives; the first genetically id's at birth, although it is the second that attempts to subdue human nature itself, by anesthetizing it).  i do know of the divergent books, and i assume they have accumulated a noticeable following, or this thing would not have been produced.  i found its scientific content to be nil, and the actual nature of the gifted, but endangering divergent to be rather vague; apparently their only unique trait is their superindividuality.  as an action/ scifi regard it as unextraordinary, but quite watchable (caveat emptor: for those attracted to cgi, it is very slight).

I have not read the books. From the looks of this movie they must have been for tweens. From the very beginning this movie makes no sense. If it is following the books, then I would say they don't make sense. Spoiler Alert: If you take a test to find out what "faction" of this futuristic society you fit, then why would you then be able to just choose what "faction" you wish to belong to? That makes absolutely no sense. Then we learn our lead character is a "divergent" who supposedly doesn't fit into any "faction". Again, what does it matter if you just choose? The movie is a sleeper at best. I don't believe it was worth the price of a rental. As usual with crappy movies they took the few "good" scenes to create a trailer. Do not waste your money unless your "tween" is begging to watch it. Though it steals from a few other movies, "Hunger Games" comes to mind first, it is a abysmal bore.

The Blu-ray quality is low and could not have been better than the standard version.  Regardless of all these negatives, if you like Hunger games, you should like this.

Okay, so first off, before I go on, you must realize i hated the book. Well, actually, more than the book, I hated the heroine of the book - Tris. I so wanted someone to kill her and put her out of my misery.

That said, I was still intrigued to see the movie. I mean, how could they ruin the book when I hated it, right?

I have to say - except for the final fight scene, I thought they did an amazing job. I actually liked Tris. They followed the book relatively closely - which is funny considering how much I hated the book that I liked the movie version.

In the movie, Tris was likable, Four was...well, YUM! But if they hadn't changed the final scene - if they had kept it relatively close to the original - I might have been able to rave about it completely. But changing that final scene is one of the things I absolutely hate about Hollywood. If you are going to stay SO close to the storyline, why throw it all out at the end? (Don't get me started about their bastardizing Breaking Dawn's ending.) They now don't have the harddrive which is a major issue with Tris at the beginning of the second book. (Of which I was only able to get through 1/3 of that book before giving up. Now I have high hopes for the movie.) Not to mention injecting Janine with the meds to have her destroy the program? Ugh! That was Four's job (and I do prefer the name Four to Tobias). We all know that was his job.

All-in-all, though I gave it 4 stars. It kept my attention. It only took me 2 times to watch it all the way through (most movies take 5-6). And, like I said, I actually liked the heroine in it.

An okay way to introduce Plato's Republic with the obvious pitfalls of Plato's Republic. It makes a good little parable about the dangers of a self-congratulatory "intellectual" class assuming the powers to substitute their judgment for everyone else's judgment. The parable falls down a bit when the "kindness" faction is a 100% virtuous and victimized segment of society. Certainly the moral vanity of identifying oneself as morally superior is just as great as identifying oneself as intellectually superior for the purpose of using violence or the threat of violence to substitute your faction's judgment for the individual judgments of everyone else. It is logically and as a matter of history just as destructive of liberty. The Communists Socialists and the National Socialists murdered en mass to create a morally, racially and  "inevitably" better society that the polylogisms of racism, ethics (minus the do no harm dictum) and historical inevitability "showed" them to be the correct path -- "we are the people we've been waiting for"  The movie was everything it tried to be though and I admire good craftsmanship. Remember though Stalin, Envir Pasha, Hitler, Pol Pot, Mao and other government thugs justified oppression and mass murder with their moral and intellectual superiority as well as a belief in biological or historical inevitability. They were the people they had been waiting for. More people have been murdered in the name of "progress" than for any other cause.

This is not a commentary on the movie. The movie is okay. It's not great. It's not bad. This is a commentary on the overall package. I can't compare it to the book since I haven't read it yet. Anyhow, this is an interesting dystopian tale of castes/factions which everyone is supposed to fit into, but not everyone does. Also, the Erudites want to wipe out one group and then take over.

This is the first of a dystopian trilogy; similar in concept to "Hunger Games" in that the protagonists are youthful warriors. I haven't read the popular novels by Veronica Roth, so I don't know how faithful this portrayal is; but I do know I liked it. While it doesn't measure up to the depth of character development in "Hunger Games" or to the complex and intelligent story line, it is still an excellent sci/fi actioner, with superb performances by the two main protagonists; a fine support cast; and a good performance behind the camera by Neil Burger. The story takes place in a dystopian post-apocalyptic version of Chicago...how appropriate...where society is organized into five distinct factions based on personality types, each understanding and playing its role in order to maintain sociopolitical balance. These are Abnegation, Amity, Candor, Dauntless and Erudite, the names are rather self-explanatory. Youths are tested at the age of 16 and based on results, they pick one in which they choose to belong...for the rest of their lives. There is one other personality type, which you no doubt have guessed is "Divergent", which means the youth can fit into more than one faction. They must keep this secret, however, during their training period, or risk being destroyed. The two protagonists are Divergent, one a veteran leader in the Dauntless faction, Four, played by Theo James; and a new Dauntless initiate, Tris, played by Shailene Woodley. During her training period, Tris uncovers a sinister plot by one of the factions that will play havoc with their perfect society...watch the film to see how she handles this discovery. In addition to Woodley and James, look for Kate Winslet in the off-type role of a villain; and Ashley Judd as Tris' mother. If you like the "Hunger Games" concept, you should like this one...looking forward to the sequel.

A simple but important comment for film lovers who use the audio commentary feature. THIS WAS THE BEST directors comments  and explanations that I heard in a very long time . You will enjoy a simple explanation for each scene . No fancy jarganese or nonsensical anedotes. Little Tris (Shailene Woodley) is one of the deviants. She survives puberty with help of her mentor Four (Theo James). But will she still survive in a society that is making tad of an adjustment in leadership; will she gum up the works?

Whatever happens remember there are more movies to come as:
Insurgent (2015)
Allegiant: Part 1 (2016)
Allegiant: Part 2 (2017)

Each has the same leading characters.

The movie does start out a bit slow as it does take its time to tell the background and set up the main story which are like most movies that are set up to be a trilogy but if you hang on past the backstory that the movie must tell to get you involved, it ends up being worth watching.
Divergent tackles themes similar to Hunger games like should I conform or be an independent thinker, bravery and cowardice and the issues and angst of growing up with a less than perfect family or family expectations that are not your own.

Woodley, James, Judd and Winslet all play their roles well and Woodley and James have good onscreen chemistry with your typical onscreen romance midway through.  The movie does a good job with the action part of the movie without getting overly bloody or graphic, rare these days in an action sci-fi movie.

Let me start off by saying that I enjoyed this movie a great deal and look forward to a sequel (if one is planned).

However, I was puzzled by the basic premise.

Why would anyone think that separating people by occupation, interests, castes or class, in an already dystopian future  would work any better  than it does now, or has in the past?

Additionally, my interests now are quite different than they were as a teenager, or even a 40 year old.  The idea of basing one's entire life on a test administered and a choice made in the tumultous teen years seems rather ridiculous and doomed to failure.

With the flood of teen lit-inspired movies on the scene today, it can be all-too easy to unfairly shuffle them all under the same leaky roof. Often, that short-sells the more gleaming examples of the genre. Not so with Divergent, a ruthlessly narrow little bit of phony escapism that confirms every ugly stereotype. Dim and wooden, it's a thoroughly hand-holding bit of tack that can't seem to get over how breathlessly important it thinks it is. The generic core storyline has nothing to offer, over-familiar and rich with the scent of manufactured drama. Its cast, thin and transparent as they come, spends most of the bloated runtime reveling in their own majesty at the expense of actual character development. Not that the actors seem capable of exploring any such depth, were they given the material to work with. Shailene Woodley and Theo James, beautiful people without so much as a single spark between them, seem to have been chosen exclusively for their pouty appearances on the promotional materials. Likewise, an awkwardly mismatched sparkle-pop soundtrack stands at odds with the bleak, dystopian tones that the plot stretches for. At least the visual effects are well done, for what that's worth. It's a real waste of time and effort, an insulting vehicle to cash-in on the latest craze and promote a few of the parent company's tunes while they're at it. I wish I could get my two hours back.

This movie was so slow it was ridiculous, which is fitting because the premise is equally bad.  If believing the premise Hunger Games movie was a stretch of the imagination, this movie will require a lobotomy to be believable.  Basically, for unknown reasons the world has ended, and presumably the last civilization on earth is contained to New York city, which I would assume would be the first place to go in the event of the end of the world.

.A small group of survivors has broken themselves down into middle-ages style Indian Class system.  The main ones to be concerned about are the Abnegation, who govern things, the Erudite whom are their scientists and the Dauntless who are basically their military but act more like a gang straight out the Warriors.  We also have the classless which are people that belong to no group.  The Divergent on the other hand is someone who doesn't really belong to a class but can work in all classes.  Divergents are feared because they break down social order, but its a very irrational fear that makes absolutely no sense what so ever.  It seems pretty simple to just take a divergent and let them choose a class, but nope, the Erudites feel they have to be killed, for reasons that are never adequately explained.  Our two main characters are Tress, a divergent who leaves Abnegation for Dauntless, and Four, a trainer at Dauntless.

So the plot of the movie is basically the Erudites have decided to take over the city by mind controlling the Dauntless.  Simple quest for power should have been enough of a motivation for the reader/watcher, but instead the writers try to convince us that the Erudites just have misplaced good intentions because they believe the Abnegation are breaking down the social order.  Irony is of course lost on the Erudites because breaking down social order is exactly what they are doing.  For a group of people that are supposed to be the smart ones, they have a pretty stupid concept of social order.

I am getting ahead of myself here because none of the above actualy happens until the last 35 minutes of this 3 hour movie.  Our main Character is Tris, who is divergent but training among the Dauntless.  This is literally 2 1/2 hours of the movie.  Its not until the last 30 minutes or so do we learn the Erudites are trying to take over, and only after they mind control everyone.  Of course, this is when the flaws in the movie start.

1.  Divergents for reasons unknown are immune to the mind control.  No idea why, other than the watcher/reader is expected to accept this as fact.

2.  These people have some extremely advanced technology for a civilization limited to a few city blocks.  Where are they getting this technology with little to no resources?

3.  Somehow by taking a shot in the neck, and taping a wire to your temple, you can see a persons dreams.  Very specific dreams btw that are tailored to the individual class and fears.  No idea how this is done.  This of course can be accepted as fact within the confines of the story, but somehow by shooting someone else nearby with the same chemical allows them to enter the others head.  Okay, there is no wires linking them.  They aren't connected in anyway, but are somehow able to interact with each other.

4.  The brain control drug is an injection that makes people highly susceptible to suggestion.  The problem is that no one is given any suggestions.  A machine somehow remotely issues commands, but there is no link up, or means of transmission.  Furthermore, the interface is extremely complicated and makes no sense, but apparently it can be shut down with a few buttons that aren't labeled.  I thought the Erudites are supposed to be smart, but apparently they missed the lesson on User Interfaces when programming their machine. Later when the bad guy is injected with the serum, she is simply commanded to turn off the machine, but up until now, it was assumed it required the machine to issue the commands.  If voice suggestions works, wouldn't it be simple to just tell the Dauntless, "Don't shoot me."  It is also shown that the serum doesn't work if the subject is forced to go against their nature, which allowed the character Four to break its control.  It would be reasonable to assume that many of the Dauntless would have broken the control when ordered to murder children and other innocents.

5.  Tris and Four pretend to be mind control and when their cover is broken, they are given the opportunity to kill the bad guy leaders, but instead shoot one of them in the leg and run.  Of course they don't kill them, because that would end the movie prematurely.

6.  Too much tragedy.  For the final 30 minutes of the film, Tris's mother is killed, she then kills one of her friends, and then her father is killed.  The mother's death was traumatic enough, but after killing her friend and dad dying, I really stopped caring.  This made me feel like the director knew he spent too much time on Tres's training (2 hours), which in no way furthered the plot, and not was now rushing through the book that the movie is based on.

7.  After shutting down the brain machine, they are given yet another chance to kill the main bad guy, to which they don't.  This of course is forgivable, because there is nothing else to win, but they are forced to quickly flee before the rest of the co-conspirators arrive.  Rushing outside, they are quickly joined by the no longer mind controlled Dauntless at which point you'd think they'd work to restore order to the city.  Wrong.  Instead they jump on the first train out of town to the unknown beyond the city walls, abandoning the city completely.  They even take the  Abnegation leader who turns out to be Fours dad.  You'd think the guy would have some work to do being governor of the city, and Four would be needed to rally the Dauntless to restore order and arrest the conspirators, but nope, they just simply leave.

8.  It is explained that the classless are people that don't fit in to society, but it is later explained they are also made up of people that washed out of their chosen class, which seems to be an extremely high bar for the Dauntless who immediately cut anyone in the bottom 20%.  This seems to be a tremendous waste of resources as surely these people could be made to contribute elsewhere, like Sanitation or rebuilding the city, a function that doesn't seem to be a responsibility of any of the classes. For whatever reason, they aren't allowed to move to another class.  This makes even less sense when you consider that many of them grew up in classes not of their chosen.  Instead the classless are left to be a dependent, handed food, clothing and shelter by the other classes instead of being allowed to contribute to the society.

9.  There doesn't seem to be any old people.  Most everyone seems to be under the age of 35.  There is a select few people in the movie that appear to be in their mid-40s, but most everyone appears to be between the age of 20 and 30.  The Dauntless particularly have no old people.

In truth, this movie is only 30 minutes of plot, with 2 1/2 hours of scene setting.  An immensely implausible scene.  While the Hunger Games required the suspension of belief that a society would allow such an event, the society depicted in Divergent is completely non-functional and moronic.

One persons utopia is anothers dystopiaat least thats one takeaway you get from "Divergent," a futuristic action-drama thats fueled as much by its young stars as it is the writers mind. "Divergent" is pretty comparable to the "The Hunger Games," only instead of Jennifer Lawrence as an archer playing a futuristic survival game in the worlds largest arena we get Shailene Woodley as a free running initiate into a faction of a futuristic society thats charged with the task of protecting it from outsideand insidedangers.  Visually, there are some fun special effects and stunts, and the CGI post-apocalyptic Chicago is much more interesting than other landscapes weve seen. The whole point of "Hunger Games" was survival, but survival here is a by-product. The real issues are questions of identity and societal structure: family vs. society, knowing the self, having to make a decision that basically pigeonholes you for the rest of your life at a time when you DONT know yourself, and, of course, the theme of divergence"of having the inclination or desire to have more than one virtue or impulse. All of these are appealing to the target audience, even to other viewers who may wonder what constitutes an ideal society, given all the political turmoil in the worldFamilyHomeTheater.com

I just recently completed listening to all three books in the series on Audible.com

Movies are typically cut down from the book versions, but many stand well despite this.  The Green Mile is an excellent example of an adaptation that stayed fairly faithful to the book version with a few alterations that were not significantly missed (though one was).  But character relationships that translate to plot points that aren't translated to the movie might cause alterations of the plot that many will be disappointed by.

One example in this movie is the budding relationship between Christine and Will.  Gone in the movie, this will have an impact on Tris's killing Will.  Either the death will not cause Christine to hold a major grudge against Tris, or there will be that emotional conflict without a movie understanding of why.

The characters as individuals just don't have the same strong impact  in the movie that they do in the books.

Perhaps worthy of rent, but not really worthy of owning.

The trailers showed a rather ham-fisted "they don't like us 'cos we're different" story in the works. I wasn't too keen on another two-hour sermon written by teenagers.

But it was compelling, and it didn't feel overlong.

It's another take on Brave New World, but where you're given a choice where to belong. You may have to forsake your family if you switch clans (a creepy and nasty requirement).

Government is given to the Abnegation faction, which seems like a good idea. However, the "intellectual" crowd, led by Kate Winslet thinks that the smart people should obviously rule instead, and want to take over.

We generally enjoyed the movie. Even with its somewhat predictable turns, there were some interesting ideas (although the flag capture bit was oddly simpleminded).

But I had a problem empathizing with Tris. Shailene Woodley may have been good in other roles, but here there's something repellent about her. She seems cold, calculating, privileged, the Wonder Girl everyone is supposed to gape at. It's not that that here - she does get pummeled and such - but that's the vibe she gives off. I just didn't like her for most of the movie.

Viewers may be confused by the movie's message. On the one hand it's another tiresome sermon on being different. On the other hand, it's about the dangers of the self-styled "intellectuals" wanting to be in charge - which may be seen as a criticism of the current administration, and of socialist fascism in general, where government controls everything. When you see Kate Winslet's character, you immediately think "Hillary", which I did not expect for such a movie. It will certainly offend her supporters, if they realize this.

Had it been made with some more originality - or ten or more years earlier perhaps - "Divergent" would have received more positive reviews. Everything in this sci-fi fantasy action (based on Veronica Roth books) is so familiar, especially for those who have seen "The Hunger Games" and other young adult themed films, that you can almost predict what is happening next.

The story takes place in a post-apocalyptic Chicago, where the entire population is divided into five factions based on their dispositions. Shailene Woodley ("The Descendants") is Beatrice Prior, 16-year-old daughter of an "Abnegation" family, who decides to be "Dauntless" at the Choosing Ceremony.

We don't know why she should choose that group whose sole interest seems to be doing parkour. That doesn't matter; the point is, renamed as "Tris," she struggles to survive the tests, and finds herself slowly attracted to the mysterious instructor Four (Theo James).

Directed by Neil Burger ("The Illusionist" "Limitless"), "Divergent" is 140 minutes of very average fun. The lead players are both very good, but the concept of "Divergent," those who can think independently, is not fully explored. I hope the studio will come up with new ideas that are more interesting for the planned sequels.

Truly 3.5 stars. I did not read the book. This movie reminded me of The Hunger Games since its youth face huge challenges early in life that have lethal consequences.

The people of the world in the future have specific roles that are classified into five types - Abnegation (selfless), Erudite (Intelligent), Dauntless (Brave), Amity (The Peaceful), and Candor (The Honest).  Children participate in the faction to which they are born but when they reach age 16, after taking an aptitude test, they choose the faction that they will serve for the remainder of their lives, during an annual ceremony. Decisions are irreversible and if the teens choose a faction different from the one they were born into, they must leave their families to reside with their new faction.

The female protagonist is Beatrice/Tris (Shailene Woodley).  She was born to the Abnegation faction (not allowed to view themselves in a mirror for very long to discourage vanity and dresses in modest dresses of muted grey) with female long hair kept to a certain length and drawn back into a bun). This faction serves others particularly the homeless and hungry masses who have no faction (factionless). Beatrice and her brother choose a faction and realize that all is not what it seems behind the scenes in the factions and in the world.  There is a love match for Beatrice with a man in her faction that presents great challenges for both of them.

The book/movie's name is derived from a group of people whose aptitude test results are inconclusive. These people are known as Divergent. They can control their fear and so realize that their testing scenario (hallucination) is not real and alter the manner in which they resolve perilous challenges within the testing matrix. Divergents are usually killed since their brains are different and allow them to take risks (in real life) and they are therefore considered to be dangerous. They are impervious to mind control.

I did not engage with the female protagonist's character since she seemed to be one-dimensional. I did not feel as though I knew her at all so the movie failed to portray her character with enough depth and I, therefore, could not empathize adequately with her. The romance between Beatrice and her man lacked heat so the bond between them seemed contrived and strained. Perhaps the reason for this was that the target audience was too young for much else (movie rating).  Perhaps viewers who had read the book were more invested.  I would not watch this movie again.

It's ok.  I felt that it could have been MUCH better. They had a solid plot to work with. They had a stellar cast. Aside from a few moments where you felt emotionally invested, the movie kept a steady and somewhat flat heart-beat.

I felt that they did not spend enough time on character development. We went through the movie barely knowing anything about any of the characters.  I did not feel invested in their struggle at all.

And the main female lead was so under-whelming that I was wondering when she was going to STOP getting her butt kicked every time they showed her "training".

Basically the show jumps from one concept to the next, without fully developing the first.  For example, at the end of the movie I was still wondering what the hell was special about a Divergent, since even the "peaceful" guys that were supposed to be unable to change or have free will picked up guns and fought at the end.  Hrmm  kind of a major plot hole, writers.

Wow.  This is the most boring movie I've ever seen.  In the future everyone has a "faction" which is essentially their job.  Each faction represents a different aspect of society: academics, the military, charity, etc.  A "divergent" is someone who doesn't fit into a particular category based on an arbitrary test.  Other than said test there really is absolutely no explanation as to why we (or the world's characters) should be interested in divergents.  It isn't clear how this society is so oppressive.  Oh no... you have to have a job when you grow up?  This is like a story about the tyranny of a personality test.  It is silly.  The story itself is a long plodding training movie, with the main character joining a military faction.  The action isn't good.  There is a cheesy romance stuffed in that doesn't serve the story in any way.  This is just a bad, bad movie.

I was reading some of the 5 star reviews.  What I noticed either you have read the book(magic being brought to life),or your a 13 year old girl.  Seems like I would recommend this to either of those 2 cases.  Anyone else go watch equilibrium for near the same plot line, but with good acting, and a much better execution of the storyline.

This was sooo much better than the books.  First of all the movie is complete.  The movie takes the best part of all three books and places all of the best parts into the movie.  All of the slow, boring parts are removed.  The parts that I hated have been changed.  The story was changed to remove the parts I did not like.  And best of all for those of us who hated the final book, the movie has changed that book in every way.

This movie was fast paced.  It was exciting, and it ended in a satisfying way.  This is what the books should have been, but they were not.

For those of you who never read the books, I advise that you do not.  They will be a total disappointment next to this movie.

The background
Classically, after a huge event like a global war, a new order has risen.
Now, in fence protected Chicago five factions exist, based on their virtues.
Abnegation the selfless, Amity the peaceful, Candor the honest, Dauntless the brave,
and Erudite the intelligent. And of course there are those that do not fit any of those,
the faction less, the place that everyone dreads to be.

The plot
At the age 16, all young people go through a selection process that is based on a serum,
in order to see in which faction they should belong too (kind like the Shorting Hat in Hogwarts).
Beatrice Prior (Shailene Woodley, "The Descendants") goes in to have the test, but there
in no definite conclusions, and she shows traits from various factions. She is a divergent!
She eventually chooses the Dauntless and goes into training where eventually she does great,
because we already know that there is something special about her. And this will only
bring about problems, since divergents are hunted down by the rulers.
Add to that that the Erudite want to overthrow the Abnegation from ruling,
and we finally have some real plots in the movie other than training.

The story is based on the books by Veronica Roth, and of course it is a trilogy, a Hollywood
fashion in these past year.
Of course it is a rival series to the Hunger Games, and , but I am not sure that Woodley would
like to have the same fate as Jennifer Lawrence.
Still, it is a good futuristic sci fi movie, despite the girly feelings and stuff
It is an action movie and that is what you should expect, although the 2 hours plus duration is a little too much.

In IMDB they gave a 7.4 rating and in Rotten Tomatoes a 5.4, if you are interested in such things

I don't see how anyone who loves the books can enjoy this movie. I saw it in theaters and almost left as the number of inconsistencies increased and, in my opinion, key points were changed or left out completely. I stayed hoping it'd get better... I should have asked for a refund. I have seen tons of movies (probably averaging one a week for the past 10 years) including book-to-film adaptations, and I am not so impractical as to think that it would be possible to match the book exactly. But I was so surprisingly, incredibly impressed with the book that the movie version crashed and burned infinitely harder than anything the Dauntless could dream of. The Dauntless themselves were mild versions of the book descriptions. Hard for 90% of the people, even just those in the background, to look pretty with the extreme hair, tattoos and piercings depicted in the book. But that's typical Hollywood, especially for a film with teen romance. But in my opinion that doesn't excuse Eric missing half his piercings which the book repeatedly gave detailed descriptions of. And speaking of tattoos, of course they had to change Four's... The ending was the worst - COMPLETELY different from the book, and I can't fathom why. To me, the specifics there were very significant to the story as a whole; it seemed very important the way it happened in the book. The changes to some of the fear landscapes were almost as bad. But I won't go into detail and give spoilers. My curiosity got the better of me, but I wish I had skipped the movie and not tainted the amazing universe and story that Roth created purely with words.

My conclusion is you might like it for two reasons: 1. If you haven't read the book, you might like it if you can catch the wisps of what the book contained (the psychology). But if you think it's good, you're better off treating yourself to the book. 2. If you're looking for a dystopian teen love story, probably while suffering Twilight withdrawals, this might hold you over for a bit. (And if you saw "Fault in Our Stars" and think Shailene Woodle can carry this movie, don't hold your breath.)

2/5 stars because 1 star is reserved for only those purely bad movies, and as I said this has wisps of what makes the book so great. And because by definition, an adaptation is not an exact replica. It should have tried harder to be, though.

It was a great adaptation of the book.  However, I thought it jumped around a lot and didn't follow the same "path" as the book did. It didn't showcase the love story between Four and Tris as the book did, I think the movie was lacking a little because of that.  If you never read the book the movie would be great.  But like so many other book to movie adaptations the book is still just a little bit better.  All in all the movie was great.  It will be something that I will watch over and over.

Like the book the entire premise was written for young girls through the eyes of how a young girl would view life. In this post-war scenario a walled-in city is populated by a caste system. Upon reaching a certain age, a person must choose which caste to belong to. Usually, by that age, they are predisposed fairly strong towards one of the castes. Those who are not, but who enter a caste anyway are called Divergents and they are seen as pariahs whenever identified. One particular female is a Divergent who chooses the warrior caste at which point she goes into training.

Well acted, with a pretty good story, it enters the dystopia genre. My daughter, however, had a fit because she stated that the movie was not totally faithful to the book.

And here we go, another YA novel adapted into a film. They never seem to slow down. After the major successes of 'Harry Potter' and 'Twilight', they did a test run with 'The Hunger Games'. And after that film became a huge success, other studios decided to test their strengths at making young adult novels into films, creating the likes of several disasters including that of 'The Host', and 'The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones' as well as several mediocre yet not completely tasteless films such as 'Beautiful Creatures' and 'Enders Game'. They never seem to slow down. Even when those four films flopped completely, studios still went on thinking they could make that next 'Hunger Games' or 'Twilight'. And after another flop this year with 'Vampire Academy' they finally did. And that success is 'Divergent'. A film that is very much similar to the other adaption's yet somewhat better. Not that better in narrative but in a few other traits. My review of 'Divergent'.

In 'Divergent', a post-apocalypse setting, Beatrice Prior (Played By 'Spectacular Now' star Shailene Woodley) must decide what she wants to do with her life. At a certain age, she and others her age, must choose one of five fractions (sorta like the 'districts' in The Hunger Games) based on their personality traits, to live in the rest of their lives. Learning she is Divergent (Divergence, is in which the person doesn't fit into one faction) Beatrice decides on Dauntless, people who guard the city, and protect the fractions. Leaving her family behind, Beatrice, now called Tris, must survive the initiation process, and try to mask her divergence, or risk being killed at the hands of the cruel Erudite leader Jeanine (Played by Kate Winslet).

A simple plot formula which is used in almost every other YA film adaption. Director 'Neil Burger' doesn't try to expand the interesting world, and try to make something different of the idea. As my father said 'It plays out like Hunger Games'. It does, nothing about it comes out as unique of any kind. You would think with almost 2 and a half hours, you would be able to do a little with the idea, but no, instead we are bombarded with plenty of tests. Which is ok, they were fun enough to watch and showed Tris slowly evolve from a weak and hopeless girl, to a strong and radiant woman.

The plain and predictable plot isn't so hard to sit through when you get the likes of a formidable cast, who dauntlessly (As the characters would say) fought the formula with their talents. 'Shailene Woodley' plays the lead with ease. She is easily believable, and is good eye candy for the audience. Her strengths and weaknesses are portrayed realistically on screen, and she projects a glow whenever she's on screen. Surprisingly, her co-lead 'Theo James' does a better than expected performance as Tris's mentor and future lover. He isn't as useless as you'd expect a male co-star in a YA adaption to be. He plays out more than your average heartthrob. Being there to do more than make out with the lead, and say romantic wooden dialogue. He holds his own and has great chemistry with Woodley. Other than them, the rest of the cast doesn't have much time to shine. 'Miles Teller' does fine, and 'Kate Winslet' plays a civilized villain in a more miner role.

It's too bad that the actors didn't have much stronger characters. Other than Tris and Four, the other characters are lifeless. They are just there. Tris's trio of friends include the suicidal Al, the smarty Will, and the tough as nails Christina. They are all the shallowest characters I have ever seen. None of the three get more than 10 minutes of screen time each. Barely, and that's not even of them speaking, mostly of them just standing there watching events or whatever they do. It's too bad, they had time to improve and become more solid then they had become. I mean, again with an almost 2 and a half hour film, why not spend a little bit more on character development and a little less on constant action. I mean it was fun, but I'd liked more than to characters to leave an impact on me. Peter, the bully, is known at the end as a bully, for no reason whatsoever. I know he's not the main character but why not give him a more clear reason to be such a jackass jerk. And Al, one of Tris's friends, why'd he turn on her? Just because he could? He had to have a reason to do so, so why not explain it. Take a dang moment and explain why. Why?! Gosh darn it; don't slack off on your characters just to satisfy your action hungry hearts.

With a modest 80 million budget, you would expect the film to make good use of it, visually. And they do, the visuals look crisp and clean. And with most of the budget going towards marketing, the film had even less money to use on visuals and I believe they succeeded in making better than average effects. Let's take the City of Chicago for instantance. It looks dystopian and futuristic. The buildings and houses look dystopian, ok, I'll admit some of that want toward good sets but most of the touch ups used to really make the city look the dystopian setting was due to visual effects. Some of the visual effects look abit rough then others but in the end it works fine.

A particularly interesting scene was involving a zip line. I felt the angles and shooting worked perfectly well for the scene. The camera work, was just fine, shooting different angles, that show all the necessary details and action, and that is good.

What bothers me was the rough editing. The film is quick paced, which makes for a pretty fun joy ride, but the editing kind of upsets the fun. Cutting crude, and quickly from one shot to the next, and it kind of hearts your eyes. It's not even small edit mistakes, it's pretty big ones. You're at one area and then at another, and back to the same area, and it just doesn't flow with the pacing. It's alittle too much. The pacing makes the film out to be a fast roller coaster, but with the editing, it became a bumpy roller coaster. And not for the best.

The script includes some moments of pure intellect, but is quickly turned off by some pretty bland instances of wooden dialogue. I mean, the dialogue was in no means cringe worthy, but somewhat tasteless and seemed filled with too many of the same words and phrases. Nothing that makes you think hard, all just one liners.

The costumes are pretty to the point, and in the simplest form, but what makes them stand out, are the slight changes that you see to differentiate each fraction from each other. The costumes define each fraction. Let's take for instance, the Abnegation fraction and the Dauntless Fraction. The Abnegation fraction members wear heavy layers of simple grey clothing. And the Dauntless members wear tight, showy, black clothing. When looked up, the color black means protection. Which in fact defines the jobs of the Dauntless. They are the guards, the protectors of the city.

All and All, 'Divergent' doesn't add anything to the YA adaption genre (yes, it now qualifies as a genre) in plot points, which weakens the film as a whole, but the sold cast and visuals make up for that, not by much but they fix the predictable formula and the shallow characters at least enough to make this film sit - through able. C 3/24/14

P.S: Let's see if the other YA adaption's to be released this year can succeed in accomplishing what 'Divergent' did, or even better, be better then 'Divergent' was. That would include 'The Maze Runner' and 'The Giver' both scheduled for late summer and early fall releases. Until then, we can only hope they do more to the characters then simple have them there, and add a twist or two that don't follow the genre's own playbook.
