Based loosely on Huxley's classic Brave New World, a young lady has to deal with her not fitting neatly into any of the 5 castes (called "factions") in her post-apocalyptic society.  She finally settles on an elite police force, only to find herself enmeshed in local politics.

The movie has the potential to be a sci-fi classic, but the too much over-the-top action gets in the way of character development.  For adventure fans only.

I have seen this movie at the cinema and liked it because it has a lot of implied messages and symbolic meaning. It is based on the best-seller by a talented young author.
Characters are portrayed vividly and quite realistically, whereas the plot follows a natural time frame.
Presumably the main issue revolves around the conflict between family/'blood' and 'faction'/professional life. In other words, personal feelings versus expected blind following of imposed commands.
The female protagonist is shown as rapidly evolving and growing up, thus becoming very strong in every sense, positive and conscientious, seeking the benefit of all people, that is, all 'factions' in society. Something which 'evil' people in authority (especially the heroine represented and played by Kate Winslet) would definitely not like. They would not like the idea of 'thinking' people who do not belong to a certain faction only till the rest of their lives, i.e. divergent ones.
In fact, the story is about the struggle of such people that want to defend their human right to existence in modern and/or future society. Actually, there are some powerful references to past dictatorial regimes as well as good warning messages for the future of humankind in general.
I went to see this movie with my girlfriend, she made me go, but I ended up liking it enough that I started reading the series. Great series also!!

Whats it about?

Set in a post-apocalyptic world where humans are divided into factions based on their personality, we follow a young girl who shows signs of having all five qualities in equal abundance.

What did I think?

Written by a youth for youths, the original storyline  while intriguing  is excessively black and white. As such the movie is a little clumsy and heavy handed in places. However having said that it is actually quite enjoyable and good escapism. Gritty enough to keep you interested and entertained. I took a friend who hadn't read the book and she really enjoyed it. It has action, adventure and romance so she came out of the viewing buzzing. Fun but it won't exactly stick in the memory. Well, not until the sequel next year.

In many ways, "Divergent" has the familiar trappings of a romantic fantasy picture - the shy, feckless girl swoons over the handsome, distant alpha male and both fall head over heels for each other. But the mold is broken by the plot, which has the girl go through a series of basic training tasks to join a futuristic marine corps. The tasks include fighting her recruits, jumping onto rooftops from moving trains and taking a hallucinogenic drug that simulates dangerous situations. I can't imagine why any of this would appeal to a teenage girl. Do young women really fantasize about going through basic training? It's like someone crossed the plot of "GI Jane" with a romance novel. The best way to characterize "Divergent" is a feminist spin on teen romance pictures. The girl gets the handsome guy, but she also has to prove herself in a masculine way. To succeed in Dauntless (the name of the marine corps-like clan the main character joins), she has to display masculine qualities like strength, bravery, and marksmanship.

The movie propagates the feminist lie that men and women are the same except for their reproductive organs. In just about every scene, you see as many women in Dauntless as men. But when you see what the recruits have to go through to join Dauntless, you realize that few, if any, women would make the cut. There are physical and psychological differences between the sexes that would skew the difference lopsidedly in favor of men. In one scene, the film breaks from feminist non-reality when the girl is beaten senseless by a muscular young man in a test of hand-to-hand combat. All of this happens while the drill sergeants watch on. Why would they encourage her to fight a man, as if she stood a chance against him? Either the drill sergeants are sadists, or they're woefully ignorant of human physiology.

I don't know who this film is made for. It's like a cross between a teen romance picture, Full Metal Jacket and Logan's Run. Apparently this is what appeals to teenage girls now.

Amazing doesn't even begin to describe it. Divergent is the best movie ever and it is a sin not to watch it. The book is also amazing. Every time Tobias was on the screen I cried. It is the best movie ever made!!!!!

There is no shortage of young adult novels that encourage the individual and warn against conformity; Divergent is one such novel. However, the film based on the massively popular Veronica Roth novel ignores those lessons and aims to have absolutely no originality or individuality from its acting right down to its execution.

The film opens a la Twilight with a brief and information-rich voice-over that gives us the low-down on a dystopian and futuristic Chicago. Society has been segmented into five personality-based factions: Erudite, Dauntless, Amity, Candor, and Abnegation from which our heroine Beatrice Prior (Shailene Woodley) hails. At the age of 16, Beatrice, later known as Tris, must take an aptitude test, which all young people must take in order to discover which faction they would be most apt to join. The test results in a recommendation, but it is ultimately the decision of each individual to select the faction they want to join. The catch is that once a person selects a faction, there is no going back and a rigid training session begins that if not passed results in that persons dismissal and the shameful label of being factionless.

After Triss aptitude test comes back inconclusive, she resolves to join the Dauntless faction, dedicated to fearlessness and bravery. If this process sounds similar to another YA novels categorization element, thats because it is absurdly similar to the sorting ceremony in J.K Rowlings Harry Potter series. Harry Potters uniqueness is a cause for one particular recommendation by the sorting hat in The Sorcerers Stone, yet he disregards it to declare his allegiance to another house. Triss inconclusive test is actually code for her being a unique anomaly within society called a Divergent. Simply put, this means that her aptitude is not wholly within one faction but a combination of them all.

The films opening act is relatively interesting and does a passable job of explaining the world these characters inhabit. The problem is that there is not enough newness to this story and while the film is just another adaptation of another beloved young adult novel, that doesnt mean it shouldnt be held to the same originality standards as any other genre. Furthermore, once the Tris enters the world of the Dauntless, a whole new bag of issues emerges that sink the film even farther.

Most of the film from this point forward is an excruciatingly long and played out training set-up piece for a lackluster climactic finish. Triss struggles at Dauntless are pitted against her secret identify as a Divergent. Will she be discovered? Are there other Divergents? Will she hook up with the hunky I don't want to be just one thing, Four (Theo James)? These questions will be answered, just don't hold your breath. The film gets so caught up in its own mythology, that it never really even considers convincing the audience why these Divergents are so dangerous. Divergents are people who can think for themselves and have multiple skills and talents. It becomes increasingly clear why Erudite faction leader Jeanine Matthews (Kate Winslet) is not fond of Divergents, but why does the rest of society view them as dangerous? A few tacked on lines of dialogue towards the end attempt to answer this, but not to any satisfaction.

A few words about Shailene Woodley. She has emerged on the scene with great success in films like The Descendants and The Spectacular Now. In Divergent, Woodleys performance is quite bland and well, wooden. She broods, she emotes with deep and hyperventalative breathing, she conveys confusion at the right times, but she never quite achieves a connection with the audience worth rooting for. Director Neil Burger is at least partly responsible for this flavorless and wishy-washy performance. His direction involves running back to the well of successful YA novel adaptations and hand picking the qualities he thought worked in other places. Woodley gives a very controlled performance and unfortunately the one in control is a strong candidate for being factionless!  D+

Divergent is rated PG-13 and has a running time of 2 hours and 20 minutes.

I was a little put off when Lana arrived at the Planet Punani in the Rektoom system. She seemed so innocent especially when all she wanted was some cream pie--I guess, who wouldn't? But it was down hill from there with everyone running about and trying to save the pinkish buttons on the top of the Nipp Hills. What was the danger? I could see being put off by the cave between the mounds where mysterious sounds emitted. But ultimately, when she got used to it, she couldn't wait to invite others in. Maybe I'm too young to understand the fuss.

Given that this was geared specifically toward the YA market - I'd say this was not bad. A great war has left Chicago as the only known civilized city left on the planet. Walled off from unseen enemies, society has rebuilt itself along five castes - or 'factions' as writer Veronica Roth defines them. Each faction representing the distilled prime qualities of humanity - Kindness, Logic, Honesty, Bravery, and Peacemaker. As each young person reaches their late teens, a neural psych test is given - revealing the inner essence of their strongest quality. Life after that point is a choice of Faction. Choose one and you're forever bonded to them - one can never go back and one can never choose again. The story opens with Beatrice, daughter to a pair of followers of Abnegation, representing the generosity found within humanity. Their lives are devoid of ego. Their purpose in life to serve those who fell through the cracks - people who are without a faction; essentially caring for the homeless, family-less, and downtrodden. Interestingly, they have also been chosen as the leaders of the city. It's their gentle touch that insures society never again repeats the mistakes of the past. Think Amish. Beatrice and her brother are about to embark on their life journey as their Selection Day is finally at hand. Their parents, who have devoted their lives to humility and charity, believe they have instilled in their children the right qualities to also choose Abnegation. It comes as an ice cold bath to watch each child select something completely different. Their son opts for the cold logical world of science - Erudite. And Beatrice? Out of nowhere she chooses to become a warrior and selects Dauntless. Each child abandoning their parent's core beliefs and even their parents themselves. But unbeknownst to the greater population - a secret and deadly struggle is underway. One that will make everyone's choice moot if the dark powers behind the movement succeed in their twisted plan. Was the plot routine? Yeah. The acting? Sufficient with moments of excellence. The filmmakers put together a tight enough weave that kept the various threads from spiraling out of focus. My experience with the resurgent 'HG' franchise has shown that some executive producers can indeed right an unsteady ship by having adjusted the problems of a mediocre first film. Am a fan of young Shailene Woodley - have been since the incredible film 'The Descendants'. But I'm not entirely sold on her portrayal as Tris. Again, it wasn't bad. But there was a noticeable lack of depth to her character. I attribute that to the uninspired plot, a script which really doesn't offer strong word play, and in my opinion, a surprising lack of firmer direction from Neil Burger. Still, I'm hopeful. For this initial effort - a very solid 3 stars. Personal Note: - The basic concept that author Veronica Roth writes about - of choosing a life away from one's family, completely cutting them off in favor of some idealized social group, is actually pretty creepy. Very much the means by which cults and gangs recruit and control their "believers". Again - creepy.

The movie keeps the viewer interested and wanting more. However, It seems that in every scene there is something different from the book. Some things minor details but others I feel were crucial to the story line. I was disappointed in the lack of the back storyline, you didn't get to know any of the other characters besides Tris and Four. Not sure if i would have understood the movie if I hadn't read the book. If you are expecting to see a movie that is an exact match or in close proximity to the book, don't get your hopes up with this one.
This movie was amazing!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! The actors were perfect and I thought it followed the book closely. Anyone who hasn't seen it should go see it!

This film, is, of course, based on the book trilogy of the same name. I have not read the book, so I did not come to the film with expectations of seeing the 'book of the movie". taking place in a post-apocalyptic world, the survivors have created a society in which the population has been divided into separate groups based upon their dominent personality types (think a super MBPI). Each group has been assigned a role in society based upon their testing at adulthood. The film was interesting and held my interest in trying to determine what the significance was of being classified as 'divergent".  It bore some similarity to the Hunger Games in  ways but different enough to be enjoyable. I look forward to the next  installment.

So many film producers throw their money at post apocalyptic themes these days because that's where the money seems get the most return. So sad in a way because part of our culture is preparing for such a scenario and self fulfilling prophecy... yada...yada.... Ok, that said, the premise of the writer's vision is quite interesting. Basically, 'You are innately good at this, you belong in this particular group' and this other group of people based on their personalities and abilities are in another. Later what follows is that egos of human nature sometimes get inflated and want to act out. "My utopic vision is better than yours.". What I have grown tired of is these many types of stories, at least played out on screen is the 'fight, kill, domination...' idea of obtaining a better society.
What I feel would make a more refreshing story line in this particular film is to see the various factions actually succeeding on various levels and then later at the end to illustrate that utopia will always be elusive and ultimately an illusion, time permitting.

Not as much fun as Hunger Games (at least for me) but a whole lot better than the lame trailer promised. Shailene Woodley is a pretty talented actress, but she's not an action heroine.

I waited a few weeks after the movie's release in theaters to avoid the swarm of opening week(end). Before seeing it, I had not read the book. I remember coming across the book while searching for something to read a few times, but couldn't remember why I'd decided against it. So after seeing the trailers, I decided to give it a chance. And I'm glad I did. I thought everyone involved in the project did great.

After seeing the movie, I decided to read the book - compare and contrast the two mediums. Honestly, I think the movie is much better. The screenwriter took the book story's potential and fleshed it out on the screen. The dialogue was tighter and better written in the movie, and Tris didn't come across as judgmental and rather selfish as she did in the book. She seemed to form a real friendship with Christina and Will in the movie, where in the book she viewed them more as competition and didn't seem to care about them. The characters came across more realistic than they did in the book.

I thought Shailene Woodley did very well in portraying Tris, the main character. And Theo James also did very well in bringing Four's mysterious & dangerous presence to the screen. Their chemistry was evident. Kate Winslet was a great choice to play Jeanine, the main antagonist. Jai Courtney and Miles Teller were great for the two mini-antagonists Tris encounters during her training.

A lot of people complain that Divergent isn't original. So what? Every story in some way shares a similarity with at least one other story. What's the saying? Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.

Is the movie perfect? No. But there are plenty of movies out there that are far worse.

I haven't read any of the books in the Divergent series, so I went in blind. Everyone was comparing it to the Hunger Games - but honestly, Tris isn't nor will she ever be Katniss. Anyways! I thought I was going to really hate it but I was pleasantly surprised to find it was a really good. The acting had it moments but the love story was great and the progression of Four and Tris were perfect. It wasn't rushed, no swooning - thank goodness. I think Shailene Woodley was a wonderful leading lady and her acting has improved since the Secret Life of an American Teenager. So thumbs up to you Shailene. I did buy the book immediately afterwards though. Hopefully, there will be other movies. So all in all, a definite buy.

The movie Divergent stole story lines, artwork, caricatures, plots, design ideas, photo poses, design layout, marketing, and main characters from not only Hunger Games but from some of the most popular young-adult fiction of the last 20 years.  They spun  it and flipped them, and then crammed it all down our throats.
The film based on the novel by Veronica Roth  never explains its premise and rips off far too many better books, stories and movies. Trying to desperately compete with the popularity of the Hunger Games, the Liberal Media and the Hollywood Elite has produced a mirror image of themselves.  People that can not produce a original or creative idea if their lives depended on it. They can only produce stolen goods. This is more that a movie audience should be forced to tolerate.

There is a aptitude test game involved.  The test is to see if media propaganda and  $50 million spent on advertising, marketing and brainwashing for the Divergent movie is adequate enough to make the viewing audience dumb enough to spend money on rubbish.  At the same time they want us to pretend that Jennifer Lawrence in the Hunger Games does not exist.  Or, maybe Suzanne Collins stole all her ideas from Veronica Roth?  See, to consider that is not even believable,  and neither is this.

In the future, after an unnamed war, Brave New World Chicago becomes a walled city nation. There are 5 factions or work groups in this tiered society. People can choose which one they want to be in, after they go through a Sorting Hat test. Beatrice Prior (Shailene Woodley) discovers she is a "divergent" i.e. someone who doesn't neatly fit into any group. Bummer about the DNA. Divergents are hunted and killed.

Beatrice hides this fact and joins a group of muscle headed protectors, changes her name to Tris and gets a tattoo. She enters a unisex "Starship Troopers" dorm where she will train and either make the grade or get cut and join the factionless beggars. Much of the film centers around her training and of course she meets a boy (Theo James) who helps her along the way until things go awry.

The production steals from a number of different pop culture iconic films/books. At times it was groan worthy. Having said that, I did enjoy the film, even while groaning through so many scenes. This was clearly aimed at teens, especially teen girls.

The film is worth seeing as a wannabe iconic production.

Trailer first... So I first saw the for "Divergent" when I took my friend to see "Vampire Academy" and we both agreed that it looked like it would be a fun movie to watch; it came out on my birthday. At the time I hadn't read the book about five days before the movie came out I received the book as an early birthday gift... and I was even more excited to see how this entertaining book was going to be adapted into a movie. Then I saw the movie and my lasting impression of it was: choppy. Overall it's okay, but choppy... not as bad as "The Last Airbender" adaption, but not as the "Holes" adaption.

This reviewer missed the book series this movie is based on, showed up with no expectations, and really enjoyed the movie. "Divergent" is a syfi thriller set in a post-Apocalyptic Chicago, where the population has been divided into five factions based on personality type. Teenagers are given an aptitude test before picking their lifetime faction. Failure to pick a faction, or failure to stay in one, dooms a person to a marginal existence.

The heroine is young Beatrice Prior, raised in the Abnegation faction, whose aptitude test is strangely inconclusive. When her time comes, she breaks from her parents to join the Dauntless faction of warriors. Boot camp for the Dauntless is quite challenging, but Beatrice, who now calls herself Tris, gets a helping hand from her handsome instructor Four, who has secrets of his own. Tris' rite of passage is a suspenseful and entertaining story all by itself, but there is more to come. Tris becomes aware of a secret plan by one of the factions to take over Chicago, a plan that involves wiping out another faction. She will find unexpected allies in her race against the clock to stop the slaughter of the innocent...

The movie runs two and a half hours, but some of this is required to set up the storyline. The cast is well-chosen, especially Shailene Woodley as the independent-minded Beatrice/Tris, and Theo James as the stoic and mysterious Four. Kate Winslet has an intriguing role as head of the Erudite faction, who takes an interest in Tris. If the plot isn't all that original, the story is well-told, with lots of action and even some food for thought about how people manage fear and how societies manage individuality. The ending begs for a sequel. Well recommended.

I never read the books so I did not really care about the book-to-film accuracy. I did enjoy it and thought the story was intriguing for the most part. I saw many similarities between this and the Hunger Games, one of the obvious was the totalitarian government. This is just me, but I am noticing that the totalitarian government/dystopian society are becoming common elements in books/films.

The fight scenes for the most part were entertaining. The training for dauntless was neat, and if anyone had seen Starship Troopers they will see a similarity in the training.  One of the disappointments I had with this film is the predictability of scenes. I know it not a real thinking moving, but we should not be able to tell what will happen for most of the film.

Overall the film was enjoyable and I will purchase it along with see the next two films. I give this film a 7.5/10 which is just a bit lower than what I gave the Hunger Games, 8/10. If the story gets better the next films will score higher.
I'm  ready to have Divergent in my hands. This movie is AMAZING. I looked forward to having this movie in my hands.

Let's examine this without providing any Divergent (DV) spoilers... First, why compare it to The Hunger Games (HG)? It is difficult not to. Both are post-apocalyptic, take place in dystopias, ultimately embody the same messages, and target primarily the same viewership age. As a side note, I find it somewhat hopeful (rather than pessimistic) that the popular YA novels these films are based upon are set in these circumstances; it provides the opportunity for critical thinking about what our society should become, or more importantly, not become. Anyway, on to the contrasting... Action If action is what you want, you'll get it in DV, although you'll need to be patient. DV isn't an action film per se, so if action is what floats your boat, maybe consider another movie. The Hunger Games had some intense fight-to-the-death scenes, but Divergent wins in the action category. Emotional impact Whereas HG tugs at your heartstrings with the death of Rue, DV somehow just didn't pull this off. Sure, people important to the protagonist are killed off in DV, but there was no parallel to the spreading flowers over Rue's body that worked so well in HG. Divergent does have more feel-good moments than HG, as when our heroine passes her many tests and wins her many battles. Overall though, The Hunger Games wins in the emotional impact category. Plot The first hour is not all that impressive. It starts to come together after that (DV is a long film at 139 minutes; oddly enough, HG is almost exactly the same duration). They do an acceptable job of keeping you guessing about who is wearing a white hat and who a black hat, which is one reason the 2nd hour is more engrossing. It is difficult to tell from either film which underground movement (against the powers that be) is stronger. The resistance in DV seems weaker (as only a tiny percent of the population is divergent), but neither film goes into enough detail about this. I guess that's part of the problem with doing trilogy films based on books: we can hope more will be revealed later, but they may not be able to squeeze it in. If you are looking for a love story, DV will be your cup of tea. The central theme of HG was very creative, but ultimately the plot of DV is just more complex (and thus more engaging, at least for me). Despite its teen vibe and the unshakable notion that I've witnessed most elements of it in numerous sci-fi productions, Divergent wins. Actors Divergent did okay with casting, but HG did better. I have the benefit of being able to judge this without the bias of having read either of these YA novels. Jennifer Lawrence (HG) is difficult to beat as the central character, but Shailene Woodley (DV) also excels in her role as the girl who didn't ask to be a hero. It's practically a toss-up between the two films when taking into consideration all of the major and minor roles, but the caliber of actors seems to me superior in HG. Cinematography HG arguably had the better cinematography. DV did okay in its sets and locations, but the CGI distracted from the story at times. Urge to see next in the series I saw the sequel to HG as soon as possible, but I have to say I am looking forward more to the DV sequel due to the plot possibilities. HG feels limited as to where it can go, being based around the games. So, which film is "better"? That depends on what you want out of a film. If you are looking for an exact reproduction of the books on screen, then I have no idea. In the end it doesn't really matter which is better, since both films are worth watching. I rate them at 3.5 or 4 stars, with Hunger Games being marginally preferred.

Not that that's a bad thing, especially since this and recent like it have been very well done (*). The dystopic society has been split into five "factions," apparently forgetting just how badly that "separate but equal" thing has worked in our world. This system has built-in tensions, as one faction has control of the government, but a second faction takes control of the military, which itself is another faction. That all plays out well enough and, without the frustration of real cliff-hanger, paves the way for a sequel. Then there are those like our heroine, Tris, who lies outside any of the neatly defined roles demanded by the social power structure ...

Good one, on the whole. Plenty of action while staying close to the "humanly possible" range, interesting portrayal of the evil intellectuals, gritty "basic training" sequences - but I found the segregation of newcomers and natives inadequately explained. Likewise, the lack of hormonal involvement when teens of both sexes are thrown together in privacy-deficient living quarters. Especially when those young men and women are so whole-heartedly devoted to their physical selves, and to physical awareness of others. Oh, there's more than a hint of something simmering for Our Heroine, but it's surprisingly chaste - well, that's better than the pasted-on romantic involvements that so many movies suffer.

Good entertainment, but not one for the ages.

-- wiredweird

(*) I mean, this seems well done as movies - I haven't read the books and can not comment on them as adaptations.

I'm only reviewing the movie as I did not read the book:  The visual effects were really good and clean, the acting was ok and if anyone can tell me the point of the story I would appreciate it. I read a lot of YA novels and I watch almost all of the movies that go along with the books and this has to by far be the best one. The casting was amazing. Shailene Woodley and Theo James did a great job as Tris and Four. They were pretty much exactly as I pictured them from the book.
I thought they did a really good job picking which moments from the book to put into the movie and that it would be pretty easy for people that have not read the book to figure out what is going on.
The only thing I wished there was more of were the little scenes here and there between Tris and Four. There were a few missing from the movie and I think if they had included a few more that it would have been easier to see how their relationship developed.
Overall the movie was full out just the right amount of action with a love story that did not overwhelm the rest of the movie.

I was a big fan of the book so I approached the movie with skepticism . . . movies rarely live up to the written versions. I was happily surprised to find that, in this case, I actually preferred the movie to the book. While the book bogged down at times, the movie was nicely streamlined and entertaining and the chemistry between the two main characters was much more palpable than in the book.

The movie is set in a not-so-distant future where society has been divided into five factions, each with a principal driving philosophy. The amity are kind and grow the food, the erudite are intelligent and conduct research and science, the candor are honest and manage justice, the dauntless are brave and act as soldiers, and the abnegation are selfless and conduct charity and run the government. While it sounds like a utopian society, there are also the factionless . . . those that have no faction and roam the streets without purpose. And then there are the divergent . . . those that don't clearly fall into any of the factions. Do they represent a threat to the utopian society?

I loved this book. And loved the movie even more.

Two things first 1) I am not the typical audience being a male in his 60's.  2) I read the book before I saw the film.  The acting was very good but Shailene Woodley was too physically big for the role of Tris (as bad as Tom Cruise being too small to play Jack Reacher even if he did a good acting job as did Woodley).  The film adaptation was bad in that if I hadn't read the book the film would have been hard to understand.  Too much was left out or sketched too lightly or just plain changed.  The pacing wasn't even either. The burgeoning relationship between the two main protagonist was just plain hokey though to be fair it was better than the book in that they spent a lot less time sighing, kissing and hugging -- teenage girls might love it but it was too gushy for me. I didn't see the film in an IMAX theater and I thought the focus was really fuzzy though cinematography was generally very good.  If you're a fan of the book(s) do go see it.  I'm not sorry I did (2 of my favorite actresses, Ashley Judd and Maggie Q were in it though in tiny bit parts)  even if I was disappointed.  The acting and cinematography were strong enough to overcome the defects to give it 3 stars.

Dystopia , teenage love is the attraction the authors reliant is upon

The attraction the authors reliant upon is point , correct ?  The point ?

Is the teenage love really " teenage love "  Catch the meaning ?

Is it truth , lie , half truth  , misunderstanding ?

And where does cliche fall in the mix ?

The entire point of the lecture is to gage the success

Success ? Is relying on dystopia for the hidden message an attempt to join with the enemy , so to speak ?

Or is it relying on a cliche resulted from miscommunication ,

If the latter is true , then is it obvious ?

The message appears , at first glance , to be simple , yet probe deeper , it's more complex ,

Ok. So I got back from seeing Divergent with the kids and a friend and I have to say I do not understand the hype. It's formulaeic with a silly premise. Fortunately, it's also really long.

The movie was just silly, I thought. There was so much that was just plain goofy... like why would these five factions create stability? Why would someone's personality make them immune to a drug? Why would you be banished (factionless) if you wanted to switch? Why can't you have a job and still talk to your family? I could go on, but the more I think about it, the more I think this was an awful movie made just to capitalize on the Hunger Games... kinda like the vampire craze that hit a few years ago. Perhaps the most ridiculous part of the movie was the conclusion: They just exposed a plot by one faction to eliminate another and saved yet another faction from becoming mind-controlled mass-murderers. So why do they have to run as if they are criminals? Because they are 'divergent?' For this being the core of the whole movie- and the title- it was never explained even a little why this is a bad thing.

Anyway, so seeing this movie without reading the book for me. This was really good. Makes me wish I had not heard or seen the Hunger Games so I can view this movie objectively without comparing it to Hunger Games. But I did enjoy this story, and I really enjoy Tobias aka Four character and the relationship he develops with Tris.

I recommend that if you enjoyed Hunger Games. You will love this!

The things they took out were minor but weremade up with what they added to make the film as awesome as it was, it was basically for most of the part like how I imagined the book in my mind. It was fan-dang-tastic! I cannot wait for Insurgent

Theatrical review.  There may be spoilers.

While long removed from the film's young adult target audience, I like a good movie.  In particular, I'm always on the lookout for some science fiction opportunities.  In a not particularly new premise established here, we are set in a somewhat distant future Chicago.  The world, or at least Chicago, is in a crumbled state.  We're not sure what happened but the city is encircled in a giant electrified fence.  The humans have been living and working together but in 5 unique and distinct sects.  Each of the 5 are characterized by their primary human traits.

For example Dauntless or The Brave are the warrior-soldiers who protect the population.  Abnegation or The Selfless essentially run the government.  Erudite or The Intelligent are the scientists, the thinkers.  The others are Amity or The Peaceful and Candor or The Honest.  I found it interesting that each faction had to have its own dictionary definition to go along with its name.  Each year a group of teens are tested to determine which faction they are best suited for.  They don't have to go there - they can go anywhere - but there they must stay.

Our heroine, Beatrice/Tris (rising star Shailene Woodley), resides with her parents (Ashley Judd and Tony Goldwyn) and her teen brother Caleb (Ansel Elgort) as part of Abnegation.  After being tested by a sympathetic Tori (Maggie Q), it is determined that Tris has no specific faction she is cut out for.  People like this are called Divergents and are considered problematic by the Erudite.  These people are prime contenders to lead rebellions against the current way of life.  Tori advises Tris to keep the results to herself.  She would be in danger if found out.  Once at the decision point, Tris surprises everyone by choosing Dauntless.

She heads off for training immediately on the outskirts of the city.  She and others who defect from other factions are placed under the training tutelage of Four (newcomer Theo James).  The middle section of the film deals with the trials and tribulations of Tris's adaptation to a soldier lifestyle, something she obviously isn't prepared for.  But she is determined and smart and then there is Four.  He's also smart, tough and real cute.  The filmmakers don't hide much, showing that Tris has a big crush on her trainer.

The final act digs deeper into the Erudite's desire to control both the government and the people.  This means an overthrow of the Abnegation including Tris's father who is a councilman.  A serum has been developed in secret that will cause the Dauntless to mindlessly follow the orders of the controlling Erudite headed by Jeannine (Kate Winslet).  Tris and Four are unaffected by the serum and work together to pull the plug.  "Divergent" is an entertaining enough film.  It will certainly draw comparisons to the "Twilight" franchise and more closely to "The Hunger Games."  Is there room for more?  Well, we'll see, but I suspect yes.  Woodley and James work well together and are believable in their roles.  Sequel(s) are coming.  As far as this film.  It is much better than any of the "Twilight" films, but falls short of "The Hunger Games" in terms of content and production value.

DVD has not been released -
The movie would be entertaining for a wider audience than just adolescent females; although, I imagine younger women would be able to relate better to the story and the protagonist.  I did not read the book, so my experience was of just the film.  It is for the premise I gave this a rating of four stars.  I wonder if the focus were more on the politics and the relationships between the factions, if this movie would have a greater appeal to a wider audience.  Then, I am sure many would bemoan the movie straying from the book and turning into a sci-fi drama.
I would enjoy seeing the premise explored further, even if it means straying from the book. Some details, seemingly trivial to some, may actually detract from the credibility or seem contradictory - for example (warning! possible spoiler for some) if Beatrice was raised in Abnegation, and she is not to even look at her image in the mirror for long since it is a sign of vanity, why is her hair frosted?  Would that not be considered vain?  There are other examples, but I tried to pick the most benign - Many unanswered questions (I want to know more about the mom, and the dad and the relationship between them, how one faction was able to convince leaders of another ... )
Nonetheless, despite some flaws, some slow moments, and many unanswered interesting questions, the movie is worth seeing.
Is it worth owning? That's an individual decision - how many times can you watch it?

this book was very good and for the most was true to the book. there were at least 2 scenes that were changed from the book. However, I suggest reading the book preferably before or after. There were a lot of things missing in the movie that were in the book and those things explains quite a bit. our children saw the movie with us and our oldest could tell there were things missing so she's reading the book to fill in those blanks.

Watched this in the theaters on a special cheap-o movie day, but it would probably have been worth a full price ticket.

First off, a disclaimer: I haven't read the Divergent books, so I cannot say how faithful the film is to the story, or if the feel is authentic to the author's vision.

That said, I could not help but compare Divergent to Hunger Games, as one success tends to breed a slew of offspring in the genre. Divergent feels like another YA dystopian sci-fi offering, much in the vein of Hunger Games--- girl grows up in alternate (or potential) future, in a post-semi-apocalyptic society. Due to political unrest, girl must endure hardship and survive in a brutal world, despite enemies and in order to protect loved ones.

Where the Hunger Games world felt fully fleshed-out, and the characters' stories were instantly more heart-wrenching, as they were in the thick of tragedy before the story began; the Divergent movie starts off with things seeming to be "okay" and the problems are slowly built up as the story progresses. The Divergent world feels a bit more shallow, has more plot holes and by the end of the film one is only just seeing Tris begin to come into her own.

I can't tell if this is because, having read the Hunger Games, I subconsciously filled in film-absent plot gaps with details from the novels, or if Divergent just isn't *quite* as good a series. It also felt like 75% of the Divergent film was a slow burn up to something more, but I really don't if the next two films will deliver without knowing the story line. I guess I am going to have to read the books and add an update to this review.

Bottom line: the film was entertaining, the acting was decent, the story shows promise and left me both curious to see the next film as well as wanting to check out the books--- which sounds like a fair success to me. I would watch it again, at least once.

Update: I finally read Divergent, and the other two books as well. I feel like the movie did a pretty good job of representing the book, but as often happens with film, there are bits left out which could have been helpful to the plot or to characterization. I wouldn't say any of the omissions really make the movie confusing, because I don't feel that wanting to question something or taking educated guesses at a mystery is confusing, but others might not like it. My guess is that the omissions from this film should be plenty clarified in the following segment. Lastly, I think the chosen actors all suited their roles. From YA book to movie I would say all the little ducks lined up in a pretty tidy row.

This movie is fantastic. The actors in it are amazing, and the story is very well told. I'll admit, some of the things in it weren't completely accurate to the book, but there are very few movies that are one hundred percent true to the book. Even the hunger games missed a big part. I think that Shailene Woodley (Tris) and Theo James (Four) had amazing chemistry, and I was fangirling the whole time I was watching it. SO MUCH FOURTRIS FEELS IN THIS MOVIE. I love the way Theo James portrays Four, and I think they do an amazing job of showing Tris's character development from the beginning where she's a Stiff who is really innocent and meek to where she's a Dauntless badass who seems almost completely fearless. I love the soundtrack in this movie, my favorite being Find You. Overall, this is just an awesome movie, and I would definitely recommend watching this and reading the book as well.
This movie is excellent. It follows the book as much as it cam. There were no weak moments. Loved ths movie.

I'll be honest - I haven't read the book yet. I started it but heard it was going to be a movie so I stopped. I find myself usually disappointed with movies made from books so I figured this way the movie had a fighting chance. :) I was pleasantly surprised by Divergent! I'll admit I'm a little over this whole dystopian thing but found the story line intriguing. I was immediately sucked in. They did a great job of explaining how the government was set up and why and the different factions without boring me to death or leaving me confused as to what was going on. I was a little worried about the casting - I've never heard of Shailene Woodley and didn't know if she could carry the movie but she was fantastic. She was emotional, believable, and best of all likable. I found myself empathizing with her and hoping she would succeed. I like the crackle of energy between her and Theo James. In the previews he seemed so intense that I wasn't sure I'd like seeing them together but once the movie got going I realized that his character was just really intense but it worked fantastic. The movie was paced really well - it was exciting but without being frenetic and never boring. I'd definitely recommend this movie - totally worth the 2.5 hours!!!
This movie is amazing and I will be purchasing a copy of the blu-ray after I go see it in theaters again!

If you've read the book, then you might notice a few changes to the film adaption. The movie was still good despite the changes but I feel that the director could have slowed down the film some and gave us more insight into the character's thoughts and background information. There were a few scenes in the book that I felt would have done well in the movie but were left out.

Divergent is a film based on Veronica Roths bestselling dystopian trilogy and its just as amazing as The Hunger Games, if not better. After a string of box-office misfires (Beautiful Creatures, The Host, Mortal Instruments), Hollywood was looking for the next big thing and Divergent truly fits the criteria.  Dont dismiss Divergent as just a Hunger Games wanna-be, this is by far the best movie of 2014, hands down.

  Divergent takes place in a post-apoclayptic Chicago in which society is divided into four factions to ensure that humanity can live on in peace and harmony. The five factions are Dauntless (the brave), Amity (the peaceful), Abnegation (the selfless), Candor (the honest) and Erudite (the intellects) and on initiation day, teens are expected to choose a faction to live in for the rest of their lives. Beatrice Tris Prior recieves inconclusive test results because shes Divergent and she doesnt fit into her societys narrow categories. Tris chooses to join the Dauntless and she discovers that being brave will be the difference between life and death.

  Right off the bat, Divergent begins with a gorgeous panaroma of a dilapidated Chicago and from that moment on,  viewers know that this is no ordinary tale. Though the world of Divergent is extremely intricate, the filmmakers capture every single aspect of this society vividly. There is no doubt in my mind that this is a film that both fans of the book and newcomers alike can enjoy because all of the world-building and explanations are easy to comprehend and intriguing.

  Shailene Woodley plays the fierce, determined Tris and she really helps viewers understand what it means to be Dauntless. Though Tris isn't always as tough as she might like, viewers will fall in love with her despite her moments of insecurity and uncertainty. Hollywood needs to feature more strong female characters like Tris Prior that could serve as role models for generations of young women. The world doesnt need another Bella Swan, it needs more passionate, driven characters like Tris and Katniss Everdeen. Woodley is magnetic alongside her co-star, Theo James who plays the Dauntless instructor Four. The chemistry between the two is undeniable and its nearly impossible not to root for this couple and their relationship. Divergent makes the romance extremely engaging and their relationship helps mitigate the dark undertones of the Dauntless faction.

  With a thrilling mixture of action, adventure and romance, Divergent is executed perfectly and not a single moment in this film is meaningless.  Viewers will always be on the edge on their edge of their seats especially in the Simulation scenes and these scenes are equally terrifying as they are entertaining. Divergent is simply a must-see and its easy to see why millions have fallen in love with Tris and Four in Veronica Roths novels. Fans will come out of the theaters, dying to see Insurgent, the sequel to Divergent, and will practically be counting the seconds till its release. Divergent doesnt just live up to the hype, it exceeds the hype and raises the bar for sci-fi thrillers.

Nine Things about the Movie Divergent

1.  This film is based on the first book of the popular young adult trilogy of novels.

2. If you haven't noticed, contemporary young adult stories typically follow a set formula - an innocent kid joins a larger society and must be categorized. But then the kid discovers they are special, which causes problems for the society, and the kid must lose their innocence to survive in a dangerous world . Some recent examples are The Hunger Games, Enders Game, and the Harry Potter series. Divergent sticks to that exact same formula.

3. Just because you have seen this basic story multiple times does not mean the movie is bad. These kinds of stories are popular because it is the archetypal heros journey myth, and, if they are well-made, hit a nerve with us. Such movies can sometimes become classics - The Wizard of Oz, The Lord of the Rings and Star Wars are other, older examples of pretty much the exact same story.

4. Thankfully, Divergent is well done, and holds its own among its cinematic peers. Its about a girl named Tris who takes a test (kind of like Harry Potters sorting hat or Enders training monitor) to discover which of five distinct factions she will become a member of (like Hogwarts Houses or the Zones in The Hunger Games). But she is so special that the test breaks, and nobody knows what to do with her (like all the stories I just mentioned). So she must trust her gut and decide in secret.

4. Tris chooses her faction and begins her training, but shes so gifted that she draws attention to herself, not only from her fellow classmates, but from her hunky instructor, too. And the leaders of another faction, who have controversial political aspirations.

5. The movie handles the usual themes well - conformity vs. independence, fear vs. bravery, and the trauma of growing up. But it also subtly asks a couple of bigger questions that are unfortunately not explored here; questions like What is human nature, anyway? and While conformity may seem bad, what would happen if we were all independent?.

6. The acting is decent, and the main characters have good chemistry. Thankfully, the movie delays the inevitable romance as long as it can, and tries not to let it get in the way of the bigger story.

7. Being aimed at young adults, there is not much blood or death, but some people may be surprised that there is a relatively high amount of violence, both explicit and implied.

8. The other two books, Insurgent and Allegiant, are expected to be made into movies and released in theaters in 2015 and 2016, respectively.

9. So yes, the story is old and predictable. No, Divergent won't become a timeless classic. But if you aren't just totally over this type of movie, its worth seeing. And it makes you realize why this same story keeps getting turned into movies over and over again: The issues that teenagers struggle with never go away. Mothers, fathers, sons and daughters are all dealing with the same existential problems. Only our perspective changes. And sometimes our choices.
I feel that it followed the book really well and was very action packed- good for all audiences.  Definitely worth owning! Already pre ordered digital copy!

Here is another series based on Veronica Roth's world-wide best-selling Young Adult trilogy. Again we have the alienated teenager in a post-apocalyptic world, which is divided into five disciplines: Candor (Honest); Abnegation (Selfless); Erudite (Intelligent); Amity (Peaceful); and Dauntless (Brave). Each faction has its own responsibility; this separation creates a smoothly running society.

Each young adult is tested so he or she will make an informed decision as they bet their life (kind of a Harry Potter Sorting Hat). Problem is, there are a few unusual folks who have aptitudes for more than one discipline ...to their great peril and they aren't allowed to change their mind! Our heroine could belong to three different factions, so her troubles begin...

We watch:
  * Shailene Woodley ("The Decendants") is our heroine Tris, trying to fit in, despite her "special mind." She opts for the Dauntless faction even though her parents are Abnegation. (Her brother goes to Erudite.)
  * Theo James (he was that dead Turk in Lady Mary's bed in Season One of "Downton Abbey") is Four, a demanding Dauntless training instructor.
  * Kate Winslet ("Labor Day") is the icy Christine Matthews; she utterly believes in the system.
  * Zo Kravitz ("After Earth") is Christina, a sweet colleague who, like Tris, is just trying to survive.
  * Ray Stevenson ("Thor"); Marcus Eaton wants forgiveness from his absent son.
  * Ashley Judd ("Dolphin Tale") is Natalie Prior, our heroine's mother.
  * Tony Goldwyn ("Scandal") is Andrew Prior, her father.

This is far more "Hunger Games" than "Twilight," in that we have a strong heroine who doesn't wait to be rescued. In addition, our heroine has to work hard to develop her skills, like Katniss in "Hunger Games," not just be born beautiful like Bella.

Director Neil Burger ("Limitless") never loses sight of the PG-13 rating, we can expect some gunfire, martial arts and a teeny bit of profanity, but no sweaty bodies, e.g., our heroine tells a would-be lover, "I want to take it slow." The YA bones show, but that is to be expected. The young gals in the audience seemed to have a splendid time, and I did NOT suffer! Amazon has (as of 03-22-14) a pre-order link for the DVD. I've ordered mine....

In a futuristic postwar Chicago, society is divided into five factions based on individuals' defining characteristic or interest, from courage to honesty to intelligence and so on.  By extension, each serves a well-defined purpose, from policing to scientific research.  Placement is determined through mental testing, and those who do not find their rightful place are either murdered or lead lives of desperation on the street.  Such is the high concept of Divergent, which focuses in particular on a teenage girl, Beatrice or "Tris," who discovers her mind contains elements of each faction and tries at first to hide this to avoid becoming a target of her city's overbearing, even dangerous government.  On the surface, the idea is rather preposterous since each person has more than one dimension and an interior life of many colors:  for instance, a policeman's duty requires at least a degree of curiosity and wit, not just drive-on, no-question nerve.  At the same time, however, the idea has a certain charm, viewed through teenage eyes in particular:  does not every adolescent at one point or another believe he or she is a lone complex soul in a sea of conforming friends and, worse still, adults (parents, perhaps, or teachers) demanding a safe, well-defined plan for the future?  Here this sweet byproduct of youthful navel-gazing is cast as an outsize science-fiction action/adventure saga, and the result is highly entertaining.

Director Neil Burger, whose previous credits include Interview with the Assassin and The Illusionist (with Edward Norton), has a potent visual style and understands how to stage set pieces with agility, atmosphere, and clarity.  He has particular fun with the many sequences which find the heroine undergoing mental examination, rendering her very imagination as a perilous and ever-shifting space on the screen; it even becomes a literal hall of mirrors at one point.  And in the lead role, one which both she and her agent no doubt hope will elevate her closer to Jennifer Lawrence status, Shailene Woodley is convincing in her portrayal of fragility giving way to ferocity as Tris' physicality hardens alongside her resolve to survive and rebel.  A capable ensemble further shade the film and, in the case of Kate Winslet as the icily regal antagonist, lend it an air of prestige.  The film, I concede, loses a bit of focus and flair in its final 25 minutes as if it realizes how long it is and begins racing toward the end credits.  As a result, the final confrontations are not as riveting as the earlier ones despite having grander implications.  Overall, though, this is a persuasive start to what I hope will become a worthwhile trilogy.
